DEBATE.TITLE: PUBLIC SERVICE (ABOLITION OF COMPULSORY RETIREMENT AGE) AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Patterson) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to remove restrictions on serving in the public service after attaining the age of 65 years.
Motion (by Senator Patterson) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: This private member's bill, the Public Service (Abolition of Compulsory Retirement Age) Amendment Bill 1995 is a bill to abolish compulsory retirement in the Australian Public Service. It will allow the recruitment of officers by the Commonwealth after the age of 65 and it will allow people who are employed by the Commonwealth to work beyond the current retirement age of 65 years.

This bill covers Commonwealth Employment and the Australian Public Service only. It does not transcend state rights but complements current state legislation relating to age discrimination and/or compulsory retirement. The act will take effect on the day it receives Royal Assent.

This is not the first time I have introduced a Private Senators bill to remove compulsory age retirement in the public service. In 1992 I introduced a similar bill which lapsed when the 1993 election was called. Since 1990 the Coalition has consistently amended Government legislation to prevent Government appointments from automatically expiring at age 65.

During that time the Government has obfuscated, delayed and uttered a few platitudes but done nothing. In 1990 the Minister for Social Security, in a media release dated 13 September, gave an undertaking to remove age discrimination from all existing federal legislation. Nothing has been done in the five years since then except that an inquiry has been instigated—a Task Force chaired by the Attorney General's Department, which is examining the issue and was originally to report in Autumn 1991.

Apparently the Task Force is now due to report shortly but how many times have we heard that. Meanwhile nothing is done to abolish discrimination on the basis of age in the Commonwealth Public Service and there is no evidence of the Government's commitment to moving to end compulsory age retirement in the near future.

There are no clearly articulated policy reasons for the retention of compulsory age retirement in the APS and more importantly treating public servants less favourably than private sector employees. The fact is the Commonwealth has direct power to amend the Public Service Act in relation to compulsory age retirement without relying on the external affairs power..

Despite this and the overwhelming arguments against compulsory age retirement, the Government has continued to discriminate against its own employees in relation to this issue. Moreover, the Commonwealth has been able to take advantage of its own unique status as an employer to avoid the very anti-discrimination laws it has foisted upon other employers.

Government inactivity further defies explanation given that the effect upon Commonwealth finances is likely to be negligible. Only a relatively small number of Commonwealth public servants are likely to be affected by the removal of compulsory age retirement. Only 2.2 per cent of permanent Commonwealth public servants are aged 60 and over, and in the year ending June 1994, there were 974 age retirements from the APS that is only 11 per cent of total separations. Of these age retirements, only 249 were amongst permanent staff aged 64 or over. As at 30 June 1994, there were 81 permanent public servants aged 65. (Source: Dept. of Finance, Australian Public Service Statistical Bulletin 1993-94, pp59 and 103)

Currently, The Public Service act imposes a mandatory retiring age of 65 with a limited (and not widely known) provision for staff beyond 65 to be able to continue working at the secretary's discretion (s.76V for non-SES staff and s.76J for SES staff plus s.76C). The act also provides for an option to retire at an earlier age. Finally, the existing act provides a bar to certain appointments of persons over 65 years of age or for a period extending beyond that age.

Amendments to the Public Service Act in this bill will cover the major areas of public sector employment, including amendments to the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act, amendments to the Commonwealth Teaching Service Act and amendments to the Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act. However, by necessity, there are some exemptions. The Judiciary, following an amendment to the Constitution in 1977, retire on reaching age 70. The armed forces and the police force will also be exempt.
The arguments in support of abolishing retirement age are overwhelming.

For most people in our society, their identity, status and self-esteem derive almost entirely from their jobs, but as the population ages and life expectancy increases, people will spend a much longer period of time outside the paid workforce in retirement. Compulsory retirement for an increasing number of the active aged has meant exclusion from the workforce, lower incomes and the implication that the person has less to contribute than earlier in life. Because it is fixed at a particular age, it makes no allowance for individual differences in fitness or capacity in older people.

Australia has particular international obligations to remove age discrimination under various treaties, most particularly under the International labour organisation's Discrimination (Employment and Occupancy) Convention 1958 (ILO 111).

The current provisions of the Public Service Act are inconsistent with the thrust of the provisions in the Industrial Relations Reform Act 1993 which amends the Industrial Relations Act 1988 to provide that employers must not terminate an employee's employment on the grounds of age (s.170DF). The Government has chosen to interpret the Industrial Relations Reform Act so narrowly that in effect it exempts itself from the anti-discriminatory legislative measures it has itself introduced in the IRA legislation. The Commonwealth has argued that the anti-discrimination provisions of the IRA are confined to terminations at the initiative of the employer rather than terminations that occur as the result of the operation of the law, in this case s.76V of the PSA. One may well ask how, if the Reform Act is intended to operate universally, is it that a major employer, the Commonwealth, is not bound by it?

The current legislative position at a Commonwealth level contrasts with the situation at a state and Territory level, where legislation relating to age discrimination has been passed by all Governments other than Victoria and Tasmania. In those states with anti-age discrimination legislation, compulsory age retirement is prohibited in NSW, Qld, WA and SA. It is exempt in the act until 4 March 1996 (at the end of which it will be prohibited), and it is exempt without qualification in the NT. It is worth noting that the states and Territories which have abolished compulsory age retirement do not report any significant difficulties with the changes to their public service employment conditions.

In 1992 the Government's response to the House of Representatives Standing Committee for Long Term Strategies Report, Expectations of Life: Increasing the Options for the 21st Century gave in principle support to ending compulsory age retirement. However they have yet to act on this commitment.

The Report of the Public Service Act Review Group (The McLeod Report) which was tabled in December 1994, concluded that compulsory age retirement should not be included in any revision of the Public Service Act:
Recommendation 51: compulsory age retirement should not be included in the new (Public Service) Act,

A Task Force, chaired by the Attorney General's Department, which is examining the issue was originally to report in Autumn 1991—four years ago! and has already indicated to the McLeod Review that it supports the abolition of compulsory age retirement.
The Government has raised a number of issues that have been used as excuses for not acting to abolish compulsory retirement age. These include:

Possible effects on the Comcare scheme. Under the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 the entitlement to weekly payments ceases at age 65 for those injured after 1 December 1988. For the purpose of Comcare, 65 years is used as the deemed normal retirement age of employees and the current Comcare policy is not to move recipients of Comcare benefits onto Social Security until the retirement age of 65. If the age of 65 were to be removed as the normal retirement age, the current Comcare coverage policy would mean that there would be no point at which there would be a justification for ending the payment of benefits, apart from the death of the injured public servant.

There are however various possibilities for "capping" the Comcare benefits paid to injured public servants if the standard retirement age of 65 were to be removed. These include a scheme modelled on the NSW option—which involves termination of payments after two years if the injury occurs when the employee is over 65.

Ramifications in the area of superannuation. Currently membership of the Commonwealth's superannuation schemes is allowed after age 65; however the occupational superannuation standards set limits on the payment of contributions and new accruals of benefits after that age. The McLeod Report suggested that consideration be given by the Dept. of Finance and Comsuper to the feasibility of allowing more flexible working arrangements before retirement with minimal impact on superannuation entitlements.

Impact on young job-seekers. Some have argued that the presence of staff beyond age 65 discriminates against prospective new entrants in that they are occupying positions that other (younger) people might otherwise hold. In answer to this, there is evidence from other jurisdictions which have removed maximum retiring ages which suggests that there has not been a significant increase in the number of staff beyond age 65 who have sought to continue working. In addition it is a philosophically flawed argument to discriminate against one group in order to promote the rights of another group. This type of argument was used to preclude married women from participating in the workforce.
Compulsory retirement on the basis of age is discriminatory just as distinguishing in employment on the basis of sex, marital status, religion and many other factors is discriminatory.
For five years the Commonwealth Government has delayed introducing legislation to abolish compulsory age retirement in the Commonwealth public service.
In 1990 the Minister for Social Security gave an undertaking that he would remove age discrimination from all existing federal legislation. Nothing was done.

In 1993 Senator Bolkus indicated that the Government intended to act BUT "the Attorney-General's Department is working towards the development of a comprehensive Commonwealth age discrimination policy". How long do we have to wait?

Are the difficulties of drafting appropriate legislation so great? Surely if all states except Tasmania have either introduced age-discrimination legislation or are in the process of introducing it, the obstacles cannot be insurmountable.

I would argue that this Government is not committed to the abolition of age discrimination. If it was committed, it would have acted in the last five years to remove compulsory age retirement in the Public Service.

This Government had no trouble overcoming the many problems encountered in drafting the Mabo legislation or the Sex Discrimination legislation or the Racial Hatred legislation, all examples of changes it really wanted. But it has obfuscated and delayed any action on age discrimination.
If it were committed to older Australians and the abolition of compulsory age retirement it would have acted before now. In the absence of Government action I am introducing this bill.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —This private member's bill, the Public Service (Abolition of Compulsory Retirement Age) Bill 1995, is a bill to abolish compulsory retirement in the Australian Public Service. It will allow the recruitment of officers past the age of 65 by the Commonwealth and it will allow people who are employed by the Commonwealth to work beyond the current retirement age of 65 years. An identical bill will be introduced into the House of Representatives by Mr Connolly next sitting week.

PARA.TAB: Discrimination on the basis of age has been a longstanding concern of the coalition. Abolition of age discrimination and compulsory age retirement has been part of coalition policy since 1988. In 1992 I introduced a similar bill to abolish compulsory age retirement in the Public Service. That bill lapsed when the 1993 election was called. Since 1990 the coalition has consistently amended government legislation to prevent government appointments from automatically expiring at age 65.

I am introducing this bill now because, despite endless politically correct rhetoric and many undertakings that the government would legislate to abolish age discrimination, this government has done nothing. It has had ample time and every opportunity to legislate against age discrimination and to abolish compulsory age retirement in its own sphere, the Public Service. It has done nothing.

In a media release dated 13 September 1990, the Minister for Social Security gave an undertaking to remove age discrimination from all existing federal legislation. Nothing has been done by the government in five years since then except that an inquiry has been instigated—a task force chaired by the Attorney-General's Department, which was originally to report in autumn 1991 but has now been examining the issue for almost five years.

In 1993, Senator Bolkus indicated that the government intended to act but `the Attorney-General's Department is working towards the development of a comprehensive Commonwealth age discrimination policy.' Still nothing was done. How long do we and how long do Australians have to wait?

In the meantime we have had the Industrial Relations Reform Act, ILO conventions, the government's in-principle concurrence with amendments aimed at solving the problem, committees, discussion papers, reports and court challenges. Yet after all is said and done the status quo remains.

Commonwealth public servants must retire at age 65 and, despite the rhetoric and a few platitudes about being committed to removing this blatant and arbitrary discrimination, the government has not only done nothing, it has frustrated any attempts by the coalition to minimise the discrimination.

Older Australians are justifiably outraged by the existence of age discrimination. To be denied employment opportunities solely on the basis of age, without regard to ability, qualifications or experience, is no less offensive than discrimination on the basis of sex, race or religion—areas in which we have wholeheartedly embraced anti-discrimination measures.

The fact is there is no arbitrary point in life where one can say you are no longer a productive and worthwhile member of the work force. There is no magic in the age of 65—rather it is an age related to an earlier era when life expectancy was less and active and healthy ageing less common.

The reality is that this government is not committed to older Australians and the abolition of age discrimination and compulsory age retirement. If it was committed, it would have acted in the last five years, since it first gave an undertaking to abolish age discrimination. It has done nothing in that time.
In the absence of government action I am again introducing a bill. I will continue to introduce amendments until age discrimination is completely eliminated from the legislation of this parliament.
Debate (on motion by Senator Faulkner) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present report No. 9 of 1995 relating to the facilities for an increased army presence in the North (APIN) Stage 2, and move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1989 the committee recommended the construction of facilities for the relocation to Darwin of the 2nd Cavalry Regiment, a reconnaissance unit which had been located at Holsworthy, New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: The Defence Force structure review announced in 1991 determined that a regular army brigade would be permanently based in Darwin by the end of the decade. This was to be achieved by the staged relocation of southern-based units to Darwin. APIN is part of the overall Defence move to the north which encompasses the activities of the three services. It is not about the defence of Darwin, but about the defence of Australia.

In November 1992 the committee tabled a report recommending the construction of facilities for units relocating to Darwin under stage 1. The report which I have tabled recommends the provision of suitable working, training and accommodation facilities for army units relocating to Darwin under APIN stage 2, at an estimated outturn cost of $264 million. Currently there are no Defence facilities in Darwin of suitable size, function or location, capable of meeting the requirements of a brigade-size force. A need therefore exists to construct additional facilities at Robertson Barracks and to construct additional ammunition storage facilities at Marrara Swamp, RAAF Base Darwin.

In response to concerns expressed at the public hearing concerning the storage of ammunition at Marrara Swamp, RAAF Base Darwin, the committee notes that all storage is in accordance with the United Nations hazardous goods classification procedures and NATO safety principles.

An issue raised at the public hearing concerned the payment of subcontractors. The committee therefore recommends that the Department of Defence continue to include in its contracts a clause stating that subcontractors must be paid before progress payments are made to contractors. The committee was impressed with the willingness of the Department of Defence to hold discussions with contractors and to conduct seminars explaining how business is conducted with the department. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Economics Legislation Committee on the Competition Policy Reform Bill 1995, together with submissions received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the referral of the Competition Policy Reform Bill to the Senate Economics Legislation Committee accomplished a couple of things. Firstly, it gave an opportunity to many of the groups affected by the legislation to raise questions about it and to seek clarification in many instances. This was the first time these groups had a chance to have any input or to gain first-hand knowledge of a major piece of economic legislation. Secondly, the committee hearings and submissions served to highlight the previously unacknowledged concern of the small business sector about how the national competition policy would affect it. We have heard much in the media about the benefits of deregulating water, gas, electricity and government-owned enterprises and how it would boost economic efficiency.

PARA.TAB: Little attention before has been focused on how the competition policy would affect small business and local government. Small businesses are concerned that relaxation of some regulations would lead to both a lowering of service standards and an increased concentration of market power in the hands of a few. This view has support from economic academics, including Dr Richard Copp from the Queensland University of Technology.

The major concern that arises as a result of committee hearings is the difficulty of getting straight answers about how the legislation will impact on small businesses and local government. This is not the result of a lack of cooperation. I congratulate the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator Schacht, for attending the hearings. I also congratulate the officials from the Treasury and elsewhere who spent hours providing advice and clarification to the committee forums. I also have a number of separate private briefings from Mr Cassidy.

The difficulty with this type of legislation is that the national competition policy bill assembles a framework to assist, review and reform anti-competitive behaviour wherever it is found in the economy—except the Labor taboo area of the labour market. The bill sets in place a reform process, but it does not tell us what the outcome will be or exactly what can be expected in small business and local government sectors. The bill imposes an economic philosophy—if you like, across an economy—and as such the experts appearing before the committee were handicapped in providing answers to specific questions about small business. We will not know the answer until the reform process is under way.

This is of great concern to those in small business and local government who cannot determine how it will affect them and their members. Much hinges on the state governments. The legislative reform process, which every government must undertake at every level, will be the key to determining how small business will be affected.

It was obvious at the committee hearings that little thought has been given to this mammoth process which is likely to catch up many unsuspecting small businesses who, if they have ever heard of Hilmer, still think it has nothing to do with them apart from the ambitious extra $1,500 in every household pocket. The hearings showed that a kaleidoscope of the nation's small businesses will come under the Hilmer thumb. I presented four pages listing legislation that I have been advised will be scrutinised in the process of the review in Queensland alone.

It was apparent that no-one at the hearings could provide definite answers on what would be the outcome of the reviews. It is of concern to the small business community that some of the reviews will be farmed out to the competition council and commission rather than being looked at locally by the state government. They are wary of the funding carrots being held out by the Commonwealth to enforce certain changes at state level.

Local government is in a similar quandary. As stated in the report, local government believes that the competition reforms will have a major impact on local government. Little work has been done to determine what this impact will be. To summarise, I quote from page three of the committee's report under the heading `General issues raised in evidence':

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation has the potential to be very far-reaching and may have an impact far broader than originally intended.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have quoted from the report but I do not have a copy in front of me. As honourable senators will see when they look at the report, there is a qualifying statement at the end of it which I have written on behalf of the Greens (WA). As Senator Boswell has discussed, a number of serious concerns were brought up in the two days of hearings that I attended. They were not inconsequential concerns.

PARA.TAB: Those concerns included statements from such groups as the Institute of Engineers. The institute had a concern, grounded in its experience of such things as the implications for the provision of electricity and water, in relation to the carry over of expertise and the possible loss of that experience with the transformation from government provision of utilities to private provision. Unfortunately, the government's response has tended to be that it is providing—as Senator Boswell suggested—a carrot and stick approach to privatisation and competition policy through the states. However, when the questions are asked the response is, `Ah, but that is up to the states'. I believe that is a cop-out.

The Institution of Engineers said that, in its estimation, any major change of this nature should be planned very carefully, and the institute found it difficult to locate anywhere in the proposals the resources provided for this careful planning to be carried out. Either the Commonwealth is pushing the states to make these changes or it is not. If it is pushing them faster than they would otherwise be going, or if it is pushing them fast at this stage and pushing us quickly to make these changes, there is a responsibility there. The responsibility is to make sure that when we make these changes we are doing it fully cognisant of what the implications are.

One of the questions that I asked during the hearings related to the experience of utilities in the United Kingdom. There has been a reasonable amount of discussion about this in the media at various times. We have had conflicting reports, political reports, about the implications of competition policy within the United Kingdom. Some people are saying, `There are serious ongoing problems,' and other people are saying, `No, we've got over this,' or, `They were only isolated pockets.'

On questioning, the Institution of Engineers clearly said that there are serious ongoing problems and that they would be able to provide the committee with information on that. Unfortunately, that meant that we would have needed to wait at least two weeks to receive that information from the United Kingdom. But, no, we had to make the decision so quickly that we did not have the ability to look at that experience from other countries.

Whatever you believe in relation to competition policy, I believe that it is not responsible for this parliament to be jumping in to actually legislate the changes until we have looked responsibly at what the implications are in those places that have made those kinds of changes. So, yes, we have heard some of the political debate about the implications in other countries, but it seems that it is not responsible unless we are prepared to look a little deeper.

There were, as we have heard, deep concerns from local government, largely about being left out of the consultation process. I have heard that on a number of occasions on a number of issues, including further discussion on such things as benchmarking that will be dealing with specific issues which local government will not be asked to participate in. So I am deeply concerned at this stage. That is why, whilst I acknowledge that the committee report acknowledges some of the serious concerns and the need to address those concerns, I am deeply worried that the recommendation is, `Let's go on with it anyway,' with undue haste without first working out how those serious concerns will be met.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be extremely brief. I note the committee report. Some honourable senators who are very interested in the question of competition policy will have noted that I have a number of questions on notice to Treasury and to certain other departments. I just suggest to the government through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that I look forward to receiving those answers fully and promptly so that I can determine my attitude about this matter on the basis of that full and prompt information being supplied. I know the government wants to get the program through, but I would request that the government ensures that Treasury provides the information that I, at least, have sought on this matter, and that it does so without the sort of obfuscation that one has seen, at times, from Treasury.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the tabling of this report from the chair of the Senate Economics Legislation Committee, I am still concerned about the questions that I asked regarding clause 73, which were on competition in New South Wales with respect to the cartage and transport of coal. New South Wales is going to be in a very bad position as far as competition policy goes if its state government does not go ahead with the reforms such as the ones that Queensland has already signed off at. It is going to give the coal producers in Queensland a distinct advantage over the coal producers in New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: The people that I am most concerned about are the coal producers in the Hunter Valley, for example, because of what I think is called `the third provider'. They will not get access to the reforms that other companies will if the New South Wales government does not go ahead in the way the previous coalition state government in New South Wales did. The submission put by the Hunter Valley rail project stated clearly that it was going to be at quite a disadvantage.

One of the problems we have with the coal industry in Australia is that we are at a disadvantage compared with our competitors in other countries in regard to freight rates. Our freight rates are something like $7 per tonne; we will have to reduce them by about $3 a tonne to really be competitive with other parts of the world.

But the main concern that I have here, and one which I do not really think was answered to my satisfaction, is that the people who are producing coal in the Hunter Valley—up as far as Boggabri and out as far as Ulan on the other spur of that group—basically will not be a part of it. There will be a disadvantage for those people if the state government does not go ahead. As I understand it the state government is just going to leave it on the backburner for those people in that area for the next five years. I think that is something, as far as competition policy or the competition reform bill goes, that really has to be thought about. I am referring to clause 73. I believe there should be an opt-in, opt-out arrangement as regards the latter concern so that the reforms will go through to the end users, that is, those coal producers in those areas.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 16th report of the Select Committee on Superannuation, entitled Allocated pensions, together with a preliminary paper prepared by the committee entitled Options for allocated pensions within the retirement incomes system, submissions and the Hansard transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This report provides a summation of the events concerning the proposal to change the treatment of allocated pensions for the purpose of social security means tests, and the subsequent repealing of the proposed changes prior to them taking effect. The report canvasses the submissions and evidence provided to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation on this issue, which assisted the government in forming its decision to repeal the proposed changes.

PARA.TAB: During the course of the inquiry the committee heard evidence of a product valued among superannuants because of its simplicity, flexibility and regularity. Allocated pensions are a somewhat hybrid product. They provide a regular income stream as well as access to lump sums if required. This product is viewed as a means of moving Australia from a lump sum to an income stream system.

The committee considered that the proposed amendments might not be necessary to address the perceived problem of double dipping. Therefore the committee met with the Hon. P.J. Baldwin, Minister for Social Security, and agreed to produce and present to him a preliminary paper. This was entitled Options for allocated pensions within the retirement incomes system. Following the presentation of this paper to the minister, the government then decided to repeal the amendments.

In summary, the repeal of the amendments to the Social Security Act 1991 resulted in allocated pensions continuing to be assessed as retirement income streams rather than as managed investments. The outcome in this retirement income matter demonstrates again the positive role that our committee is playing in furthering retirement incomes in Australia, because it is only through diligence and open-mindedness that this occurs. The committee is an important one for the Senate, and I thank all of those who have participated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise to speak to this 16th report of the Select Committee on Superannuation to note not only, as Senator Watson has said, that the committee played a positive role in resolving problems relating to retirement incomes—an increasing proportion of Australians quite properly take a great deal of interest in the work of this committee because retirement incomes policy is a matter of major concern to them—but also that the achievements of this committee have been possible only because of the outstanding leadership and contributions of Senator Watson. He is one of those senators who succeeds far more in his work and influence on legislation than he does in persuading the media that he is someone who should be given a great deal of attention. There is almost an inverse relationship between the real contribution people make in this place and the volume of media attention they receive.

PARA.TAB: I hope that Senator Watson's influence in this area, along with his influence in the area of tax reform—for which he has been acknowledged by his own professional association, the Institute of Chartered Accountants—will persist, and that he will continue to show the same sort of enthusiasm that he has demonstrated in leading this committee. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
