SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was responding yesterday to a very long speech that was given by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) on this matter, when he sought unnecessarily to take the time of the Senate to argue that he had been so unable to effectively manage the program that he needed further sitting days. In response, I was demonstrating that this requirement for further sitting days does arise from a failure—
—Get a decent tie.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—Order! Minister, it is irrelevant to make comments about the honourable senator's tie.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with my tie?
—It is in extraordinary good taste.
—You are wasting time again. When are we going to get on with the legislation; that is the question.

PARA.TAB: I was seeking to present an argument that, with reasonable management, further sitting days would be unnecessary. I explained to the Senate that, during the last sittings, the government had lost control of its program. The Manager of Government Business had, in effect, abdicated his position and responsibility for management of the government's program in this place and had sought to recover his position in relation to his own environment portfolio. He lost the confidence of the environmental lobby when he, in part, had to bring in a Natalie to advise him on these matters at public expense. The embarrassment was such that he had to give all his attention to the portfolio and found no time to do his job in the chamber. As a result, government legislation did stack up towards the last session.

This session, which was to be principally applied to dealing with the government's budget and financial bills that arose out of that budget, has now been cluttered up by the overlap of bills from the first session this year. The real question is: why should the Senate now have to return for extra sitting days due to the incompetence of the government? I see no argument for that at all.

Later this year we have another nine sitting weeks. They were the weeks in which the non-financial bills were to be dealt with. There is no reason why they cannot be dealt with at that time in the course of this year, unless the government has other plans for the balance of this year. I remind the minister that, in a spirit of cooperation, I suggested that we come back a week earlier in the August session so that some of his backlog could be dealt with at that time—a time when the House of Representatives is not sitting. It seemed to us, in a constructive way, to be a good opportunity to help the government out of its problems, but it was not interested in that proposal.

The issue then arose that, if the government would not accept the extra week of sittings that we offered, what other options were available. There certainly was discussion about two extra sitting Fridays. My attitude, and an attitude that I conveyed to the minister, was that if agreement could be reached on a program—in other words, if the government were serious and put to us the program of necessary bills, principally being the financial bills necessary to implement the government's budget—we would be cooperative in relation to those two days. Unfortunately, that has not been forthcoming either. The government has sought to fix its daily program to pursue objectives other than the implementation of its budget.

As I said yesterday, it was not until yesterday that the government finally started to bring budget bills onto the red. I think for the first time the government listed the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill 1995 on the red. That was the first indication that the government was serious about seeking the passage of its budget bills during this session, which was particularly set for that purpose. I know that the government has said that some bills are still in the House of Representatives, but there are a number of bills with starting dates for the end of June and the beginning of July that the government could be putting before this chamber. However, it has so far chosen not to do so. The flexibility of this government when it comes to the push is particularly demonstrated in how it has dealt with the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1995, a matter which my colleague Senator Short is particularly familiar with.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a bill of high priority.

—That is what we have been told for days, weeks and months—that it was a bill of the highest priority. Senator Short had written to the minister responsible for that bill, Senator Bolkus, suggesting that it should be deferred until after the full court had handed down its judgment. It is a somewhat unusual legislative practice to seek to intervene with a legislative process—a parliamentary process—while the issue is still before the court. That seemed a sensible and logical suggestion by Senator Short. What was the response of Senator Bolkus to Senator Short on 31 May 1995? The response was:

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot agree with this suggestion. The bill forms a key plank in the government's actions.
He continued:
The parliament must show leadership on this issue. We cannot place ourselves on the timetable of the courts. We will be continuing to seek the urgent passage of this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —And that was Senator Bolkus?
—That was Senator Bolkus. When the Manager of Government Business came in to address the issue of the timetable two sitting days ago, what did he say? In relation to this particular bill, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The government has decided not to proceed with consideration of that bill this sitting. We anticipate that by the time we return,—
that is, for the August sittings—

the full bench of the Federal Court will have delivered its judgment on the appeal which is the subject of this legislation. That decision will either make the legislation unnecessary or put the parliament in a better position to debate its merits.

Finally, after being asked so many times to act sensibly, the government came back and said, `Yes, we now concur and we will withdraw that bill.' In other words, `We will put the program into a more sensible shape and come back and address that at the proper time, which is after the Federal Court has handed down its judgment.'

PARA.TAB: What we ask of the government is that if it can finally under pressure be sensible in relation to one bill, I am sure it should not be beyond it to be sensible in relation to others. When it comes in here and puts down its proper program to implement the budget, to get these financial bills through the Senate, it will find that it will be dealing with them quickly and expeditiously. We have always cooperated with the government's program but the manager of government business must finally learn that cooperation is a two-way street. When the government starts reacting sensibly and puts a sensible program before the Senate, the legislation will reach the top of the Notice Paper more quickly than it does at the moment.

In concluding, I just say what a farce it was last night. The manager of government business will remember that we objected to this new sitting timetable but it was forced upon us by agreement between the government and the minority parties. At 10 to seven last night, when we were here ready and waiting to debate government legislation, the Senate adjourned because there were no government documents to be debated. So short of the appointed hour, the Senate adjourned. That is because the structure of this sitting program that the manager of government business set in his agreement with the minority parties is flawed. It was flawed when it was debated at that time. We said so but, of course, the manager of government business knew better. The government should get the program in order and it will get legislation through much more quickly than it does at the moment.

We believe that, unfortunately, it is necessary to apply some discipline to the government in this issue. Unless we do so it will continue to abuse the process of the Senate in the way that it has in the past and that is principally why we are objecting to these extra sitting days. We don't mind. We are full-time politicians. It makes no difference to me whether I am sitting in the chamber on Friday or doing other work pursuant to my obligations. I am happy to come back and sit on Friday but I would be happier to do so if the government was prepared to show some leadership in management of the program, which is its responsibility. On that basis, and in relation to the need to apply some pressure and discipline to this government, we are not supportive of the motion moved by the manager of government business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without taking up too much of the Senate's time, I want to strongly support Senator Hill's words and our opposition, for the reasons that he outlined, to the government's motion. In the 10 years that I have been in the Senate, I have never seen a legislative program in a greater shambles than this one. It is an absolute disaster, it is a disgrace and it appears from today's reports in the press that that is precisely how the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) sees it as well. I can understand the frustration that the House of Representatives must be feeling at what is happening here.

PARA.TAB: What is happening here is absolutely and entirely of the government's own making. It is a total lack of management on the government's part. There has also been an almost total lack of interest on the government's part in meeting any sort of respectable legislative program beyond, and perhaps including, the bills that it has been classifying as more urgent. There has been—and this distresses me greatly—a total contempt for the parliamentary processes and the role of the parliament.

This government and this Labor Party has always denigrated the role of the parliament. It sees itself in government as an executive that does not really need to listen to the views of the parliament. It sees the parliament basically as a rubber stamp. It treats, continues to treat and has always treated the parliament with contempt. That is shown very strongly in the situation into which the government has now got itself with regard to the absolute debacle of its legislative program.

As I said, there has been no sense of urgency on the government's part. As Senator Hill said, at the end of the last session, when we were trying to facilitate the work of the Senate, it took the whole of the final day of the last session to mount a quite spurious and personal attack on my colleague Senator Michael Baume.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a really high priority.

—An absolute top priority job, that one. It had nothing to do with legislation, nothing to do with anything relating to the federal parliament. It was all to do with the NSW elections. Yet this government, which says it has got such an urgent need to get legislation through, took the whole of the final day of the last session to attempt to deal with Senator Baume.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Hill said, it was only yesterday that any of the budget bills, any of the essential bills that need to be debated to implement the government's budget which was brought down a month ago, started to appear on the Senate Notice Paper. For the government to get up, beat its breast, look at the opposition and say that the opposition is in any way frustrating the work of the Senate is absolute nonsense, and the government well knows it.

What we are seeing here—and I will refer to a particular bill in a moment—is a complete hypocrisy on the government's part. That has been exposed very clearly in recent days. The thing that has really exposed it, to me, is the government's treatment of the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1995. The opposition has, with great difficulty in many respects, worked towards facilitating the government's request made as long ago as the end of last year that this bill be introduced and its passage expedited. This is the very contentious bill that deals with the government's approach to China's one-child policy so far as boat people from China are concerned.

The government has been pushing and pushing, so it says, the urgency of that bill. It has been in the Senate since the last session. It has not yet been debated. It has been pushed up the Notice Paper, down the Notice Paper and all around the Notice Paper. Never, though, has it come up for debate. I remind the Senate that what it is all about is an attempt to negate a decision by Mr Justice Sackville in the Federal Court last December, a decision which the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) has appealed against.

So long has the delay been in debating this bill that we now have the situation whereby the Federal Court has heard the minister's appeal, and is awaiting a decision which is expected in a short while—the next few weeks seems to be the expectation of the minister's department. As Senator Hill has said to the Senate, on 30 May I wrote to the minister to suggest that, in view of all the circumstances, the government consider deferring that bill until the court decision had been heard. I think the understanding on both sides was that that would be in the next few weeks; therefore, the bill could be debated in the light of the court's decision, if necessary, when we come back in August after the winter recess.
The following day, 31 May, the minister wrote to me strongly rejecting that suggestion on several grounds. In that letter, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Bill forms a key plank in the Government's actions to maintain the integrity of Australia's onshore refugee determination processes.
He went on to say:
The Parliament must show leadership on this issue. We cannot place ourselves on the timetable of the Courts.
He went on to say that the government would continue to seek urgent passage of the bill. He concluded:
For these reasons the Government remains committed to the early consideration of the Bill.
Minister, I have not cleared this letter with you, but I seek leave to have this letter by Senator Bolkus incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen it. I am not granting leave. We will have a look at it in a while.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept that. There is a copy for you to have a look at.
—Can we have your letter incorporated in the Hansard as well?

—Yes, although I do not think it adds much to the first paragraph of Senator Bolkus's response. Two sitting days after the minister told me that this is an urgent bill, that it has got to be passed, and that there is no possibility of having my sensible suggestion of deferral adopted, the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) announced here in the parliament that the government had decided not to proceed with consideration of Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) in this session. In justification of that, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We anticipate that by the time we return—
that is, in August—

the full bench of the Federal Court will have delivered its judgment on the appeal which is the subject of this legislation. That decision will either make the legislation unnecessary or put the parliament in a better position to debate its merits.

In other words, Senator Faulkner two days ago, in mounting his argument for two extra sitting days, said, `We have got rid of some of the legislation that is not really important.' The only bill he named was the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4)—the very bill that this government has been telling us for months is such an urgent bill to protect the integrity of Australia's onshore refugee determination processes.

PARA.TAB: Senator Faulkner's statement here is absolutely and totally inconsistent with Senate Bolkus's letter to me—both as to the need for the bill to be considered this session and as to the future of the bill in the light of whatever the Federal Court decision is. To add point to what I have said, it was approximately 10 days ago that the minister's office phoned my office to ask whether we would allow part of another migration legislation bill—Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5), which seeks to temporarily extend the duration of the migration agents registration scheme—to be added to Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4).

The reasoning was that as Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) was urgent and was going to be debated last week and then again this week, whereas Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5) was unlikely to be debated before the migration agent registration scheme expires in September—and that is a very dubious point anyway—the government wanted to tag on to Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) part of Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5). In other words, the government was using it not only as an important bill in its own right but also as a tag for other items.

The absolute hypocrisy of Senator Faulkner's statement in justification for the dropping or the deferral of Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) in his comments two days ago—comments which are absolutely and totally at odds with those of the responsible portfolio minister, Senator Bolkus—makes us extremely cynical of the government's motivation in all of the shenanigans that are going on now with the government's programming.

The simple fact is that you, Senator Faulkner, and you alone, have put the government's program in a total shambles. I do not know whether it is retrievable, even with the two extra sitting days. You are not going to get anywhere near what you said you wanted earlier on by way of the legislative program. As Senator Hill said, we offered you an extra week. You rejected that and now you come back with a half-hearted approach. You called it a minimalist approach in your comments the other day. You can hardly wonder why we are so concerned with your proposal and the cynicism and the hypocrisy behind it.

It is for all those reasons that we are not prepared to accede to your request. Unfortunately, it looks as though your proposal may go through, because you have probably made some sort of arrangement with the minor parties. But that does not in any way absolve you from the responsibility for the terrible situation that the Senate now finds itself in with this legislative shambles. Now that Senator Faulkner has had a look at the letter from the minister, I wonder whether he will agree to its incorporation. I seek leave to have the letter incorporated into Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: SENATOR NICK BOLKUS
Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Senator Jim Short
Senator for Victoria
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Short

I refer to your letter of 30 May 1995 concerning the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1995. You have suggested that the Senate's consideration of the Bill should be deferred until after the Full Federal Court decision is handed down.

I cannot agree with this suggestion. As you are aware, the Bill forms a key plank in the Government's actions to maintain the integrity of Australia's onshore refugee determination processes. The legislation remains as important now as when I originally foreshadowed the measures on 30 December last year.

The Parliament must show leadership on this issue. We cannot place ourselves on the timetable of the Courts. Only the Parliament can quickly, and clearly, return the law to the commonsense position that existed before Justice Sackville's judgement.

On the basis of our experience it would be highly unlikely to expect that the Full Court decision could be handed down within the next few weeks. The timing of the decision is a matter for the Court. It could be that the process goes well beyond the end of the Winter sittings of Parliament. Of course depending upon the decision of the Full Court there could well be an appeal to the High Court delaying significantly the ultimate resolution of the matter.

Another factor in the Government continuing to seek urgent passage of the Bill is that the decision of the Full Court may not assist in clarifying the law. The outcome could turn on particular facts, or be limited in some particular way. The result may be lack of clarity, with the result that the precedential nature of Justice Sackville's judgement remains in place. As I believe you are aware, a number of RRT cases have now been decided on the precedent that case provides—which in the view of the Government is bad law.
For these reasons the Government remains committed to the early consideration of the Bill.
Yours sincerely
NICK BOLKUS

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleagues in opposing the motion moved by Senator Faulkner. I have to say that I agree with Mr Beazley on one thing: he told the caucus that the Senate was in a complete, unutterable mess. I wonder whether Senator Faulkner's colleagues in the other place have woken up to what the real reason for this is. Senator Faulkner has presumably stood up in caucus and said, `Isn't it terrible the way I'm being treated over there by the Democrats, the Greens and the Liberals. It's all their fault.' I wonder how long that is going to wash with his colleagues over there, particularly with people such as Senator Robert Ray, who used to manage the program of the government.

PARA.TAB: What has precisely happened is this: Senator Faulkner and Senator Gareth Evans, unlike Senator Ray and former Senator Button, have no capacity to stand up to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). The Prime Minister tells Senator Faulkner, `Go over to the Senate and make sure we put these bills on and make sure we try to cause as much trouble in the Senate as possible.' Of course, in the old days Senator Ray and former Senator Button would say, `Look, Paul, that can be done, but just remember that the program of the Senate is not entirely controlled by the government. It has to be done in cooperation with the other senators. If you want to do this, mate, it is going to cause some problems.'

But, of course, Senator Faulkner does not have the guts to stand up to Keating. So he pitter-patters across here, wanting to show what a big, tough manager of government business he is. Yet when he comes into the Senate, we notice that he gives no priority to the government's real budget program.Senator Faulkner wants to indulge in some politics, but he gives no priority to his own program, such as the migration bill to which my colleague Senator Short referred. As a consequence, as Mr Beazley said, the Senate is in a complete and utter mess.

I do not have any great truck for former Senator Button, or particularly for Senator Robert Ray. But in the old days they would have been able to give the leadership in the other place the facts of life. They would have been able to say, `We can indulge ourselves the way we have and we can occasionally burst into the press and complain about all the other people in the Senate. But the fact of the matter is, if you want your government program, you have to sit down and discuss it and make sure that it can be achieved with the cooperation of the Senate'—and we are more than happy to do that. But you did not do that, Senator Faulkner—you did not show the guts, you did not give the right advice to your own party. As a consequence, you, Senator Faulkner, have got yourself in this appalling mess.

A classic example of this mess was raised by Senator Short. Paul Keating has this bugbear against Senator Michael Baume. I am not too sure why he does, but it has to be admitted that the Prime Minister does not like Senator Baume all that much. Senator Baume, as a man who is prepared to raise controversial issues, is not liked by the Prime Minister, who thought that this was a good chance to get back at Senator Baume. So Mr Keating dumped his program for the day and said, `Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Faulkner, you go back into that Senate and you make sure that Senator Baume is censured.'

Unfortunately, neither Senator Faulkner nor Senator Gareth Evans had the guts to actually tell Mr Keating that such a motion might not get through, would waste another enormous amount of time in the Senate and people would stand up and say, `If the government is not giving priority to its own program, why should other senators give a higher priority to the government's program?'

Of course, you did not give the right advice to the Prime Minister and you did not give the right advice to Mr Beazley and so you got yourself in a ridiculous mess. And that whole day was wasted—you did not get the motion you wanted through and, as a consequence, you have not learned the lesson.

I think the first thing you should do, Senator Faulkner, is stand up to Mr Keating, tell him the facts of life on how the Senate operates, tell him that the Senate is not like the other place and that he has to negotiate his program through the Senate. There is a fund of goodwill in this place to make sure that we achieve a reasonable program. But if the government does not give a priority to its own program, it cannot complain about other senators.

Let me bring to the attention of honourable senators the sort of program that the government initially thought it was going to bring in. The government listed some 27 packages of 39 urgent bills and 16 non-controversial bills, making 55 bills in all. Is that correct, Senator Faulkner? That is right.

The past statistics show that non-controversial bills take an average of about 30 minutes each. That leaves, making some adjustments for the time, only about 50 hours for the other bills. So, in order to pass all the other bills, the Senate would have an average of under one hour per bill. These are for all the other bills you have—these are the ones that are urgent and which cannot be considered non-controversial. It just simply cannot be achieved.

When these budget sittings started, you did not put down a sensible program, Senator Faulkner. You did not come around and discuss a sensible program with the Australian Democrats, the Greens (WA), me and others to make sure that it could be achieved. Instead, you tried to play politics with your program. You did not give a priority to the bills you thought were important and now you come in and you are starting to complain. So I put it to you that the mess the government's program is in can be entirely sheeted home to Senator Faulkner.

Senator Faulkner should have the guts to stand up in his own caucus and explain the real reason for the mess. I do not think he will because that requires him to take the responsibility on himself. I suspect we have spent two hours—or close to it—debating this motion. We would not have had to debate the motion if Senator Faulkner had been prepared to come to the table with a modicum of goodwill and negotiate a sensible program.

We have made what I think is an extraordinarily generous offer—given the commitments colleagues presumably have made. We have said we are prepared to come back a week early in August to assist the government with its program. But there has been no response from Senator Faulkner. We will not support this motion. I suggest Senator Faulkner goes away and thinks about how he can give priority to the bills that are important and must be dealt with. Then he can come back and negotiate with goodwill how this can be achieved. Senator Faulkner should stop trying to play politics with his own program and should make sure he gives priority to the important bills. I am sure the Senate will respond appropriately.

Until Senator Faulkner comes to the table and is prepared to negotiate on that basis, it is unlikely that he will achieve his program. It is an example of exceedingly poor management of the business of government. As I said, former leaders in the Senate would have been prepared to tell their colleagues in the other place—their leadership—the facts of life on this extremely important issue of the government's program. Maybe all this time in this debate could have been saved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few short comments on this motion to have two extra sitting days. I remind the Senate that at page 825 of the Hansard of the Senate's proceedings of 5 June, Senator Faulkner says:

PARA.TAB: One of the bills that has been on the government's forward legislative program for this session is the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4). The government has decided not to proceed with consideration of that bill during this sitting. We anticipate that by the time we return, the full bench of the Federal Court will have delivered its judgment on the appeal which is the subject of this legislation. That decision will either make the legislation unnecessary or put the parliament in a better position to debate its merits.

SPEECH.PARA: That appears to be an acknowledgment that the judicial processes must be exhausted on a vital issue such as this. I anticipate that the government acknowledges this ending up in the High Court.

PARA.TAB: The decision of the government has been welcomed. Senator Short indicated that he had written to the minister to seek to ensure that the judicial processes properly proceed before we take a step in this matter. This decision of the government has been welcomed, I know, by a number of government members who are concerned about this legislation and has been welcomed by quite a large number of opposition members.

The Greens and the Australian Democrats were opposed to the legislation because of its vile character. One Labor senator was reported by AAP on 6 June as welcoming the decision to delay the contentious refugee legislation. Senator Reynolds is quoted as saying that the bill would jeopardise Australia's reputation on human rights and women's issues. She indicated that it was wise for the government to wait until after an appeal court ruling and until after the United Nations women's conference to be held in Beijing in September. Those are very perceptive comments by Senator Reynolds, a senator who has been around this place for quite some time.

The bill is quite serious in its implications. It would not guarantee protection as refugees for people who have established a well-founded fear—and in the Chan case that means a `real chance' of coerced abortion, coerced sterilisation or other grave sanctions if they are returned to the People's Republic of China—and if that fear was established on the ground that the people involved were members of a particular social group, namely persons identified and targeted by the fertility control policies of the People's Republic of China.

I am very pleased to hear that the government has made a decision to delay that legislation. However, I note for the record that Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) is still on the Notice Paper as No. 27. Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4), in the words of the government, is substantially the same as Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). Why is that? Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) was introduced into this chamber by the government on 1 March—more than three months ago. It is so urgent that it has not been debated since then.

When it became clear that there would be substantial opposition to it—and it may even be defeated in this chamber—the government introduced Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) into the House of Representatives. The only reason that I can see why the government would have done that is to enable that bill to be a double dissolution bill. A bill that is introduced into this chamber cannot qualify as a double dissolution bill. In the government's own words, Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) is `substantially the same as Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3)'. I leave senators to make up their own minds about that. Having said that, I acknowledge the wisdom of the government in deciding to defer this legislation.

I, too, doubt whether we are going to be able to get through all the legislation even with Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) out of the road. The debate on the competition policy bill will be enormous. Admittedly, it is important legislation. The government has given it priority. I suppose other people have also given it priority. It will need to be examined very thoroughly, particularly from the point of view of its effect on regional Australia and the smaller states.

We have a whole raft of budget legislation to consider. We have the human rights bill, the bill to fix up the situation of `Brandy' and the racial hatred bill. You would have noticed the speakers list on the racial hatred bill and, by the looks of it, it will take at least a couple of days. I wonder whether it would not be better for the government, if it wants to keep it on the agenda, to at least put that bill back a little bit further so that we can get our teeth into some of these other substantial bills. I am supporting the government's motion for the additional two days of sitting.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to briefly put on the record where the Greens stand on this motion relating to the days and hours of meeting. The Greens have always wanted to assist the government in addressing its legislative program, and I am sure all of our colleagues in the chamber want to do that. We felt concerned that the bills that were listed required prioritisation, because there were so many that it was impossible to say that we would accomplish the whole of the government's legislative program.

PARA.TAB: It has already been pointed out that this is a very short session and that there is a long session scheduled for the end of the year. Maybe it is an error in judgment in planning for the year's program to have left a substantial proportion of time for the end of the year and only such a short time for the passage of budget bills and other urgent bills, and maybe we need to reflect upon that in the future.

The Greens were also concerned that we should not coerce the Senate to sit extra hours than those nominated in the advance program without reasonable consensus from our colleagues. The consensus of the Senate should be required to extend the hours. So, when there was a whips' meeting at which we were requested to have an extra week on the end of this session, that was not received with great acclaim or happiness by anybody in particular. It was actually Senator Panizza who suggested sitting on the Fridays, and that added an increased option. He actually tried, I believe, with his colleagues to have three extra Fridays for sittings, but eventually the opposition came up with the suggestion of these two extra Fridays. So it was, in our view, a consensus position that we offered to the government in order to assist the government to cover its program.

The opposition then, I believe, quite understandably, protested when it saw bills which it did not consider urgent listed ahead of budget bills and other bills. The opposition protested about sitting the extra days which it had suggested—and this presumably has led to its opposing this motion at this point in time. Because I have never made any secret of my concern about Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4), I felt happy at least to consider supporting its opposition to this motion.

I did not share—and I made this quite clear to the opposition—its concern that the racial hatred bill should not be debated this session. While I agree that it may not be very wise to have it so far up the program and that it would be better to put more urgent bills ahead of it—and I echo Senator Harradine's suggestion—I believe that we should be able to express our concerns about what the program is and whether it is urgent and warranted. I do not believe that it is sufficient to make me feel that the consensus that we want to assist the government's program has been lost.I think that is there.

I think the opposition has a right to say that it does not consider the arrangement of the program is to its satisfaction, and I believe that is what it is expressing in opposing this motion. The Greens do not share that view. We believe that, whether we particularly like the program or not, we should extend the two days to the government to do that legislation.

I just want to say in passing that the opposition parties and the Greens have been accused of delaying the Senate—and maybe I am even open to that accusation right now. Certainly, when we conducted what I believe was a very serious and legitimate censure motion, we were accused of wasting time. There has been a slight absence of civility and respect for the due processes of the Senate in some of the comments that the government has made, and I believe it has something to answer for when it lacks that civility and respect because that is what will delay the program from now on.

The Greens are supporting the motion to extend the sitting by two days, but we can only support the due parliamentary process and consideration of legislation. We will not be responsible for what happens if the government obstructs or is rude and pretends that any questioning that comes from this chamber is of an obstructive kind and does not necessarily have a principled argument behind it. That is all I wish to say. I believe this chamber should accede to the government's request for the two extra days, and that is what the Greens (WA) will be supporting.

TALK.START.PARA: —A minute ago Senator Chamarette mentioned the arrangement we may or may not have made. I certainly admit to trying to organise three extra Fridays or three extra days for consideration of government legislation. But, when I did that, I intended it to be for urgent government legislation—that is, for start-up bills from 1 July and, of course, for the bills that were necessary to put this government's budget into place. I also believed that, being urgent, the budget bills and the start up of 1 July needed a lot of time for discussion.

PARA.TAB: At no stage did I suggest to the government, or to any other party, that we should be debating the Racial Hatred Bill or migration bill No. 4. They have since been taken off the list. I believed that it was urgent that we sit, but that we sit to do urgent business so as to put the budget in place for Australia for the next 12 months.

I believe that the government is starting to come to its senses by attempting to run this Racial Hatred Bill as an urgent measure. I have always said to the government that we would be prepared to discuss that bill for a full week when we come back in August. One of the government advisers over there might think that is quite funny, but that is exactly what happened—that is the suggestion I made. I abhor this Racial Hatred Bill but, whether honourable senators support the bill or not, I agree that it is a bill that needs a thorough debate in this place. It is a bill that has a lot to do with personal freedom and freedom of expression in Australia.

I supported the extra three days in the belief that the government would use the extra three days. Of course, the third day was not available because that particular Friday was already set down for estimates; the estimates really could not be brought back into the week before we sat. That is the reason we came back to two days, and we were genuine about that. We were happy with the two days so long as we could get this urgent budget legislation up.

When looking at this program I might say that I will not speak one minute less than my allocated time when it comes to the Racial Hatred Bill. I will not advise any of my colleagues to talk for less than their allocated time. Senator O'Chee, like myself, is from an ethnic background, and I am sure he will speak to the bill. But whether we have an ethnic background or not, I believe it is a very important bill in so far as it could take away from Australians the freedom of expression. It needs to be well debated, so I will not be asking any of my colleagues to cut back on their 20 minutes if they wish to speak for that long. The bill could have been dealt with in August.

As I said, I agreed to the extra days on the basis that we would be doing urgent business with regard to the collection of levies and whatever else had to be put in place. Our offer is still very genuine: we will support it on that basis. If the government has any sense that is how it will start lining up the legislation.

I see that the Qantas and the human rights bills are still there. I do not know the importance of the human rights bill because I am not part of it, but I will be involved with the Qantas bill. If the government has any sense it will bring the other urgent bills straight up behind those.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take much of the Senate's time, except to say that we believe that there probably should have been more than five weeks in a budget session to start with. It is unfortunate. But this is the first time the government has tried this; obviously it was wrong. I would expect that next time the government will schedule more weeks for a budget session.

PARA.TAB: It is unfortunate that 23 bills considered to be urgent were left over from last session. We did not get through them, and we still have not got through them. It is also very unfortunate that we have had somewhere between three and four minutes of government legislation in the last week and a half.

It is also unfortunate that we have an awful lot more bills with 1 July start-up dates. The government, the opposition, the Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine have all considered these bills to be urgent but we have not got through them.

Senator Panizza made a very responsible and sensible suggestion that we should suspend on Thursday evenings and have the Fridays for business. I must say that, ever since he became Whip, Senator Panizza has behaved very responsibly and reasonably in that position. I am very pleased to see that.

The Democrats believe that we need these Fridays. We need this time just to get through the budget related bills. Even with these two Fridays, we will be pushing it to get through them. Obviously, the two Fridays are very necessary and the Democrats will be voting to sit on those days.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government sets the program for this chamber and it set aside five weeks for discussion of the budget. A proper discussion of any budget and associated bills needs more than a five-week sitting program. I am very concerned about the effect of this budget on families—a matter I will be taking up at a later date—and I would want a much longer period in which to discuss it. That we have been given such a short time in which to debate the budget is a total abrogation of the government's responsibility to provide for proper discussion. The government has been caught out on this, let's face it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—All the claptrap and codswallop we have heard from the opposition—from Senator Hill, Senator Kemp, Senator Short and others who have contributed to this debate—does not disguise the fact that in the last six days there have been only three minutes of discussion on legislation. You do not have to be a great mathematician to work out that that averages out at 30 seconds a day. That is the effort that has been put in by senators in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: Let the record be clear on this: this has been an absolutely deliberate tactic on the part of the opposition to ensure that there be no discussion of the government's legislative program. These bills have not been debated in this chamber because the opposition has filibustered, the opposition has delayed, the opposition has obstructed at every turn, and the opposition has indicated very clearly its intention to keep doing so. That is the opposition's record and, over the last six sitting days, it has achieved its end admirably.

The opposition will stand condemned in the wider community for what it has done. We have heard all this rubbish from opposition senators about the government not having bills on the program. Currently, there are 68 bills on the Senate Notice Paper ready to be debated today. By the end of the week there will be around 100 bills on the Notice Paper for debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well bring them on, John.

—Senator Kemp interjects, `Bring them on.' But he and the opposition will not debate these bills. The mentality of those opposite is not one at all of an alternative government. Any serious self-respecting alternative government would have the view that it is important for a government to see—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: we are all in the chamber, we are ready to debate the government's program. The minister should sit down so that we can get on with the government's program before the chamber and stop making utterly absurd comments unsubstantiated by any facts.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Watson)—Order! There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: I have been waiting since last Monday week to continue my remarks on the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill. I had only three minutes to debate the bill some 10 days ago. It has nothing do with my side of the chamber; it concerns that side not bringing it back on.
—Order! Will senators please state their points of order rather than make statements before the chair. There is no point of order.

—There has been one government speaker in this debate. I spoke for a comparatively short period of time. Opposition senator after opposition senator have contributed to this debate, as do so many others in the chamber, for no other purpose than to waste our time and to disrupt the proceedings of this parliament. I am going to take a few minutes to say so. I am going to take a few minutes to expose the bastardry of these people and of people like Senator Kemp.
—Mr Acting Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: I do not think `bastardry' is a very nice word to use in this chamber. I think that is unparliamentary.
—I accept your point. Minister, could you withdraw the word `bastardry'?

—If truth is no defence, I will withdraw it. The role of these people is exposed for all to see. Senator Hill in his opening contribution in this debate talked about the role of the government mishandling estimates committees. It is an absolute farce for a member of the opposition and the opposition leader to come in here and talk about the abuse of estimate committee processes. It is a bit rich when the government is now allocating an unprecedented amount of time for estimate committee processes.

PARA.TAB: We have a new system with the three parliamentary sessions where the estimates committees are in virtually continual session. My experience is that the difficulty we have in relation to the estimate committee process is because of the complete lack of discipline from the opposition, committee after committee, portfolio after portfolio, in its questioning. All we see time and again is opposition senators needlessly pursuing personal agendas before these committees and misusing and abusing the estimate committee processes. They know it is true.

In relation to this motion, the opposition gave commitments that we would not have to have the debate. It supported the government's proposal that the Senate sit on the number of Fridays. I asked for this motion to be formal so that we would obviate the need for this debate, but the opposition wanted to debate it knowing full well that a number of senators wanted to see this particular motion supported and carried so the Senate could get down and do some work.

I do not accept for one minute any accusation at all that has been levelled at the government that we have not acted during these sittings of parliament with an absolute commitment to cooperation in trying to achieve cooperation not only from the opposition but from the minor parties and independents in the Senate. I see Senator Bourne nodding her head in agreement. It is true that notice of what the government has intended has always consistently been provided to the opposition and the minor parties in the Senate well in advance. The government took seriously its obligations to prioritise its legislation and all those in the chamber have been made well aware of it for a long period.
Last night we saw Mr Howard come out with a load of old codswallop. Let me quote from page 23 of Mr Howard's speech last night on the section of the role of parliament. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, it would be the intention of the coalition that parliament sit for longer periods.
Today the opposition is proposing to vote against a motion to see this parliament sit for longer periods. It is selling Mr Howard out within about 15 hours.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. We have proposed an extra week, so get it right for a change.
—Order! There is no point of order. The minister is relevant.
—I ask members of the opposition: will you sell Mr Howard out or will you sit next week? The government will come back here next week and deal with our legislative program. Will you join us?
—It's about time?
—Will you join us? Will you come back next week, Senator Kemp?
—Bring on legislation.

—Will you come back? (Quorum formed) Let the record stand regarding Mr Howard's commitment to see the parliament sit longer. Here is an opportunity in this motion today. The opposition is opposing that. It will not agree to sit next week. It is nothing more than lies, lies, lies. It has had an opportunity within a short period—15 hours—to give some support to Mr Howard and it has sold its leader out.
—Senator Faulkner, could you withdraw `lies, lies, lies' please. It is disorderly.

—I will withdraw it. It is clearly a case of these people selling out their leader within 15 hours of his speech in which he gave a commitment that parliament would sit longer. Here again this afternoon, we have proof positive of the intention of those opposite to do nothing more than disrupt the processes of the parliament—another MPI; another waste of time; another attempt to derail the government's legislative program. They stand condemned for it.

PARA.TAB: The record is clear: the responsibility is yours and yours alone. The government will continue its commitment to work cooperatively with other parties and senators in this chamber. But everyone understands it is impossible to do that with the despicable and contemptible method of operation that the conservatives have. All should understand that any serious alternative government in this country would not up-end, derail and destroy a legislative program like this. The only people who would do that, the only opposition that would do that, is a perpetual opposition like yours. It is an opposition that does not approach any of its parliamentary responsibilities from the perspective of an alternative government; it approaches them from the negative, carping attempts to destroy, filibuster, disrupt and delay a government in its processes. This government and this manager will not be accepting it and I urge the Senate to reject—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to the provisions of standing order 196, which refers to tedious repetition and continued irrelevance. It would seem that, in a debate in which we are talking about not bringing on the government's bill, Senator Faulkner is just repeating himself over and over again. In the 15 minutes he has been speaking, he has put no new material in the last five minutes. It really is very irrelevant and tedious repetition. So I draw your attention to standing order 196 and ask that you bring the minister to order.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Watson)—There is no point of order. I can understand a degree of frustration entering into the minister's comments. I ask him to continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I appreciate the fact that you, like so many other reasonable people, are frustrated by the actions of those opposite. The government will not resile from its commitment to deal with urgent non-budget bills, budget bills, budget legislation and with those bills which are essential for the government to implement its policy and program. That is our commitment on this side of the chamber and we intend to see it honoured.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Faulkner's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 29 May, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is so long ago that the government wanted to debate the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill. I think this was last debated on 29 May. I had about three minutes to speak on this bill at that time. To recap where I was up to—if I can remember quite where I was up to, because it was so long ago and I obviously do not know why the government has taken so long to bring on this government legislation for discussion—I think I was telling two stories about two people who could have been enrolled on the electoral roll. There was a person called Nigel Langford Black, who was registered to vote. His occupation was given as a leading hand. His accurate address was given and so was his name.

PARA.TAB: For the same election I think I was talking about a Samuel Bach, who was registered to vote or could have been registered to vote. His name and address were accurate. The problem was that neither Nigel Black nor Samuel Bach voted at that particular election. There was a very good reason for that: Nigel Black happened to be a donkey and Sam Bach happened to be a dog. I think the point I was trying to make when I last spoke on this matter was that there is no difficulty in any person or persons putting names on the electoral roll.

It would have been very easy for those persons claiming to be who they were not to have turned up and voted at a polling place. Most probably they could have voted five or six times. There was little to stop someone claiming to be either of those two names and then turning up and voting. A letter in the Sunday Telegraph on 16 April 1995 prompted me to talk about this issue. The letter was headed `Voting fraud'. It said:
Former NSW Electoral Commissioner William Cundy is justified in worrying about electoral fraud

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Cundy talked about it in the Sunday Telegraph on 2 April—. . . particularly when you realise only 170 votes in three seats determined the State election outcome.
The letter is referring to the New South Wales election. It states:

PARA.TAB: That is the reality of elections today: a handful of people on key marginal seats determines who governs. Yet at the moment there is no onus on applicants for enrolment to prove their identity or place of residence. So an election could be "fixed" by a party by enrolling phoney names and addresses of their supporters in key marginal seats, then simply have those supporters vote on the fictitious names.

Until voters are made to prove their identity at the point of enrolment and then made to produce a registration card to vote, there will be no guarantee that any government in Australia is democratically elected.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that in all those close elections it always seems to be the Labor Party that wins them. I leave you with those thoughts, Madam Acting Deputy President, because basically that is the concern a lot of people have in the electorate.

PARA.TAB: For example, I well remember what happened in the seat of Page at the last federal election. The Labor Party won that seat by 170-180 votes, but it was quite interesting to see the number of sectional votes. Sectional votes occur where people who claim to be on the roll are not on the roll but get their name put on it. They vote but, subsequent to that, people might find that they did not even live in that particular electorate. So you could very easily have people moving from one electorate to another.

The letter I quoted, I think, supports my concerns about the Electoral Act as it is at the moment with people who most probably are not even there but have a chance to vote. In the past people have talked about people voting from the cemeteries—dead people voting. I am not talking about that, I am talking about how it could be easily done at this particular stage.

The Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill that we are debating, and on which I spoke for three minutes last Monday week, provides for the simplification of what the committee that reported on financial reporting by political parties saw as `unnecessarily onerous reporting requirements for registered parties'—parties that will now have to report particulars of their financial transactions in minute detail. The committee reported that `it was serving no useful purpose in achieving the policy objectives underpinning the original legislation'. In talking about disclosures and donations, in his second reading speech the minister said that the objectives were `to force disclosure of donations to candidates or their parties that might appear to influence a parliamentarian's or a political party's position in the parliament'.

The Parliamentary Research Service provided me with a document entitled Election funding disclosure and Australian politics: debunking some myths. Under the heading, Does disclosure inhibit donations?', this research service paper, written on 29 March this year by Dr Rolf Gerritsen, the consultant to the Law and Public Administration Group, says:

SPEECH.PARA: This data set does not allow a firm conclusion. Nevertheless, the decline, in real terms, of corporate support for the political parties referred to above does indicate some unwillingness to contribute to the political process.

Anecdotal evidence, plus the claims of all the major parties' officials is that disclosure does reduce the incentive to donate to their campaigns. There is near-unanimity that some potential donors are reluctant to contribute to their favoured party because of the disclosure of their names. This seems anomalous in the nation that initiated the secret ballot. There is inescapably some tension between the requirements of disclosure and the right to privacy. This affects private individuals more than corporations. There is a prima facie case for increasing the minimum donation required for disclosure. It is unlikely that any amount under $5,000 (in current dollar terms) could be construed as an attempt to influence the political process.

Similarly, the data analysed here, which gives us a unique view into the processes of Australian electoral politics, provide no grounds for alleging that improper pressure is being brought on Australia's political parties by their donors (which is not to say it could not happen).

How much pressure does the trade union movement put on the Labor Party for the donations they give? They seem to get appointed to every little board and they seem to have plenty to say on giving advice to the government. I would say that, in their donations, they get their real pound of flesh, or dollar of flesh, out of the Labor government.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating seems to call in the ACTU for first consultation on many items of business. It gets consulted before people in the wider community. I suggest that the ACTU puts a bit of pressure on the Labor Party. That should be noted in this debate. The article goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . because any donor cannot . . . give sufficient funds to create dependence upon their financial contributions in any of our major political parties.

I would say that would be the case as far as the conservative side of politics is concerned—the Liberal and National parties. No pressure is ever put on when a donation is given to help in the political process—in the giving of free speech and policy and positions to the people of Australia. But the trade union movement definitely gets plenty of say in the political process.

PARA.TAB: The minister, in his speech, talked about how the Liberal Party and the National Party do different things so far as donations are concerned. But he did not mention anything about the trade union movement and its manipulative powers on the Keating Labor government. That movement has run this country—run it into the ground in a lot of cases—by pulling the strings and fiddling on the side with this Labor government.

The other point in the bill is the recommendation for higher thresholds before individual donations have to be highlighted in returns. That is definitely a step in the right direction. The bill raises the threshold from $100 to $500 and for nominees to $1,500 as the sum which must be reported. The minister in his second reading speech was talking about the long gap between political parties and candidates running up campaign debts, and the receipt of funding. This has led to campaign directors having to get bank overdrafts to accommodate them until the future payment of their entitlement. This reform is a step in the right direction because that gap was cumbersome; and something needed to be done about it.

Service charges on overdrafts in those cases could be very heavy and could be a big cost to the political parties involved. The burden will now be lifted because 95 per cent of that entitlement will be paid by the third Friday after polling day. If some of the proposals for the computerised counting system for the Senate are implemented, hopefully that time will become a lot shorter.

We on this side of politics are not here to hold up this debate. I have waited for over a week to have a say: I had three-minutes say over a week ago on this bill. I support the fact that the Senate entitlement will now be the same as the House of Representatives entitlement. I entirely support the amendment moved by Senator Kemp which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule, page 9, proposed subsection 314AEA(3), omit "(either before or after the commencement of this section)", substitute "after the commencement of this section".

I hope the government will be supporting our amendment so this bill will go through with speedy passage and not be held up by the government, in the way it has held up legislation here in the last week.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been indicated, the coalition will be supporting the thrust of this bill but I want to make one important point to do with the philosophy of a participatory democracy. I think there is a danger in this bill in that it undermines popular participation in the democratic process and replaces popular participation with government subsidy. I think that is dangerous. I have discussed this bill with overseas friends in different countries and they all made the same point to me. They said, `Do not go down the Canadian way of subsidising lobby groups and political parties with the final consequence that ordinary people lose interest in the political process'.

PARA.TAB: What we should be encouraging in this country is an open participatory democracy. We should be encouraging a democracy in which people feel free to become involved in a political party and, more importantly, a democracy in which people feel a sense of responsibility to become involved in a political party. There was a time in this nation when membership of a political party of either persuasion—now we have multitudinous persuasions—was something that people prized. There was a time when people saw it as their moral obligation, their duty, to become involved in some way in the running of the country.

The point I make to the school students who are listening to this debate is this: the future of this country relies upon ordinary Australians becoming interested in the political process and becoming active participants in the political process. This bill substitutes a government subsidy for active political participation. What this bill says to the political parties is that there is no need to go out into the community to recruit, to win people's support, to win their membership and their backing because the taxpayers' dollar will replace that.

In a democracy in which governments do not subsidise political parties, political parties are forced to win the hearts and minds of the populace in order to continue to function. The danger is that as we increase the level of subsidy we decrease the level of popular participation. We decrease the interest that ordinary people will have in politics because ordinary people will say, `Why should I bother getting involved in a political party? It is simply a small group of people—a little plutocracy—who live off the public purse'.

That is the danger that this bill has for parliamentary democracy in this country. It is an inevitable consequence of this bill that political parties will become fatter and lazier and less responsive to voters and members because there is not the urgent need to continually recruit and to continually touch base. That is the danger.

It happens for the simple reason that the government, in earlier legislation, discouraged people from becoming active participants and donors to political causes in which they believed because the government had this perverted, twisted sense that that was somehow wrong. It is a sign of a healthy democracy that people are free to donate to the causes in which they believe and are free from the threat of political victimisation which we have seen in my home state of Queensland.

I disagree with the fundamental thrust that the government introduced some time ago. I believe that this bill does pose dangers to parliamentary democracy. I believe that it poses dangers to the stake that ordinary Australians feel that they have in political parties and in this parliament. If that is the case, then this parliament, this institution, will be the weaker by the passage of this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I stood up determined to be very brief in response to this debate, but I have to say that I have never heard such rubbish argued in a good cause in my life. The point of Senator O'Chee's advocacy that it is a very good thing that more people are involved in the political process is absolutely correct. I share that view. But to then seek to attach that to the comfortable argument of the privileged that those who have money should be free to maximise the political advantage that can be gained from it under the cloak of secrecy is a travesty, distorting—
—Like Laurie Connell's donations to the Labor Party.

—Whoever makes secret donations seeking to buy influence is wrong, whether they seek to make it to my party or to your party or to anybody else's party. I unequivocally state that. It is wrong, and the public is entitled to know the source of the money and to make a judgment about whether there are links between the donation and the political consequence. That is a fundamental tenet of proper, open democracy.

PARA.TAB: Anybody who understands how most political parties—I have to say that I do not understand how the Queensland National Party works—operate knows that even the funding formula in this bill will not in any way remove the need for active local fundraising. Everybody else, Senator O'Chee, that I know around this chamber is very actively involved in that process. Most of us wish we were not, but we are. It is a very important part of our continuing activity in support of our political campaigns and those of our colleagues.

I think the right to donate secretly is not one of the great political rights of our time. The right to donate, of course, is; the right to participate is. Anything that can be done to encourage people to participate is important, but let me now come back—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is so you can intimidate people, is it?
—Those of you who come from Queensland would understand about intimidation but, fortunately, that government has been defeated.
—That is why we have been on the receiving end of it from the Labor government.

—That is right. I can remember the crocodile tears from those who benefited from that for so long. Let me just say this. This is actually a bill that is about the funding and disclosure provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. We have, over the years, properly made changes to continually tighten the disclosure requirements and to enhance the integrity of the process, but it has become incredibly complex. The bill is designed to reduce the complexity of the act, while retaining the integrity and the disciplines of the system. So I welcome the fact that the core of it, therefore, has the support of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: We will deal with the amendments in the committee stage but, just for the record, there is an assurance I undertook to give, which I will do now. Section 13 recognises that some political parties are organised on a national basis and others on a federal basis, and it seeks to accommodate both models in matters of funding and disclosure.

It has been drawn to my attention that the Democrats are concerned that, by dint of being registered as a single party, they will not be covered by this section. On behalf of the government, I can give an assurance that, if this is the case, in subsequent amendments to the act this situation will be rectified. My understanding is that the Liberal Party has given a similar assurance. The Australian Democrats have agreed that, as they are not adversely affected by this section and in consideration of the backlog of bills before us today, they are happy for this matter to be dealt with at a later date. I commend the bill to the house.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule, page 9, item 34, proposed subsection 314AEA(3), omit "(either before or after the commencement of this section)", substitute "after the commencement of this section".

This amendment tackles what we believe to be a serious retrospective element in the bill relating to annual returns of associated entities, which will require details of the source of the capital even though that capital was contributed when there was no question of disclosure. As I pointed out in the second reading debate, contributions of capital made years ago when disclosure was not an issue were made under completely different rules. It is grossly unfair to require details of these donors, some of whom may well be deceased, to be made public under a new and necessary law. The amendment we propose will address this issue. It removes the need for disclosure of capital contributed prior to the date of effect of this bill.
