The Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill is, as has been announced, a bill that concerns disclosure provisions as well as funding provisions. While the Greens do not object to the disclosure provisions that are being changed to increase accountability, we do feel that the matter of public funding of political parties is a matter that deserves the attention of both the chamber on the public record and the community.

PARA.TAB: In the dying moments of the autumn sitting of the Senate, the government, with the support of the opposition and the Australian Democrats, sought to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act to double the amount paid to political parties for the votes they receive at federal elections. Those amendments were all recommended by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, and the bill containing them was first introduced into the House of Representatives in November 1994. On the morning of 9 March 1995 the Minister for Administrative Services introduced changes to the bill which altered the payment of electoral funding. The bill was passed by the House of Representatives with this change later that day.

Behind this alteration lies a sorry tale of secret deals by the ALP, coalition and Australian Democrats to bypass the normal method of seeking change to the Commonwealth Electoral Act in order to avoid public debate on the funding of political parties. This is contrary to the principle that the mechanism which elects the people that make the laws should only be changed after significant public inquiry and debate, and only on the recommendation of the committee set up to evoke and foster the public consultation—the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. That principle has operated since at least the 1950s, and the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters was created in 1987 to provide an ongoing process of scrutiny and improvements to the act.

The proposed change that the Greens (WA) senators object to was not recommended by that committee and has received very little public airing. Because of the delay in the legislative timetable, the Greens have made their concerns public. We have also discussed it within our own party, and it has received a very small amount of media attention. We believe that because this bill gives political parties $1.50 for every vote they receive at an election irrespective of how much money they spend on their campaign, it is a significant shift in policy which has deserved more scrutiny than it has received.

SPEECH.PARA: Public funding was, prior to this bill, then given on the basis of the costs of a political party's election campaign or an amount of money for the vote received, whichever was the smaller. There is a considerable cost to this change. The cost to the taxpayer will be over $15 million per election, based on the last election figures. The ALP and coalition will receive nearly an extra $7 million each. Under the change, the Australian Democrats will receive an additional $1 million and the Greens (WA) a further $100,000.

PARA.TAB: We are, therefore, registering our objection to this proposed change and seeking to amend the bill to bring it into line with last year's recommendation of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. We want public funding of the election campaigns of political parties to be just that—funding of election campaigns. The funding process should not become a mechanism by which to publicly fund parties based on their electoral support.

This is one of the rare occasions on which I am actually in agreement with Senator O'Chee. He expressed some concern about replacing popular support with public subsidy, noting that the capacity of a party to operate on its popularity and level of participation could be reduced through reliance on public funding.

I do not agree totally with everything Senator O'Chee said. While I support this issue being raised for discussion, the principle of public funding or public subsidy is not the problem here; it is the way in which that public funding is being provided. Anybody who gains more than four per cent of a vote becomes an involuntary beneficiary—and there is no ceiling on this public funding. Clearly, the change will not necessarily benefit the democratic process.

The Greens are concerned that the threshold of four per cent is too high. If we wanted to enhance participation in the electoral process through public funding, it should be dropped to two per cent. In Mexico the subsidy threshold is only 1.5 per cent.

The likely use of this funding is also of relevance. I believe that the major parties have pressured this change because, with the disclosure provisions possibly discouraging private donations, they face considerable electoral debt. This measure is the sweetener in a bill that is intending to make political parties far more accountable.

Greens from all around Australia—not just the WA Greens—believe that, since the general population has been asked to tighten its belt throughout this recession we had to have and to suffer the effects of downsizing and smaller budgets, there is no valid reason the major political parties should be exempt. If the funds are not immediately available perhaps that is a sign that we need to become trimmer and to look at the $15 million which is being made available through this legislation. It might be regarded as a drop in the bucket of public funding but funds are a scarce resource and there are many groups in the community which are desperately in need of assistance. While they have been asked to tighten their belts, we are on the verge of voting ourselves a funding windfall.

There are two points to be made in presenting these amendments. One is that there has not been sufficient attention given to the process of making such a significant change to the Electoral Act provisions. The second is that this is a way of voting ourselves an immense windfall—of which, of course, the Greens would be happy recipients. While we do not receive anywhere near the amount of money that the major parties receive, we recognise that this public funding represents a greater proportion of our total funding. This mechanism doubles funding to the major parties but it quadruples the amount of money available for our electoral campaigns.

I am not saying that we are not aware that we are beneficiaries; we are. We just believe that the change should have been acknowledged and that it should have had far more public discussion, because there are different viewpoints on it. There is no consensus in the community regarding this matter. It could have merited far better debate. I commend these amendments to the Senate as a way of saying that we have not given sufficient attention here. We should give it the rightful discussion across the committee process and across the community that it deserves. I was asked to sign a letter saying that we agreed with it. That was the first I had ever heard of this mechanism. I refused to sign it because I had not consulted my party. I was told at that time that all the other parties had signed the letter. That is the basis on which I make the accusation. Rather than a due process, there was a behind the scenes arrangement between the major parties because we would all be the recipients of this windfall.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak very briefly to three issues that need to be responded to. I agree with Senator Chamarette when she said that the whole process of disclosure has been part of the process of making political parties more accountable. That is absolutely correct and important. I am pleased she reiterated that and supports it, as I think almost everyone in this chamber does, some more reluctantly than others.

PARA.TAB: There are two points on which I disagree with Senator Chamarette. First, she has a concern that moving from a claim based system to an entitlement based system will somehow deny the public access to knowledge about any activities concerning electoral expenditure. The law will still continue to require political parties to disclose details of their expenditure; it just means that it does not all have to be done within a few days of the election consistent with the claim. If, by some bizarre process, a political party sought to spend less than its entitlement, it would be very strange. The party certainly would not be maximising its support. I cannot imagine why anyone would want to do that, but if anybody did it would be publicly disclosed, observable and commented upon in part of the democratic process of open accountability.

There is no way that people can make an underhand, undisclosed windfall out of this. It is simply getting some of the duplication of the bureaucratic process out of the system. It is a while since I have had to do any of this in a capacity as a party official. I have had to do it as a candidate in the election, but that is less onerous. Even in those days, there was a lot of unnecessary bureaucracy both for the political parties and for the government, which has to receive and process the documents. So it is wasting the resources of both the political parties and the taxpayers.

The second issue on which I disagree with Senator Chamarette is her concern about the process. I do not share her fascination for the Senate committee process or the parliamentary committee process overall, although I do accept that the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Reform has done a very good job over the last decade. It is a process that has enhanced our electoral process and smoothed a lot of minor amendments that do not go to major issues of partisan significance but improve the electoral process.

The parliamentary process is the ultimate sanction and the ultimate public accountability of changes to our laws. This bill is not being rushed through in the dead of the night. It was first introduced at least six months ago. First exposure drafts were circulated, as I understand it, in November and the bill was introduced in December. It is not one of those introduced one day, passed the next specials that sometimes cause concern to people. In terms of proper process, there is nothing to apologise for. It is a question of the public's assessment of whether it is an appropriate change, but it has majority support in the parliament. Overall, the bill will approve the accountability and operation of the electoral system, and I support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a few brief comments in relation to the remarks made by Senator Chamarette. I endorse what Senator McMullan said: this bill has been in the public arena for a very long period. I say to Senator Chamarette that there has been quite a bit of public debate of which she has been behind. Her implication that this has been rushed through is not correct. In fact, it has been an amazingly slow process and there has been some press discussion on it. I do not accept that point of her argument.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette commented on the remarks of my colleague Senator O'Chee. We are faced with a real dilemma here. The dilemma is how much disclosure is required and public funding. The reality is that the disclosure provisions which existed before this bill came about and which exist now are very onerous. A lot of people simply do not like to disclose to whom they give money; it just does not have to be a political party. Typically—I do not know whether I have done it in every case—when I am asked to give money to a charity and asked whether I wish to have my name disclosed, I generally say no.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are hiding your light under a bushel.
—I do too, and I accept that.
—Sometimes it only takes a very small bushel.

—It is a big bushel occasionally. I think there is a dilemma. We do not have to think this for sleazy reasons. A lot of people who would contribute to political parties simply are not prepared to have their names bandied around. It is not because they are trying to reach a special deal with a political party, but they do not want to become the subject of public debate and possibly follow-ups from political opponents. That process is not unknown. There is a real dilemma. Senator O'Chee raised it. I have some sympathy with what Senator O'Chee said. The disclosure provisions are enormously heavy and onerous and it has led to defunding of political parties. This was predicted at the time. I think those predictions have been fulfilled. On the other hand, we want to have a vibrant electoral system where parties can compete. It is always a problem to strike the right balance in that area.

PARA.TAB: With commendable frankness, having moved the amendment, Senator Chamarette noted that she was going to benefit by the passing of this bill. I did not note whether she said she would not be prepared to accept the funds which were available. I do note the commendable frankness with which she mentioned that her own circumstances will be substantially improved. In fact, she wanted to loosen the bill even further. She wanted to reduce the cut-off point from four per cent to two per cent, which would lead to a rash of smaller parties coming in, which may be a good thing or a bad thing. We have to strike a balance between making sure that people have a genuine claim to be part of the political process and take part in that process in an active manner, as distinct from trying to encourage people to come in so they can get hold of public funding. I suspect the four per cent cut-off point is appropriate.

I will not touch on a particular issue that Senator Chamarette raised because we want to speed the journey; we do not want to have Senator Faulkner in here speaking to us again. My colleague Senator Abetz will deal with the issue Senator Chamarette raised in relation to whether this bill should have gone through the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. I am sure she is wrong in that respect. I look forward to hearing the remarks of my colleague.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak very briefly, as we do not want to come back and consider this bill again. I do not know how many times we have adjourned it. While I understand the concerns that have been raised, I believe that what is not understood is the onerous requirements that are now imposed, particularly on treasurers at branch level but also on candidates. I believe we are running the risk, as Senator Minchin said, of destabilising political parties by imposing some of the requirements that we are now putting upon them.

PARA.TAB: I do not know about the Greens but certainly at branch level and at state executive level all of our officers are volunteers. To put these requirements on them is to put enormous stress on the actual machinery within parties. I know that in the Liberal Party it is all volunteers as well, certainly at branch level. To have the requirements that we now have in place means that there is a doubling up—you keep one lot of books for elections and a separate lot as you put in your annual return. The annual returns stay. Indeed, the annual returns, thanks to amendments we are now moving, are even more onerous in terms of trust accounts and the further tightening that we are doing.

We are limiting participation in political parties by continually imposing more and more requirements. It has gone beyond what I would consider to be a reasonable level of accountability. It has reached the point where I know there are many people who are even questioning becoming candidates because of the amount of paperwork they have to keep, the amount of records and the very, very fine detail. So the Democrats will not be supporting these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I fully support the comments by Senator Lees. In general terms, if there is going to be corruption in political donations one would anticipate that it would be of the brown paper bag variety which does not find its way to the party concerned—rather, it would go to particular ministers who are able to influence decisions or they would get funding in kind by the provision of certain services at no cost; it would not go through the political party.

PARA.TAB: I know that within the state Liberal Party in Tasmania, even before disclosure was required, people would make donations to the Liberal Party through a solicitor's trust account because they did not want the political party to know that they were funding it. They were not expecting any favours in return; they wanted it to be deliberately at arm's length. But now, with disclosure, those people who were absolutely clean and pure in their motives in donating to the party are no longer able to donate without the party actually knowing who the donor was. We would now find out through the public disclosure provisions. As a result, those people, unfortunately, feel somewhat exposed; they do not want any favours, nor do they want any publicity. They donate for the genuine reasons of contributing to the body politic of our society and to a particular cause—in my case, the cause is liberalism within the state of Tasmania. I think that is something that ought to be taken into account.

Whilst there clearly have been funny money deals and sleazy deals in relation to political parties, the people who have also been caught are those who have donated on a genuine basis, who have never wanted a reward; in fact, they never wanted their name made known to the party or anybody else. They are now exposed by the legislation that we have.

I noted the comment of Senator Chamarette that the Greens would be substantial beneficiaries under this legislation. I was not quite sure whether she was undertaking on behalf of the Greens to repay that into consolidated revenue. I am sure they will willingly accept the moneys and I do not necessarily blame them for doing so.

I turn to matter that Senator Chamarette raised relating to the question of whether or not certain proposals ought to go through the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. As a member of that committee—might I add only a very recent member—

TALK.START.PARA: —But an expert nonetheless.
—Senator Kemp says `an expert nonetheless'. Even my own modesty would not allow me to say that, Senator Kemp, but thank you for that assistance.
—It didn't stop you repeating it!
—That's right; making sure it was in Hansard.

—I recognised the interjection so that it at least gets into Hansard and I might be able to pass it on to some of my preselectors, and change the Hansard somewhat to allow them to recognise the expertise with which Senator Kemp credits me.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette raised the question of whether or not amendments to the Electoral Act relating to an increase in election funding ought be brought before the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. As I understand the situation, there is no obligation on the government through the Electoral Act or other sources, such as the committee's resolution of appointment, to refer amendments to the act to the committee for consideration. Nevertheless, it would be appropriate that most major changes to the electoral legislation go through the committee. As a matter of principle and as a matter of course, I do not think there is any argument with that.
In its June 1994 report, Financial reporting by political parties, the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, on the question of election funding at page 9, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: At present, a Senate vote attracts half the amount of public funding of a House of Representatives vote, where elections for the two Houses are held together. The rates payable at the 1993 election were 100.787 cents for a formal House of Representatives first preference vote, and 50.393 cents for a formal Senate first preference vote.

There was then discussion by the committee as to whether or not a Senate vote ought to attract the same consideration as a House of Representatives vote. The committee agreed that that ought be the case and recommended accordingly. So this change in funding, equating the Senate vote with a House of Representatives vote, came out of the report of June 1994—now some 12 months old.

PARA.TAB: The committee—before I was a member of it, I hasten to add for Senator Kemp's benefit—did not nominate a figure at which the election funding level should be set. Given that the committee did not deal with that matter, as I understand it the government took it upon itself to consider what an appropriate level of funding would be. Whilst I accept and understand Senator Chamarette's concerns that amendments to the legislation relating to this aspect ought be considered by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, the actual principle was touched upon in June 1994—some 12 months ago. The committee, for reasons undoubtedly best known to itself, did not make any suggestion as to the actual level of funding. As a result, the government took it upon itself to make this proposal—which, might I add, has been in the public arena now for some considerable time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendments that have been moved by Senator Chamarette. I would like to mention that I do know a little bit about elections, political and industrial and various other ones, and when I resigned as a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters—or electoral reform, as I think it was called then—I was the longest serving member on that committee.

PARA.TAB: I am aware of the development of the arguments for the public funding of political parties. There was considerable discussion, both philosophical and practical, about that question. It was felt, though I had grave reservations, that the public funding of political parties may be accompanied by a level of electoral expenditure by political parties coming to some sort of plateau.

Very serious consideration was given to the issue of whether we should tie public funding for political parties to a cap on expenditure by those political parties for the purpose of elections and for the general running of the political parties between elections. That is really the issue. If political funding is to be used only as a top-up for the private donations that political parties accrue, the result will be that more and more money will be expended by political parties in election campaigning. This will be done in a manner, as has been seen, that does not really help in informing the public during election times.

Nobody around this chamber would surely suggest that all political advertising is simply to inform the potential voter about the programs. We all know that PR firms are hired by the political parties to get across a message. That message is really comprised of images. It is like selling a new motor car or something of that sort.

Once this amendment is put to the chamber and decided upon, I will be asking the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator McMullan, to inform the Senate, from the date when the public funding first became law, of the rate of increase of expenditure for political campaigns in each year in which returns have been made. It is important that we know that and compare it with, for example, the increase in inflation in those periods.

I know that the rates demanded by television stations and the media have risen rather considerably. But those sorts of figures ought to be available and presented by the minister to this chamber to see whether we have been led along a path which I thought at the time none of us wanted to be led along.

Senator Abetz mentioned the 1994 report. As he indicated, that 1994 report related to the question of whether a vote for a Senate candidate is worth as much as a vote for a member of the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Worth a lot more.

—Senator Abetz says that it is worth a lot more. In all seriousness, I think it was generally acknowledged, as indicated by that report to which he referred—and I do not think I was a member at that time; I had already resigned—that it was agreed all round in any event that there should be equality there. I believe that is the view also of Senator Chamarette, the proposer of this motion.

PARA.TAB: I support this motion. There has been no valid argument put forward by the government to support the increase in the amount of public funding. That increase, as Senator Chamarette said, is going to cost $15 million! That is something we should be very disturbed about. If we ask people in the electorate, `Do you think $15 million of taxpayers' money ought to go to political parties?' we will find that nine times out of 10 the answer will be no, particularly if it is just going to mean that there will be extra money for political advertising of the slick variety to bombard the voter.

So I am supporting the proposition put forward by Senator Chamarette. I am disappointed that the proposal by the government was not formally put before the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters so that the sorts of questions I referred to could have been asked of the government, of the Australian Electoral Office and of the political parties which are the beneficiaries of this piece of legislation as it relates to this particular clause.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have worked through in my office the 17 points of the amendments as circulated by the Greens. I thought I had worked through them painstakingly. I want to know whether I have missed something. Senator Chamarette may be able to assist in her response as to whether any of these proposed amendments would actually deal with decreasing the funding that would be received for a Senate vote or for a House of Representatives vote.

—I thank Senator Abetz for raising that issue because I do not think I made clear enough my stance on what the amendments actually do. The reason why they do not address the question of funding is that this did not go through the process of discussion at the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. Senator Abetz quite rightly pointed out that the amount per vote was an issue discussed in that committee. He also quite rightly pointed out that we agreed there should be an equivalence of amount for the Senate vote and for the House Representatives vote.

PARA.TAB: I was at that discussion. I joined in and agreed with the recommendation. We specifically did not set an amount. We did not put any constraints on the government as to whether it should reduce the House of Representatives vote to 50c per vote or increase the Senate vote to a dollar. I do not recall any of us anticipating a mutually beneficial increase to $1.50. So I have some concerns about the amount that has been nominated, but I did not feel as free to stand on my principles in relation to the process because we had actually made a recommendation to the government from the committee that there should be an equivalence of vote. So it was not an issue that had not received discussion.

The point I was making was that the subtle change, that the refund should be available to political parties on the basis of their primary vote rather than on their campaign expenditure, was slipped in in March to an amended version of the bill that was passed in the House of Representatives. That had the double benefit that, firstly, unless we were vigilant we would not have seen it and, secondly, that particular matter had not come through the committee.

While I am concerned that the amount of increase may not be warranted in relation to the constraints that other people in the community are suffering, the change that I am asking to be reinstated is the one that has not received that kind of scrutiny. While it seems a subtle shift, it is a very major one in the amount of money that would be available to political parties. So it is on that basis that these amendments simply reinstate the previous existing situation of the bill without addressing the issue of the amount of funding.

I again flag my concern that we are doing this without necessarily demonstrating that that $15 million is a very significant change to public funding and we have not given it the discussion it warrants. And I thank contributors to this discussion because I believe that it has received better discussion—and that was partly my reason for moving the amendment. I am quite able to see that I do not have the numbers to reinstate the former position, but I will be calling a division on this simply because I am forced by the nature of the bill to support the bill at the final vote and I will not be causing any division on that. So I am registering my concern about the financial implications of this change at this point by giving the committee an opportunity to not go forward.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Chamarette's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

That so much of the sessional order be suspended as would prevent proceedings on the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill 1995 being completed prior to discussion of matters of public interest being called on.

—As I indicated to Senator Harradine earlier, I would be pleased to provide any information he is seeking in regard to that matter. I will seek to provide it expeditiously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Abetz for standing aside to allow me to make this contribution which I believe is of some importance. In the small hours of the morning on 25 May, after 14 hours of emotionally charged debate and 50 or so amendments, 15 people made it legal for doctors to administer death; to expunge life at the request of a terminally ill patient. These 15 ordinary, fallible politicians, members of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, were the first legislators in the world to take this step.

PARA.TAB: The federal Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) has called for a national response to euthanasia laws. What is important, she says, is uniformity—as though death requires standardising like rail gauges or share transaction charges. Other states are feeling the pressure to legislate accordingly.

From the outset, it is important to accept that neither the advocates nor the opposers of euthanasia have a monopoly on compassion or understanding suffering. All protagonists love their parents, children and spouses and wish to reduce their pain.

The Northern Territory, like other decentralised parts of Australia, perhaps sees less of the ways suffering can be relieved and managed. According to a palliative care specialist, the Top End has, `no medical oncologist, very little radiotherapy services, not a single palliative care program and no hospice'.

The debate on euthanasia is itself a harrowing one, contemplating and confronting life and death. It divides families, communities, political parties and parliaments. To enjoin Australians in this divisive process, the euthanasia bill's proponents must have felt that there was great injustice being done and great injury to human rights and dignity. They thought euthanasia so necessary as to justify the inevitable division and the outcry from Australia's churches and medical communities.

From a national perspective, it is difficult to argue that legislative change is warranted by widespread community dissatisfaction with the status quo. In 12 years as a senator, I have received tens of thousands of letters from constituents on all sorts of issues, but never one on euthanasia.

The Senate Table Office checked its records back to 1973 and found no petitions on euthanasia. The word `euthanasia' appears, for whatever reason, only 16 times in the House of Representatives Hansard since 1983. Euthanasia, by its very scope and nature, cannot confine itself within state borders, nor escape attention in the federal parliament. Internationally, there is no push to introduce euthanasia. But, as a result of the decision of 15 people with the authority of a legislative assembly, Australians everywhere are being asked to consider euthanasia.

In view of the concern I see in the electorate, I am compelled to raise the issue of euthanasia in the Senate. I do not see that it should be ignored or can be ignored. I do not see that it should be left to others. I do not see that the fact that some doctors admit to practising euthanasia is an argument for its legalisation. The fundamental objective of governments is to protect the life, law and liberty of its citizens. The protection of life underwrites our judicial and social systems. If the duty of government is subrogated, it becomes a wedge, opening the door to further erosion of the protection of life.
The 1994 House of Lords report of the Select Committee on Medical Ethics found that it would be impossible to set secure limits on voluntary euthanasia. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Issues of life and death do not lend themselves to clear definition, and without that it would not be possible to frame adequate safeguards against non-voluntary euthanasia if voluntary euthanasia were to be legalised. It would be next to impossible to ensure that all acts of euthanasia were truly voluntary, and that any liberalisation of the law was not abused. Moreover to create an exception to the general prohibition of intentional killing would inevitably open the way to its further erosion whether by design, by inadvertence, or by the human tendency to test the limits of any regulation.

For the first time, intent to kill no longer constitutes the mens rea of murder. Now we must add motive, or the reason why the intent was formed. Euthanasia is intent to kill but will not be murder. The onus to prove the motive for murder will be on the law enforcement authorities. The 1994 House of Lords report canvassed the issue of euthanasia thoroughly. It found:

Ultimately, however, we do not believe that these arguments are sufficient to weaken society's prohibition of intentional killing. That prohibition is the cornerstone of law and of social relationships. It protects each one of us impartially, embodying the belief that all are equal. We do not wish that protection to be diminished and we therefore recommend that there should be no change in the law to permit euthanasia.

We acknowledge that there are individual cases in which euthanasia may be seen by some to be appropriate. But individual cases cannot reasonably establish the foundation of a policy which would have such serious and widespread repercussions. Moreover dying is not only a personal affair. The death of a person affects the lives of others, often in ways and to an extent which cannot be foreseen. We believe that the issue of euthanasia is one in which the interest of the individual cannot be separated from the interest of society as a whole.

PARA.TAB: The Netherlands has been frequently cited as a reference point for any discussion on euthanasia, although, even there, they do not have legislation explicitly permitting it. However, the results of euthanasia in the Netherlands provide an example of what could happen here. It should be noted that Australia's population of 18 million is greater than the Netherlands's population of 15.24 million.

Evidence presented to the House of Lords committee showed that there are 2,300 cases annually of euthanasia in the Netherlands and another 400 of assisted suicide. There are 1,000 cases annually where a patient's life is terminated without the explicit request of the patient. In 41 per cent of those cases, the patient was not competent to discuss the proposed course of action. The justice minister for the Netherlands commented recently that she saw no reason why involuntary euthanasia should not be legalised and that euthanasia should be permitted even for persons not in the terminal phase of an illness.

Members of an Australian parliament will listen in silence while an attorney-general reports the number of euthanasia deaths, `as soon as practicable after the end of each financial year' as mandated by the legislation. Would people be able to blank from their minds that some of those deaths would not have been voluntary: names and faces and lives they never knew but had sentenced to death through an act of parliament; human beings whose passage to death was subsidised by Commonwealth taxes via Medicare funding agreements, rebates and pharmaceutical benefits, as confirmed by Senator Crowley last week?

As a society, we must take responsibility for our sick and our dying. Through this debate on euthanasia, I have learnt that we do not do that nearly well enough. The House of Lords committee strongly recommended the development and growth of palliative care services, research into pain relief and symptom control and the importance of individual dignity in the long-term care of dependent people. That is our compelling responsibility. That is where a national debate on the rights of the elderly, dying and disabled should truly start.

There is no doubt that euthanasia is the easiest solution. Its very existence devalues the work and perhaps the funding of palliative carers and researchers. As Professor Lickiss, Director of Palliative Care at Sydney's Royal Prince Albert Hospital, commented:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is a country of creativity as well as compassion and we can surely improve the care of our people without resort to euthanasia, a violent solution, which impoverishes the human—and medical—community. We have not, as a nation, become so impoverished, nor as a profession have we gone so far astray.
Contrast this approach with the callousness of the prominent advocate of pro-euthanasia, Dr Helga Kuhse. At a conference on the right to die, she said:
If we can get people to accept the removal of all treatment and care—especially the removal of food and fluids—they will see what a painful way this is to die, and then,
in the patient's best interest, they will accept the lethal injection.

Mr Acting Deputy President, Australia owes much to its multicultural heritage, but it seems to me that euthanasia is a particularly white man's way of dealing with a problem. In our parliaments, some would argue that we go to extraordinary lengths to protect Aboriginal secrets. Our legislators are, by world comparison, sensitive to the views of different cultures. Ethnic communities are powerful lobbyists.

PARA.TAB: Yet, in the Northern Territory, home to the greatest number of traditional Aboriginals, this perspective has been lost when it comes to white man's euthanasia. In a submission to the Northern Territory select committee on the euthanasia bill, the Aboriginal community of Milingimbi wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: We are nomads, hunters, food gatherers, ceremonial and cultural people who just want, and will give, comfort and tender loving care to our terminally ill relatives. Because our terminally ill relatives know that they are dying, they usually always want songs to be sung, they want to hear the last sound of their traditional songs and the sound of the didgeridoo and clapsticks . . .
The Aboriginal Resource and Development Service Inc., part of the Northern Regional Council of the Congress of the Uniting Church, says:

Dying is seen as something that should occur naturally, even for people who are terminally ill, and any intervention by an outside person or agent should not happen, as it will be immediately seen as an act of murder or sorcery.

The bill passed by the Northern Territory is not about refusing medical treatment. That right already exists. It is about actively taking another person's life. Fifteen people at 3 o'clock in the morning assumed the competency to judge the quality of another person's life against a background of inadequate care facilities. As a Daly River resident put it:
Please spend the money on hospices so that the terminally ill have a choice and do not feel they are a burden on their loved ones.

Mr Acting Deputy President, this year we celebrate the triumphs and the legacy of the end of World War II. `Australia remembers' is the slogan on caps, rulers and key rings in the shop in the Parliament House foyer. But do we remember? Have we forgotten the urgency with which countries got together after the war to come up with some basic principles on civil and human rights in an attempt to prevent the circumstances ever rising again that led to Nazi atrocities?

PARA.TAB: In 50 years, euthanasia has metamorphosed from a Nuremburg war crime to legalised compassion. The Germans never saw the door they were opening. They, too, believed their initial intentions were honourable and compassionate. Leo Alexander, an observer at the trials of Nazi doctors at Nuremburg, wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: It started with the acceptance of the attitude, basic in the euthanasia movement, that there is such a thing as a life not worthy to be lived. This attitude in its early stages concerned itself merely with the severely and chronically sick. Gradually, the sphere of those to be included in this category was enlarged to encompass the socially unproductive, the ideologically unwanted, the racially unwanted and, finally, all non-Germans. But it is important to realise that the infinitely small wedged-in lever from which this entire trend of mind received its impetus was the attitude towards the non-rehabilitable sick.

Why should we have so much faith in ourselves that abuses would never happen here? Australia has its own dark corners of hate and prejudice: blood-red swastikas on a grave, sarin on Australian soil, anti-Semitism and extremist propaganda. Adopting that `it could never happen here' syndrome means that we are blind to the existence of those dark corners in the human psyche, and blind to the real lessons of World War II, when the insanity of a few infected the reason of many at the cost of human life.

PARA.TAB: Lest we forget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was most impressed with the speech just given by Senator Boswell. I am very much against euthanasia myself, and not only because I am getting a bit towards the age where people might contemplate it. It is done on a higher basis than that. Whether one agrees with it or not, one could hardly say that the legislation passed in the Northern Territory was the greatest exhibition of drafting. Just trying to administer the act would probably cause one to suicide, because it is so extraordinarily drafted. But I am against the culture of death, myself, whatever others might be.

PARA.TAB: In any event, Mr Acting Deputy President, we are talking of high values, and what I wanted to speak about is a headline in the Age today which reads: `Opposition leadership disowns Aldred'. It is written by Karen Middleton, an eminent journalist from the Age and its diplomatic correspondent in Canberra. She has written:

SPEECH.PARA: Federal Liberal MP Mr Ken Aldred has been isolated by the Opposition leadership and savaged by senior ministers for using parliamentary privilege to make extraordinary claims of bribery and paedophilia in the diplomatic corps.

Yesterday, both the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the shadow minister for foreign affairs, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), distanced themselves from the allegation by the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Aldred). The Leader of the Opposition and the member for Mayo are to be congratulated for their action. People are entitled to maintain their reputation and they are entitled, according to the values of our society, to pursue their lives and to go about their business without harassment and without false statements being made about their character as has happened in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: A headline in yesterday's Financial Review reads, `Federal Police inquiry clears Ray and Richardson'. The by-line provides the information that the article is written by Steve Lewis, who is an eminent journalist in the Fairfax press. The article says:

SPEECH.PARA: An Australian Federal Police inquiry has cleared Defence Minister, Senator Ray, and former Federal minister and ALP power broker, Mr Graham Richardson, of any Commonwealth offences arising from a Queensland-based police investigation.
It would be heartening, and, may I say, an act of justice and of graciousness, if those on the other side acknowledged the result of the inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wasn't it Senator Chapman?

—Senator Sherry, I accept your interjection. I am confident that it is acknowledged by those on both sides that Senator Ray is an eminent senator who is universally respected in this chamber, and, indeed, in this parliament. I am disappointed that, even though Senator Ray is exonerated, the response to the situation is a question which, although in its terms is a legitimate question and is not framed in abusive tones, nevertheless contains the imputation that the investigation conducted by the Federal Police is tainted. The question also contains the imputation that, since the investigation is tainted, the stain which it is suggested is attached to the characters of Senator Ray and Mr Richardson remains.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that Senator Ray and Mr Richardson are entitled to the character that they have. As I said previously, Senator Ray is an eminent minister of the Crown and he is entitled to be seen and to be accepted as a person of absolute integrity. It is disappointing that circumstances are allowed to occur so that innuendo, subtle though it may be, is allowed to emanate through this chamber. Having emanated through this chamber to the world at large, the innuendo suggests that there is still some question over Senator Ray's character.

This situation is shameful, and I use that word advisedly. If the leadership shown by Mr Howard and Mr Downer in the House of Representatives in respect of the scurrilous allegations that are made against members of the diplomatic corps could be similarly shown here, that action would very much help the situation in this place. It would also be an act of considerable justice to the people who deserve it.

The source of the information used against Senator Ray and Mr Richardson has not been established, although it is suggested that the information came from the Criminal Justice Commission of Queensland. There is no evidence of that, and, therefore, the Criminal Justice Commission should not, in any way, be held responsible until it is shown otherwise.

A suggestion is occasionally made that out of frustration investigating bodies sometimes release information to damage people publicly because the investigating officers are unable to proceed against them in the course of their duty. In other words, there is no evidence that can be safely relied upon by those investigating officers and they therefore use other methods, including the method of publicity.

I noticed earlier this year that Sir Paul Condon, the commissioner of metropolitan police in England, was concerned that the police under his charge did not have enough weapons to proceed in a way he thought appropriate. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Many police officers feel the criminal justice system is almost nothing to do with establishing truth.
He went on to say:

If there isn't confidence in the system, then it is harder for people like me to hold the line on ethical standards, because street cops see what's happening to victims, they see villains escape time and time again from court hearings, and that's when you risk `noble cause corruption'.

It is a very serious issue when a very senior police officer talks in terms of `noble cause corruption'. What he is saying is that, if the police are not satisfied with parliament and the legitimate institutions of this land that set out these standards by which police might act, they must use corrupt methods—methods other than those which are given to them by parliament. I suppose it is the Oliver North syndrome that was made so famous by that person in America during the 1980s.

PARA.TAB: It would be a most shameful thing and a very worrying thing and something highly prejudicial to the sort of democracy we live in if investigating agents were to become frustrated, not satisfied with what parliament does, and therefore turn to noble cause corruption, either by leaking information to the press so people's characters may be brought into disrepute or by other means.

The reality is that the decision makers in this country are the parliamentarians. It is this institution of parliament that delineates how people should act. It is this institution that delineates the powers that will be given to the police or investigating agents—to try to go outside that is a very dangerous matter. If this institution were to encourage that—and that encouragement would no doubt come about inadvertently in a way that was not intended—it would be a matter for considerable concern.

I say that without pointing the finger at any particular investigating agency. I simply say that those sorts of agencies in the generic sense ought to be ever mindful that it is this place that decides those instruments by which they will be empowered to carry out the investigations.

I simply want to reiterate what I said at the start, that I do hope that it is acknowledged by everybody in this chamber, and as soon as possible, that Senator Ray and Mr Richardson are people of undoubted integrity, and that Senator Ray is a minister of undoubted ability and his integrity has never been marred, either in this place or elsewhere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to deal with a matter which I think is very much of public importance and public interest, particularly to many workers in an industry in Tasmania—namely, the forest industry. On 23 March this year I gave notice of a motion that the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee conduct an inquiry into certain aspects of conduct of the operations of forestry authorities in various states. To date I have not been able to get support for that notice of motion, even though it was agreed to by, I think, all members.

PARA.TAB: One of the very reasons I sought to do that was because of the circumstances that currently exist in the industry within Australia and, more particularly as it relates to Tasmania, which is the state that I know best. Some of the existing practices simply are not lending themselves to a forest industry achieving better outcomes for this country in social and economic terms. They are also not lending themselves to better management of our forests—in particular, our native forests.

In addressing those concerns, and the unfortunate fact that we have not been able to allow the committee to proceed with this inquiry, I just want to highlight some circumstances that exist to show why this inquiry is so very important. The forest industry has not been without its inquiries. We have had umpteen inquiries into the forest industry, many of which I would have said were not even relevant and many of which, I would have thought, were politically motivated. But, of course, the one I sought to pursue simply was not. It was based on trying to achieve a better outcome for the industry, to allow the industry to achieve its full potential and allow it, as I said, to deliver better both socially and economically.

Forestry Tasmania, a corporate body which used to be called the Forestry Commission, has the responsibility for management and control of the state's crown forests. One of the very concerning things that has been allowed to continue in Tasmania is a concessional rights system under which an area based concession is granted to a particular company. This arrangement, which has been legislated for in the parliament, has been in operation for many years. Of course, we would probably have to accept the fact that, in the days when concessions were granted, they had some relevance on the basis of encouraging investment, particularly in the area of paper making.

Today is a new age and we have a responsibility as a community to ensure that we achieve a better outcome from the natural resources that we take, either from forests or out of the ground, in so far as there are economic benefits and, in particular, employment benefits that must flow from something that is, after all, the public's resource. What has happened in Tasmania is that in 1991, and as the result of a state Labor government effort, legislation was introduced into the parliament, and ultimately passed, to bring an end to the concessional rights system. The legislation effectively sought to change the whole practice of the way in which wood from public forests is sold to customers of the Forestry Commission, now Forestry Tasmania. It was proposed that the wood be sold on a volume basis rather than through the concessional rights system.

The concessional rights system has in effect led to what in my view is a misuse of the forest resources, in such a way that ours has become a pulpwood driven industry. As most senators would be aware, there was much debate prior to Christmas last year about export woodchips. Even though there were some unfortunate consequences of that debate and the circumstances that led to the debate, we have not sorted out the real issues for the forest industry.

In Tasmania we have a situation where the commission categorises the type of wood taken from the forest. Under the allocation system, it has an obligation to what are known as crown sawmillers to provide a certain amount of category 1 and category 3 sawlogs. Category 2 sawlogs are produced and then sold on the basis of demand. Then we have a new category of logs known as category 8, which effectively have no specifications set by Forestry Tasmania. There is no requirement on the current industry participants in the sawmilling sector to utilise these logs. They can utilise them on the basis that they seek to do so. Outside of that, most category 2 sawlogs, which in all other states sawmills would be required to take, ultimately end being woodchipped. That is simply because of the way the industry is conducted in our state.

That is a sad state of affairs. Nobody would argue about the jobs in this industry being in the sawmilling sector—the processing sector. That is exactly what we have to deal with. If you have a system of selling wood from the crown to a customer that is flawed, then it should be changed. That is what I sought ultimately to bring out, as a result of seeking some inquiry: to identify the circumstances that were wrong, to see if we could get some remedy to those—because I believe there is a remedy to them—and to get onto greater processing of wood taken from the forests in Tasmania.

By way of example, in terms of looking at logs that are currently woodchipped in Tasmania, I have photographs that were taken on 25 April 1993 at a railway siding. They are photographs of logs that are destined for the woodchip mill, but there is no way that logs like these should be destined for a woodchip mill. Indeed, many people have proposed that by way of introducing recovery mills, whether they be flitch recovery mills or recovery sawmills, they can cut those logs into face grade material.

I have here a photograph taken on 27 May 1993 of logs that someone has put up a proposal for processing to the Tasmanian Forestry Commission in 1992. In 1992 he put a proposal to the Forestry Commission to put flitch recovery mills at each of the woodchip mills that were in existence in Tasmania at that time. We now have an additional one, but at that time we had three. The proposal would have seen somewhere in the order of 200,000 cubic metres of recoverable wood produced, which could have been channelled into the existing processing industry. To put that in context, 200,000 cubic metres is around 60 per cent of what is currently being used by the entire crown sawmilling industry in Tasmania. That is the sort of figure we are talking about. Take the number of jobs that exist in the current sawmilling industry in Tasmania and multiply it by 60 per cent, and there would be a lot more jobs.

The current state government has made some small effort about dealing with processing plants. It has made a few announcements about medium density fibreboard plants and it has made another announcement about a fibre form plant. Also we have had some indication from the Taiwan Pulp and Paper Corporation about building a pulp mill. But nowhere is there any evidence that any of these things are being progressed so that they might come to fruition. In fact, I think that the state government and its authority have been doing exactly the opposite.

The reason for my view is based around a letter from the Forestry Commission to a proponent of a particular development. The commission wrote this letter on 8 July 1993 to a person who was proposing to build flitch mills. In part, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: As previously indicated, the Commission is at various stages of negotiation with a number of proponents interested in using pulpwood available in our forests. For some the interest is in the southern forests, while for others it is in the north-west of the state.
Then it goes on to say:
As you would be aware, a high degree of cooperation with the chip exporters—
this is the manager of the crown forest—

will be necessary because your proposed operations need to tap into the flow of logs they have previously utilised and relies upon them for the sale of residues. In addition, the Commission does have ethical, legislative and contractual obligations with these customers and wishes to ensure that no disadvantage accrues to existing industries.

I would have to say that any state government that would suggest and, in my view, actively oppose somebody who was proposing to improve the recovery of wood taken from our native forests is highly questionable. But it gets worse. The letter states:

Accordingly, we have discussed the cooperation issue and related matters with some of the people in the industry and within the Commission itself. We have identified a few issues which need to be resolved jointly at your earliest convenience. None are seen as insurmountable hurdles.
Remember, this is 8 July 1993. Then there are a number of points that are set out as the not too insurmountable hurdles. It says in point 4:
Residues can be taken by the chip exporters only in the form of offcuts. That is, they do not want to buy chips.

Anyone who has got any knowledge about having a recovery sawmill has to understand that the only way it can be made economically viable in terms of the residue that will be produced, because it is actually cutting up lower grade logs, is to have some form of in-line chipper. It is simply not economically viable, or it is very difficult to make it economically viable, in terms of the volume of residue that will be produced to actually then have to reload that and pack it off at your expense and send it to some woodchip plant. The letter goes on:
The purchase of residues by the chip exporters cannot reduce the quality of their product mix.

Forgive me for being somewhat naive but I thought that the woodchip industry, from its inception, was designed to actually utilise all of the low-end, low-grade quality wood that could not be used for other purposes. To have the representative authority of a state government, which is managing the state forests, putting this down in writing is ridiculous. It goes on to say:
The arrangements to be set in place between the Commission and your company must not place additional cost burdens on the existing users of the pulpwood resource.

Quite frankly, if that is not active dissuasion against a person who is proposing better utilisation of the forests, I do not know what is. Given this, I would encourage the members on the other side of the chamber—and I am happy to provide more evidence to them—to consider the position of the inquiry that I have proposed and allow it to proceed. To do otherwise is simply aiding and abetting what can be, it has to be said, almost corrupt practices of a state forest authority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to inform the Senate of a recent visit that I made to Portugal, as a guest of that government, in relation to a conference dealing with the situation in East Timor. The conference was held last week from 31 May to 2 June. There was a delegation from this parliament comprising my National Party colleague Senator McGauran, and members from the other place, Mr Gary Gibson, member for Morton, and Mr Ted Grace, member for Fowler.

PARA.TAB: The Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade acknowledged in its report last year dealing with Indonesia that the situation in East Timor is the greatest difficulty that this country has in its relations with Indonesia, and so it should be. Some 32 countries were represented at this conference and there would have been over 150 delegates from a variety of political strains, and racial and ethnic backgrounds.

The conference concluded with a Lisbon declaration. I will deal with the terms of that declaration. In the first instance, the declaration was proposed by the Portuguese delegation. However, it was felt by delegates that perhaps there was not sufficient substance to the declaration, as such, and that there should be a specific plan of action. So it was that His Honour Mr Justice Kirby, the Chairman of the International Commission of Jurists—I believe that was the capacity in which he attended the conference—drafted some 23 points as a plan of action. Lord Avebury from the United Kingdom also drafted a plan of action. At the conclusion of the conference, we were successful in having both of those plans of action incorporated into the Lisbon declaration.

I take this opportunity to pay tribute to Mr Justice Kirby for the excellent submission he made to the conference and the work that he put into drafting these 23 points comprising a plan of action. Australia was well represented by the delegation that attended this conference, a delegation which represented the diverse, domestic political views in this country. I think that Australia's standing was advanced both by the efforts of the delegates who attended and, in particular, by the contribution made by His Honour Mr Justice Kirby. The declaration, as proposed by the Portuguese delegates, in summary, recommended that, inter alia, Indonesia accept the various United Nations resolutions which have been passed in relation to the East Timorese question, that political prisoners be released, that an arms embargo be placed on Indonesia—due to the current situation in East Timor—and that there be a resolution to the problem which is internationally acceptable.

The more specific points raised by Mr Justice Kirby dealt with such matters as: increased parliamentary visits to East Timor; parliamentary pressure to continue to be applied by way of resolution; United Nations action involving a visit to East Timor by the High Commissioner for Human Rights; pressure on the Secretary-General to call on Indonesia to comply with the recommendations of the special rapporteur on summary executions; the collection of sound data and information on the situation in East Timor, such as the number of extra-judicial killings; increased presence of the Red Cross and UNICEF in East Timor; and consideration of the use of the genocide convention in respect of any alleged cases of genocide. There was also a further recommendation that the Inter-Parliamentary Union add East Timor to its list of concerns. For his part, Lord Avebury recommended that there should be coordination between parliamentarians who support the rights of East Timorese. I think that is a sound recommendation and one which could only advance the cause of the East Timorese people.

For his part, Lord Avebury recommended that there should be coordination between parliamentarians who support the rights of East Timorese. I think that is a sound recommendation and one which could only advance the cause of the East Timorese people.

I believe the Lisbon declaration with these plans of action—and I have only touched on some of them—was a worthwhile result from this conference. This conference has been timely for two reasons. Firstly, whilst that conference was being held, a boatload of East Timorese people arrived in Darwin in the Northern Territory. These people were seeking refugee status in this country. Secondly, on 3 June, at the conclusion of the conference, the United Nations sponsored a meeting in Austria between the various East Timorese groups and the Indonesians. Indeed, this initiative is a very good one. I think it is perhaps one of the more remarkable steps forward in relation to this matter in the last 20 years.

I will not touch on the case of the East Timorese people seeking refugee status here today. Perhaps that will be dealt with at another time. The fruits of the meeting of the United Nations in Austria remain to be seen. I can only hope that good will come of it. It may be that further meetings have to be held and that, in turn, will only be positive.

We cannot ignore the history of this matter. As I mentioned previously, the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs looked at the question of East Timor and our relations with Indonesia. It found evidence which supported the deaths of some 200,000 East Timorese as a result of causes directly or indirectly attributable to the integration by Indonesia. Furthermore, there has been acknowledged suppression of East Timorese culture and language. There has also been an interference with religious freedom in that country. Religious practice there is predominantly Catholic and recent events have taken place in relation to the practice of that religion.

More recently, this year there have been incidents mentioned at Baucau, Dili and Liquica. These incidents must also be taken notice of and must be the subject of great concern by this Senate and all parties represented here. The government, of course, has protested strongly in relation to these recent events and, in the past, has protested to the Indonesian government in relation to the abuse of human rights in East Timor. I think that is a proper course of action to take. In a speech to Amnesty International, Alexander Downer recently stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We can't simply speak with a loud voice when injustice occurs on one side of the world, while whispering softly or remaining silent when similar events take place within our own region.

This statement has a universal application. It is much easier for countries that are well removed geographically from this problem to voice strong concerns; it is perhaps easier for us as a country to voice strong concerns about matters which occur on the other side of the world.

PARA.TAB: For my part, the state of Western Australia, which I represent, has its northern coastline only a few hundred kilometres from the country of Indonesia, the place where these events are occurring. Whilst it is imperative that we have very good relations with Indonesia, it is also imperative that that relationship be based on honesty and frankness, and that includes a frank approach to the question of human rights by Australia. I support Alexander Downer's suggestion that there could well be an Asian Pacific human rights body which could have some influence in curbing human rights abuses in the region. It is not only East Timor that we are looking at. There is also the question of Burma, Tibet and other places in the region which could well be the subject of some scrutiny. I believe that countries such as Australia and New Zealand have a crucial role in this regard.

There have been some positive aspects in Indonesia recently. One is the establishment of the national human rights commission. That has been greeted with some scepticism, and I would say to the Senate that it is up to this Senate and the parliament of this country to monitor closely the performance of that body, to give it every encouragement, and to ensure that it achieves what it has set out to do.

There is a great deal of international concern about events in East Timor, and I would suggest to the Senate that the concern is bipartisan. This was evident at the conference which I attended. The delegation from Australia represented all spectrums of thought, and this applied to those other countries which were represented there. More recently, in March this year, we have had the Oceanic catholic archbishops conference expressing solidarity with the struggle that the East Timorese people are undergoing.

This is a matter of great importance to Australia. I believe that the Portuguese initiative in holding this conference was a very good one, and for that I congratulate them. I would, however, state one thing. The case that Portugal has in the International Court of Justice can perhaps be confused with the question of human rights in East Timor. That matter is the subject of some deliberation by that court, and I will not go into it in any detail. Suffice it to say that Australia is only setting out to use those resources which are legally hers. The case put by Australia is a sound one, and I would commend to senators the case, as put forward by Michael Tate and others, as a means of ascertaining our position in that respect.

Finally, Madam Acting Deputy President, this is a problem which will not go away overnight. It will require our constant attention and our constant monitoring of the situation. I would urge all senators to participate in the debate on this matter, and to participate in resolutions in relation to this matter. I would encourage the Senate and any of its committees which have any terms of reference which might touch on this to push for some sort of exchange visit with East Timor. I believe that it is only by maintaining pressure from this chamber that we will see a solution to this problem which is internationally acceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a matter of public interest concerning ageism and the continuing negative stereotyping of older people. Recently I received a copy of a letter from members of an aged care organisation who were concerned and offended by a children's book which dealt in part with the aged. The book is a series of short stories and poems on various subjects, two of which are about the aged. The two stories about older people are not only in extremely bad taste and degrading to older people; they reinforce outdated and incorrect stereotypes of the elderly and they misrepresent community organisations such as Meals on Wheels. I would like to read to the Senate from this book a story called `Looking after Granny'. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: You be Granny, OK? Hullo, Granny.
Hullo, Darling.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sit down here, Granny, and let your dear little grand-daughter look after you, you silly old prune.

SPEECH.PARA: That's nice, Darling.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Put your teeth back in, Granny, and stop dribbling. Do you want a cuppa tea?

SPEECH.PARA: That's nice, Darling.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Here's your cuppa tea and your pills, Gran.

SPEECH.PARA: Mind you, `cup of' is spelt c-u-p-p-a: good for children to learn how to spell.

PARA.EMPHASIS: This one's to make you go to the toilet, this one's to stop you going to the toilet, this one's to make you sleep, this one's to wake you up, these are for your kidneys, this one's for your guts, this one's for naughty dreams, this one's for warts. Now take all your pills

SPEECH.PARA: That's nice, Darling.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Now would you like your dear little grand-daughter to give you a massage?

SPEECH.PARA: That's nice, Darling.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Well you just lie here and I'll massage your bottom
hard like this with the potato masher.

SPEECH.PARA: That's nice, Darling.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Now you just lie here and do a bit of dying.

SPEECH.PARA: I'll pump up your pillow. Oh, sorry Gran. I plumped up your head. All comfy now, Granny?
That's nice, Darling, more pills please.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Don't eat too many pills or you won't have room for your meals-on-wheels. Here's your ciggies, Gran. I'll put on some nice music.

SPEECH.PARA: That's nice, Darling.
And it goes on. I will not read all of it, but here is another bit of it:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Now here's your meals-on-wheels. That brown mush is soup and that brown mush is main course, this brown mush is cabbage and pumpkin and parsnips and this brown mush is dessert and this brown mush is brown mush.

SPEECH.PARA: That's nice, Darling.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Now do you want another massage to get your dinner down? Or do you want a snooze in front of the telly while I wash your undies?

SPEECH.PARA: That's nice, Darling . . . erp!
Now it's my turn to be Granny.

Unbelievably, this book won an honour award from the Children's Book Council of Australia. I do not know whether, like Ros Kelly, they looked at the cover and did not look at the contents, but I cannot understand how a book could get an honour award with a poem in it like that. The point is that representation of older people in this book could not be condoned by any reasonable person and certainly should not have been encouraged to be read by Australian children.

PARA.TAB: Could you imagine the outcry if a children's book presented an equivalent negative stereotyping of indigenous Australians, an ethnic group or homosexuals? There would be an outrage. Why is it that we tolerate such negative images of older people—in this case, even rewarding the book with an honour award—while we are so strident in our condemnation of anyone who negatively stereotypes or misrepresents vocal minority groups in our community.

Only yesterday in the Australian there was an article with the heading `Attack on magazine's "racist" poem.' It said that the Australian Press Council condemned as racist a poem which had been published and saying it was portraying a poor image of a particular group of immigrants. There was the Press Council coming out in rage. Have we seen any rage in terms of the sorts of stereotyping we see of older people?

Negative stereotyping of any group, including older people, is an insidious and destructive force. In the case of older people, negative stereotyping has acted to undermine their self-esteem and sense of wellbeing and stigmatised and excluded them from mainstream Australian life.

Healthy ageing is not just about physical health; it is about a feeling of wellbeing that develops out of experiences and the feedback that people get from others about their worth. Like any group in society, older people's sense of self is socially constructed, so society's attitude to growing older has an effect on how older people feel about themselves. Positive stereotypes can play a significant and important role.

I do not know whether my colleagues here are aware of the successful ageing project which took place in the ACT. It was a project which focused on what older people themselves identified as the social and physical conditions that enhanced the process of growing older. Let me quote from the evaluation report of that project:

SPEECH.PARA: Those interviewed repeatedly identified the need for widespread acceptance of older people as a population continuing to have resources to offer the community. This was seen as a social condition enabling people to successfully age. It was felt that as long as people feel they are valued by the community they in turn value themselves.
Later on the report went on to say:

Acceptance of this age group as capable and valuable members of the community was seen as essential to the `successful ageing' of the community . . . It is particularly important for policy makers and service providers alike to set about to change not only their own perceptions of the group aged 60 years and older but also to change the prevailing image in the wider population, including many of those already considered elderly.

Older Australians are too often portrayed and treated stereotypically as dependent, frail and unwell, inflexible and unable to accept change, passive, unproductive, mentally deteriorating and eventually needing institutionalisation. They are depicted by many as an inconvenient, slightly conscience-prodding minority who have little to do with the young vigorous majority.

PARA.TAB: These stereotypes have been perpetuated in language, government policy documents, professional literature and particularly in the media. In the 1990s they are still being perpetuated—I have given such an example today in that children's book. On television, if older people appear at all, they tend to be depicted as more comical, stubborn, eccentric and foolish than other characters. They are also more likely to be treated with disrespect. The negative images surrounding ageing are bound up with fear, outdated stereotypes and alarmist projections about the implications of an ageing population.

It is important to study the images of the elderly that are presented in our literature and the media and to ask whether these images are appropriate, accurate portrayals of older people in our society. The fact is they are not. These stereotypes do not reflect the reality of older people. They are grossly incorrect for the vast majority of older people. They demean and devalue them. The reality is that increasingly the aged are active, independent, healthy and involved people who contribute much to the economic, social and cultural life of Australia. The reality is that more than 60 per cent of the over-65 population have no limit to their functional ability. An additional 30 per cent report only some minor restrictions to their activity. Only 2.5 per cent of Australians over 60 live in nursing homes while 1.7 per cent live in hostels. Of those over 85, only 20 per cent live in nursing homes and 13.2 per cent live in hostels.

Most older people are leading active lives out in the community. Let me give an example of just how incorrect negative stereotypes are. Older Australians are frequently portrayed as dependent. Rarely emphasised are the figures that show how centrally involved our elders are in supporting other people. Hal Kendig's study of the aged in 1983 found that older people were more likely to be providers than recipients of many kinds of support. They are twice as likely to give financial assistance to their families than the reverse and they contribute enormously to families and the community through child minding and as volunteers.

Older people are also the pivot for much of the continuity of family culture and, as such, their position in our society should be valued and acknowledged. Older citizens are individuals who cannot and should not be lumped into one category of physically, socially and mentally impaired people. They are not an homogenous group with static needs but are a diverse and dynamic group. They come from a wide variety of cultural, educational and professional backgrounds with very different financial circumstances, physical capabilities, lifestyles, opinions and expectations. They range from the very active involved to the older frail aged.

Ageing is not an illness; it is a description of the life cycle itself. As a society we need to change our attitude to ageing and think again about the intrinsic value of life's many stages: from infancy to childhood, adolescence, adulthood, old age and old, old age.

As Australia grows older in the latter part of this century and even more into the next century, the majority of us can look forward to a fit, productive old age.
