In fact, future generations of older Australians are likely to be the best educated, best fed, best housed, healthiest and most active generation of Australians ever to have reached their sixth decile. Old age promises to be a rich resource for our society; but only if it is accompanied by wise and appropriate policies and by a shift in attitude away from the negative images that consign older people to the scrap heap.

It is time as legislators that all of us here, members and senators, ensure that outmoded images of ageing and the aged are broken down. Today I have given just one example of a very outmoded and totally inappropriate representation of older people. Those outmoded images should be broken down and the public and policy makers should be educated to understand that the years after 65 are overwhelmingly a time of wellness, achievement and opportunity. What we need is a revolution against ageism. We have seen revolutions against sexism and against racism. Now we need to make sure that older people in our community are not ridiculed or treated with disrespect.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Cook, the Minister representing the Treasurer. I remind the minister of the recent OECD report, Taxing profits in a global economy, a report I think the minister has referred to on a number of occasions recently, which found that Australian investors face the second-highest effective corporate tax burden among all OECD countries and that Australia's effective corporate tax burden was above the OECD average for foreign investors. I ask the minister: how is the proposed increase of another three percentage points in the company tax rate going to make Australia more competitive and encourage people to invest here rather than invest overseas?

—Just on a small point of correction to begin with, I did not refer to that report recently. What I referred to was the OECD country report which the OECD provided. I think it was under an embargo for release at 3 a.m. last Friday.

PARA.TAB: I have to say that as a consequence I am not as familiar with the report that Senator Hill has referred to, but I must say that the Australian economy does offer a good destination for investment. The reduction in tariffs, the opening up of our economy, the removal of exchange rates, the changes to a more liberal financial market and the growth of Australian industry and its increasing competitiveness under Labor all mean that Australia has been a country that has attracted a great deal of foreign investment interest.

The steps we have taken which have internationalised the financial markets have meant that there has been a greater degree of foreign borrowings. These foreign borrowings were mostly for financing expansion of the Australian economy, and there has been a degree of increase in equity take-up in Australia too. On both those scores one can see that Australia, as an investment destination, is indeed internationally attractive. Further to that, we have been pursuing—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is the saving rate so low? You are selling the farm cheaply.
—I have been talking about how the market has been reacting.
—Order! Senator Kemp.

—The market has been reacting positively to the investment attraction of Australia. In addition to that, the government has been pursuing a course of action in attracting regional headquarters of international companies to Australia.

—Could I take a point of order, Mr President? This is all very interesting but it is not relevant to the question that was asked. The question that was asked was, if Australia already has the second highest effective corporate tax rate of OECD countries, how is an extra three per cent added to that going to affect our capacity to attract investment?
—That is not a point of order. Where is your point of order? Which standing order, Senator?

—It is relevance. Don't you understand the standing orders? Do you want me to repeat it? The question is: as we already have an extraordinarily high corporate tax rate, how will Australia be more competitive by you pushing up the percentage another three points?
—Order! There is no point of order because I have no way of judging relevance in such a precise nature.

—The question relates to the attractiveness of Australia as an investment destination. As I have constantly said here, in terms of the OECD list—I think on the last figures—and in terms of the overall tax burden Australia is the second lowest tax country in the OECD. But what attracts investment to Australia is in part the attractiveness of our tax settings.

PARA.TAB: But it is much wider than that. It is to do with the stability of our government and the stability of the political climate here; it is to do with the provision of a high-skill work force in Australia with a plentiful supply of skills that cannot be found in other areas in this region; it is to do with the multicultural elements of Australia. We speak all the languages of Europe and Asia; that is the reason for investment in Australia, to take advantage of the Asian market. It is to do with the comparative lower cost of other competing investment destinations in the region, the lower cost of office and factory set-up in Australia compared, say, with Singapore and Hong Kong. It is about one half to one third of those two destinations. For a whole host of reasons, Australia is internationally rated as a good investment destination, and I recall remarks of that character being made recently by an international banker about Australia's investment standing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the minister to the continuing public debate on the reform of the Australian constitution in the move towards the republic. In particular, I refer to the proposition from various quarters on the need for a people's convention to discuss these various issues. I ask: will the government embrace the opposition's proposal for a people's constitutional convention as part of its approach to the republic debate?

—Mr President, a number of things need to be understood about the idea of a people's constitutional convention. In the first place—this may come as news to the opposition—the 1990s are not the 1890s. It is true that an elected people's convention was a key part of the federal constitutional decision making process in the 1890s but the circumstances are very different now from then.

PARA.TAB: Then, there was no Australian nation. Then, there was no Australian constitution. Then, there was no established process to debate the making or the amendment of the national constitution. Then, there was no established process for initiating constitutional change. Then, there was no established process for adopting constitutional change. In that context, the establishment of a people's convention was necessary to give a kick-start to the whole process: to create a body which could decide upon the constitutional text, to decide upon a method of putting it to the people, and to trigger the whole adoption process into action.

By contrast 100 years later, in the 1990s, we have an Australian nation, we have an Australian constitution, we have an established representative process for debating and initiating constitutional change, namely, the national parliament, we have an established process for adopting constitutional change, namely, the referendum process laid out in the text of the constitution itself. So we do not need an elected convention or any kind of formal new body as part of the decision making process, whether it is about the republic or anything else, in the 1990s.

In the second place, it is not at all clear what value a people's convention would add to the consultative process. We do need, just as we did in the 1890s, a proper consultative process to ensure that the Australian people are well informed about the constitutional proposals put to them and also to ensure that the parliament itself, before putting proposals forward, has systematic input from the community as a whole.

A people's convention means—although the opposition does not tell us—a fully elected convention, otherwise it would be just another conference like the one we had in the Old Parliament House a few weeks ago, or just another gathering of parliamentary representatives, as we have had six times, without conspicuous success, over the period from 1973 to 1985.

But, if you had such an elected convention, it would be extremely expensive to put together—something like $40 million to elect it—and, at the end of that process, it would not necessarily be any more representative or any more responsive to public opinion than this particular parliament and it would not of itself have the capacity to actually require any proposals to be put to referendum. The most it could do would be to request or advise this parliament to do so. This is the basic point: the idea of a people's convention may or may not add some value to the consultative process but we do have real doubts on this side of the parliament—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections on my left.

—whether it could possibly add more value to that consultative process than it would cost. Certainly, we have some doubts as to whether it could add any more value than other ways of tapping community responses through an extensive grassroots consultative process of the kind that we have in mind.

PARA.TAB: What any kind of people's convention, of the kind that the opposition seems to have in mind, cannot do is add any real value to the decision making process. Mr Howard's people's convention—which, he says, the opposition will not be bound by anyway—is not a means of advancing decision making on an Australian republic or anything else. It is simply a means to enable Mr Howard to avoid making any decisions himself, to stay in his cautious, nervous, leaderless policy-free zone.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: I remind you of the ruling that was made in this place on 17 May 1990. On that occasion the questioner was one Senator M.E. Beahan. The ruling was that a minister cannot accept responsibility for matters that are alleged to be contained in the policies of the non-government party. Senator Evans, in referring to Mr Howard's contribution to this debate, is clearly making reference to what is in the non-government party's policies and outlook. What he ought to do—

—Order! You have made your point. It is quite clear what you are saying. There is no point of order because the questioner clearly asked for the intentions of the government in this matter, and that is also a clear precedent.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Could the minister inform the people of Australia what higher and new taxes will come into effect on 1 July 1995 and how much extra tax revenue the people of Australia will be paying next year as a direct result?
—The taxes that will take effect as a consequence of the budget are set down in the budget. They relate to a range of measures.
—Not really! You do surprise me and everybody!

—They are indeed. They relate to a range of measures. I do not have a total outcome figure in my brief, but I refer you to the budget documents, which you are familiar with because we covered them just recently on Friday in the estimates process. There are a range of tax changes which have been reported to this Senate.

—Mr President, on a point of order: the minister who is answering this question is the minister representing the Treasurer in this place. Surely he is not trying to tell us that he does not know the new tax increases that he will be introducing and that will take effect from 1 July. I ask him to direct his answer to the specifics of my question.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—I agree, Mr President. I am simply saying that I am not a research officer for you, Senator Short. If you want to find out information, look in the budget papers.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is quite clear that, once again, this minister does not have a clue in the world about what he is talking about or the facts at his disposal. Is it a fact that the increases include a one percentage point interest in sales tax rates; a new 12 per cent sales tax on building materials; a two percentage point increase in sales tax on wine; an increase in the Medicare levy to 1.5 per cent; an increase in the excise on light fuel oil; a new aircraft noise levy; further corporate fee increases; higher bank licence and supervision fees; and a $150 increase in migration application fees? Furthermore, is the minister aware that these measures alone will increase taxation by over $1,400 million and that, when the almost 10 per cent increase in the company tax rate and the other new tax increases that were introduced in the budget are included—
—Sit down!
—the total tax grab this year—
—Sit down!
—will be $2,400 million next year?
—Order! I will tell him when it is time.

—We have had from Senator Short an indication that he knew the answer to most of the question anyway. All I can say is that Senator Short is in here not in the interests of adducing information but simply to play games. Senator Short, thank you for acknowledging that you are a games player. The list sounds full, but I do not know whether it is complete. I will check that and I will add to my answer. Secondly, I do not accept the figures that Senator Short has given us on the tax burden. I will check those and provide the Senate with an answer on that matter.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. My question relates to an extremely important area in Queensland—namely, the area in which the Torres Strait islands are located. Is the minister aware that there have recently been queries about customs activities in the Torres Strait area, particularly relating to the adequacy of resources? In this regard, can the minister inform the Senate whether the resources allocated to the Australian Customs Service to protect the area are sufficient to detect and deter illegal activities?

—The Torres Strait area is recognised as a high risk area and is resourced accordingly by the Australian government. Customs cooperates with the Australian Federal Police, the Queensland police and PNG authorities to continually assess the risk in the Torres Strait area and exchange information. I am informed by customs that it has eight full-time people operating in the Torres Strait area and the Federal Police has 23 officers engaged in operational matters in northern Queensland, including the Torres Strait area. These controls are applied in an environment where, under the Torres Strait treaty, there is free international movement of traditional inhabitants for traditional purposes.

PARA.TAB: Customs itself currently has a launch, three fixed-wing aircraft and a helicopter operating in the Torres Strait region. With the commencement of a new Coastwatch contract on 1 July 1995, a new helicopter will replace the existing one. The new helicopter will be a more capable aircraft and, in particular, will be fitted with night vision capabilities. This is a direct response to the requirements expressed by Coastwatch clients, including customs and police, that an ability to operate at night was necessary in the Torres Strait islands. On 1 October 1995 the second phase of the new Coastwatch contract commences with six new islander and one Shrike aircraft being deployed on the northern Australian coast. Two islander aircraft will be located in the Torres Strait region.

Customs is also reviewing its marine capability in the Torres Strait region. This is likely to result in a periodic deployment to the area of one of the larger customs vessels which, with the forward air support from Coastwatch aircraft, will significantly improve customs and marine capability in the region.

Customs has been working with the local community as part of a community participation program for island communities to significantly enhance the opportunities for the local community to advise customs on the improvement and collection of information about the possible illegal activities in the Torres Strait islands.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you ever considered setting up controls there using the local people?

—Senator Macdonald interjects. He has raised this issue before, sometimes in the local media, in a very misleading way. He has made allegations that firearms trafficking is rife across the Torres Strait islands. He first raised this in October 1994. At that time his main identification was a man wearing a red hat. Senator Macdonald was specifically advised in January by the Minister for Justice that this issue was considered by a conference of all the relevant enforcement agencies in late 1993 and mid-1994. He was advised that arising from these conferences, a joint strategic assessment was conducted of the alleged smuggling of firearms into PNG in exchange for cannabis. The assessment, finalised in August 1994, found that, despite media speculation, evidence of such exchange is limited.

PARA.TAB: I cannot give a 100 per cent guarantee to Senator Colston or the Senate that the enforcement agencies will stop all illegal activities in the Torres Strait islands but I can assure the Senate and Senator Colston that we are deploying relevant resources to the Torres Strait islands. In working with the local communities, we are doing everything we can within that region to stop illegal activities, as I have just described.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I remind the minister that on 22 December 1994 the Prime Minister's media statement included the words `export woodchip licences in future will only be granted in relation to areas where there has been significant progress towards, or the completion o,f both a regional forest agreement and the establishment of a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system'. The Prime Minister also indicated that woodchip exports from native forests not covered by regional forest agreements will be reduced by 20 per cent per annum. I ask the minister: What is the base figure that the Prime Minister meant would be used to determine the 1996 export licences? What is the Prime Minister's definition of significant progress towards an RFA that will be used to determine the 1996 licences? Will the 20 per cent be from volumes granted or volumes exported?

—In his statement of 22 December 1994 which Senator Bell referred to, the Prime Minister made it clear that the maximum permissible level of woodchips for export for 1996 would be five million tonnes except in relation to areas where there has been significant progress towards a regional forest agreement or the completion of such an RFA. I am advised that, so as not to foreclose options for a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system to be developed as part of the RFA process, the Commonwealth will be conducting a preliminary assessment of areas that may be required for the reserve system. Licences will not be granted for woodchips sourced from those areas. The base figure for 1996 will be dependent on the outcomes of this preliminary assessment, known as the deferred forest assessment process.

PARA.TAB: As to the second part of the question, significant progress will be judged to have been made when a scoping agreement to pursue an RFA has been signed by both relevant governments and progress made on the collection of the relevant data. The scoping requirement will, amongst other things, outline data requirements, critical time lines for the conduct of an RFA, potential resource use options and consultative arrangements.

As to the third part of the question, for areas not covered by an RFA or where significant progress has not been made towards an RFA by 31 December 1995, a 20 per cent reduction will apply to the amount of woodchips granted for 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. The time scale is a little worrying. This concept of scoping is one we have heard before. It seemed to be an excuse for not actually getting on with it. If the government wants to issue export woodchip licences this year, it appears there has not been much progress so far. With regard to the Prime Minister's statement that the maximum permissible level for export would be five million tonnes, Mr Beddall's table of 1995 licences totals 5.655 million tonnes and 20 per cent of that leaves about 4.524 million tonnes. I really think that half a million tonnes should be seen as a significant amount. Which will be the final figure for the licences—4.524 million tonnes or five million tonnes?

—My understanding was that the 1995 base figure was of the order of six million tonnes, a little over that. So with a 20 per cent reduction it would be just on five million rather than any less than that. But I will seek confirmation of that detail and advise Senator Bell further.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The Industry Commission report The growth and revenue implications of Hilmer and related reforms has been used to support claims that competition reform would generate huge benefits to Australia in the order of 5.46 per cent of GDP. These assumptions are highly questionable. While it is claimed by the Industry Commission that compulsory competitive tendering is supposed to yield cost savings of 20 per cent, the United Kingdom, which has been doing this, estimates the yield as six per cent without including the costs of monitoring. How do we expect to achieve 20 per cent savings in Australia given this experience? Haven't gains from improvements in technical efficiency been occurring anyway? Aren't the major gains based on increases in sackings and work intensification?

—The answer to the last part of the question is no. I think it is important to look exactly at what the Industry Commission was asked to do in this case. The report was commissioned at the Darwin COAG in August 1994 at the request of the states. The states wanted to know what were to be the likely revenue benefits to governments arising from the implementation of the Hilmer reforms.

PARA.TAB: Working in a tight time frame, the Industry Commission undertook a modelling exercise to estimate the revenue and broader economic benefits of competition policy and those related reforms. The Industry Commission used an outer envelope of reforms on which to base its estimates. In many cases these were reforms which were already being contemplated by governments; that is, reforms to electricity, gas and the water sectors.

The report is not a blueprint for what governments will or should ultimately do in implementing the competition policy. But the commission, as you have said, estimated the economic benefits to be about 5.5 per cent of GDP—an increase in real consumption of $9 billion and around 30,000 more jobs. That is why I answered no to the last part of your question, Senator Margetts. It is expected to generate higher employment.

There has been a lot of debate about the size of benefits estimated by the Industry Commission, but few have argued that there will not be benefits to consumers and businessmen from the competition reforms. It is the case that benefits should be gauged not just in an economic sense but in the context of government's broader policy concerns. These include the environment, social policy, health and safety et cetera. It is the legitimate role of elected governments to assess the benefits and cost of policy action in the broader context. This is not the task which the Industry Commission proceeded with.

For this reason, the competition policy agreement, signed by the Commonwealth and the states in April, includes a clear provision that any reforms be considered taking into account a range of other public interest matters—and they are ecologically sustainable development, industrial relations, community service obligations, occupational health and safety and like matters. The reforms are not about competition for the sake of competition but are placed clearly in the context of broader concerns. The figure estimated by the Industry Commission, using an outer envelope of estimates, is a 5.5 per cent increase in the level of GDP, an increase in real consumption of $9 billion, and the creation of around 30,000 extra jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister. I am very interested in his response that the Industry Commission's task was not to assess the costs and benefits. It has been suggested by Professor John Quiggan that the Industry Commission has represented the upper bounds to possible achievement, rather than the likely outcomes. Minister, why should we believe the incredible benefits? Could you please outline who in your government and your bureaucracy is able to do the cost and benefit study? I will be very pleased to know because, as I far as I know, there is no-one in the federal government who would do it. Where do the resources come from to do this full cost and benefit study? Please give the details. We would be happy to hear it.
—What the Industry Commission did is in the outer envelope of those reforms.
—On the back of an envelope?

—No, I mean the broader range of reforms. What the government has adopted is set out in the COAG agreement. These figures are Industry Commission estimates. Everyone has agreed, it seems to me, that there is significant national benefit. The exact figure might be in dispute, but it is commonly regarded as a huge windfall to the economy and an improvement in the competitiveness of the economy.

PARA.TAB: In my additional remarks, I was saying that, in looking at it from a strict economic modelling point of view, governments bring a range of other values—such as social, environmental, occupational health and industrial relations values—to that calculation. I believe that makes it a richer, if you like, and more effective reform too. I take it that you have asked a series of other questions which are quite detailed, and I will ask the Treasurer whether he is able to provide an answer on those matters. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Following Mr Keating's pre-election l-i-e not to put up taxes, how is it that in just three budgets since the March 1993 election your government has ripped off Australian consumers through sales tax?
—Order! I ask you to withdraw that.
—I am sorry—the government's l-i-e.
—No, the l-i-e!
—Get on with your question; you have rephrased it.

—May I start again? Your government has ripped off Australian consumers through sales tax, which has risen by an overwhelming 52 per cent, from $9 billion to over $14 billion, lifting consumption tax to its highest ever proportion of gross domestic product in Australia's history. It is almost 50 per cent higher than when John Howard was Treasurer and about 25 per cent higher than in the pre-election 1992-93 budget. Why is it that, while continually claiming to oppose consumption taxes, your government has hit struggling Australian families with Mr Keating's hand in their pockets to the tune of a 400 per cent increase in sales taxes? (Time expired)

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. When there is an interruption to a question, as I understand it, the questioner is allowed to have the time made up. When you interrupt me to make a point of order, is my time made up?
—Order! I only interrupt when the standing orders have been broken.

—Let me first of all deal with one of the misleading statements made by Senator Baume in what I think was admittedly a confused presentation for the reason of either interjection or misunderstanding. Nonetheless, it was a confused presentation. That misleading comment relates to the coalition's record of taxation in Australia compared with the record of the government.

PARA.TAB: Under the last coalition government when John Howard was Treasurer, in 1982-83, government revenue as a percentage of GDP was at 26.0 per cent. Under our government, it is at 25.3 per cent. In other words, the high taxing party of Australian politics is the coalition, not this government. In his speech last night, Mr Howard opened the door for the coalition to increase taxes further in direct contradiction to what Mr Costello had said publicly about three weeks earlier. The coalition's record on taxes is of the classic George Bush type: just read its lips; it is in that category.

For the rest of this question, I refer Senator Baume to an answer I gave and added to after question time yesterday. I am happy to repeat the answer. The government has complied with the undertaking given by the Prime Minister, which is not to raise the tax burden overall. We are still within those limits. The figures are here. I can give them to the Senate if Senator Baume wants them. They are on the record from yesterday.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked the minister about sales tax specifically. How come the government has hit struggling Australian families, with Mr Keating's hand being in their pockets to the tune of a 400 per cent increase in sales taxes over the 12 years that his government has been in control of the country's piggy bank? Will the minister at last come clean and admit that his government holds the title for the highest sales taxing government ever? I draw his attention to comments by Mr Willis, who said this when in opposition:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the Opposition is implacably opposed to these measures.
. . . because they represent a repudiation of a pledge . . . not to broaden the indirect tax base . . .
A move to more reliance on indirect taxation is therefore a move to a more inequitable tax system and one which we therefore strongly oppose.
How come the government totally supports this allegedly inequitable tax system? Sales tax as a proportion of gross domestic product is the highest that it has ever been in Australia's history.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me get these things again clear. Australia is one of the lowest taxed economies in the OECD. The level of taxation under us is lower than the level of taxation under the coalition. The tax system is a lot fairer under us than it ever was under the opposition. The level of tax avoidance that was rampant under the coalition is not possible under us. If I were Senator Baume, I would not delve into history. As I recall, not all that long ago, he was standing in about the same place advocating a 15 per cent GST for Australia. So let us get it clear: opposition members are the taxers; we are not.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. A letter from Senator Tierney was published in yesterday's edition of the Newcastle Herald. In his letter, Senator Tierney claimed that the only reason the minister attended the Hunter region small business rally was the actions of the opposition spokeswoman for small business and Senator Tierney. Senator Tierney further claimed that no action on a number of small business issues would be taken by the minister or the government unless pressure was applied. These surprising claims contradict the government's earlier statements as to the measures being taken, and to be taken, to support small business. Would the minister care to comment on the claims made by Senator Tierney.

—When a letter in the Newcastle Herald came to my attention yesterday—a letter written by Senator Tierney after he had attended with me and others the rally for small business in Newcastle on 19 May—I must say that I was more than somewhat astonished at his claims in that letter. They bear no relationship to what he or Mrs Moylan said at that meeting, or what I said at that meeting, or the outcomes. It was claimed that, pressured by Senator Tierney's attendance, I would attend. I made it quite clear that, once I got a firm date from the organisers, I changed my itinerary and attended, and was more than welcome to do so.
—When the Prime Minister told you to get up there; that is when you changed it.
—Order! Senator Tierney!
—After hearing Senator Tierney's performance at that rally and the performance of the shadow minister for small business, Mrs Moylan, I am surprised he wants to raise it again.
—They gave you a razz, didn't they!
—Order! Senator Tierney!
—What I found extraordinary was that—
—Tell the business people that.
—the major issue they wished to raise was shopping hours—complaining about the extension of shopping hours, which were introduced in New South Wales by the Greiner-Fahey Liberal government.
—Tell what you have done—nothing!
—Your party introduced what they were No. 1 complaining about—the extension of shopping hours.
—You have to do something now!
—No. 2, they were complaining about planning regulations that allowed new supermarkets to be built.
—And No. 3—that you are doing nothing!
—Order! Senator Tierney, I will give you one more warning and no more.

—I made it quite clear that, although I might like to have the power in both those areas, constitutionally the federal government does not. They are issues that have to be dealt with by the state government and the local council. But the one issue that I accepted responsibility for—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Schacht is referring to matters that he claims to be outside of his portfolio, being state matters, and therefore would appear to be out of order.
—I must say that that was not the way I read it, but I ask Senator Schacht to keep his comments relevant.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. It relates to standing order 73, part (h), which says that questions shall not ask `for an expression of opinion'.

PARA.TAB: Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a lot harder for me to do that than it is for you, Senator Ray. You do it every day. Senator Forshaw's question asked whether the minister would just comment about something he may or may not have read in the paper. I ask you, Mr President, to rule whether asking for basically Senator Schacht's opinion of something that appeared in that very important chronicle in Newcastle is indeed within the standing orders?
—I took it to mean that Senator Schacht was asked for his version of events and I think that is perfectly in order.

—Thank you, Mr President. The one area I indicated at the meeting that the one area where the federal government has constitutional power is under the Trade Practices Act—the corporations power. I indicated that the one area the small business people may have a concern about is the operation of the unconscionable conduct provisions of the Trade Practices Act. I indicated as early as November of last year, as a result of representations from the Small Business Forum, that we were looking at reviewing that section of the Trade Practices Act. I expect to get a report in detail from the Small Business Forum on Friday week outlining what it wants changed in those provisions of unconscionable conduct to strengthen it so that small business gets a better deal.

PARA.TAB: To my astonishment at the meeting, Mrs Moylan for the first time indicated some rough idea that the Liberal Party may be interested in supporting this. This is the first time the Liberal Party has ever expressed a view about changing the unconscionable conduct provisions of the Trade Practices Act. In view of Mr Howard's remarks last night in his speech on helping small business, I thought he might have made a comment that he supported his shadow minister on changing the Trade Practices Act. Guess what? There was not a word of support for small business in changing unconscionable conduct provisions of the Trade Practices Act—not one word.

Again, the Liberal Party is a policy-free zone on small business. It has plenty of rhetoric but no policy in detail. This is something that for the next election we will make clear to the people in small business. You have no policies. We have already started the process of changing the unconscionable conduct provisions of the Trade Practices Act. I started in November last year and there was a dead silence from those opposite when I announced that. There was not a comment of support that came up at the meeting back in May. Now, slowly, maybe some of you are jumping on the bandwagon.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, and I ask: could you please outline to the Senate what action your government is taking to eradicate age discrimination in Australia?

—This government's commitment to the protection and care of people who are over 65 is very extensive. We are very clear about our commitment to people who are aged and we are even committed to ensuring that all sorts of rights prevail for those people and that they are not discriminated against in all sorts of ways.

PARA.TAB: It is important to note the assistance we provide for people who are aged—by definition, I refer to those over 65—and talk about the way we respect their dignity to make sure that they can retire with an adequate and fair income and how we are improving that provision in any number of ways, including with our superannuation changes.

We are absolutely concerned, too, to make sure that aged people are also provided with a very adequate health system. And of course, Senator, you would know, perhaps better than many on the other side, the number of aged people in Australia who have access to all sorts of educational opportunities, particularly through the university of the third world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Third age.

—The third age. Thank you very much for that correction, I appreciate it. Those are all people who are benefiting from our government's commitment to respect the dignity of people of whatever age, including older Australians.

PARA.TAB: In terms of your specific request, which I understand may indeed go to specific anti-discrimination measures, I will take that on notice to see whether there is any particular detail that I can add. There certainly have been provisions to extend beyond 65 the age of necessary retirement. Certainly that is the case, I believe, in South Australian legislation—and I need to be clear, because this matter has been canvassed extensively in the Commonwealth. So I will take that on notice and get back the detail for you about the particular anti-discrimination provisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Today at lunchtime I actually referred to a poem in a children's book. Had that poem been about an ethnic group or about indigenous people, you would have been outraged. Where was the outrage from the government? There was none. You have not told us anything that the government is doing in legislation to eliminate discrimination against older people with regard to employment in the federal Public Service. What are you doing about age discrimination in literature, the media and in many other areas of employment? You have not answered that question. What is the government doing?

—In terms of the reference you made in the lunchtime speech, I happened to hear some of that, Senator, and I would have to say, along with you, that, if that is the sort of literature that passes without any criticism in this country, then I believe that it should meet criticism. I have not seen that book and I have not had it drawn to my attention before. I will certainly see what further information I can provide for you about that matter.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian Institute of Sport Athletics Commission

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I note that the minister has today announced the establishment of an Australian Institute of Sport athletics commission. Can the minister inform the Senate why the government has established this commission and how the commission will operate?

—I am very pleased to confirm that an AIS athletes commission has been established. This initiative has been developed over the past few months and it is something which I fully support and endorse. The athletes commission is an important step towards meeting the government's commitment to strengthen the people's side of Australian sport.

PARA.TAB: It will ensure that AIS scholarship holders have an active input into all the issues affecting their lives. It is important that our top Australian athletes who use AIS programs have a say in the way they live and the way they train. As a representative body of AIS athletes, the commission will assist with the ongoing development of AIS athlete support programs. It will consider any matters that may be of relevance to the development and welfare of athletes, and make recommendations to the Director of the AIS and the executive.

I am very pleased that Nicole Stevenson has been appointed the chair of the athletes commission. She is a national champion and a representative of Australia at two Olympic Games and three Commonwealth Games. She is also a representative on the Australian Olympic Committee athletes commission and will provide a very good link between both these bodies.

The athletes commission will be made up of a representative from each of the AIS sports, the AIS residents manager, an elite athletes services representative, a coaches representative and an Australian Sports Commission representative. Regional centres will also be represented. The athletes commission will provide a strong link between the Australian Sports Commission, the AIS and the athletes. It will build on the very good relationship that currently exists. I am sure it is an initiative that will be welcomed by all senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It relates to my question last week about which the minister apparently had no understanding. Is it the case that, as a consequence of compulsory unionism and union affiliation with the ALP, the New South Wales Labor Party's rescue package proposal, which is a one dollar levy on each of the 700,000 trade unionists of all political complexions, will effectively be subsidised by the Commonwealth government to the tune of $224,000 because of the tax deductible status of union dues? If so, why should taxpayers be forced to contribute almost a quarter of a million dollars to help foot the bill for the New South Wales Right's financial incompetence in running the affairs of the Labor Party in New South Wales?

—What is proposed, as I understand it, in New South Wales is not a levy but an increased affiliation fee. It forms part of the larger mass of the affiliation fee paid by the unions. It is a familiar feature of our tax law, and has been for years, that for any form of business or professional or industrial association which involves the advancement of its members' interests, it is permissible for the fees to be the subject of a tax deduction. In that respect, trade unions are no different from any other business or professional associations which advance the interests of their members. There are multiple contexts in which those interests are advanced.

PARA.TAB: The fact that unions choose to spend a proportion of their affiliation fees from members on affiliating with the Labor Party is a perfectly understandable and legitimate decision for them, just as similar forms of expenditure decisions are made by other businesses and professional associations. That is the tax law of this country. It was under a coalition government; and has been for as long as I or anyone else here can remember. So get off your high horse, Senator Woods.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whether you call it a levy or whether you call it an increased affiliation bill, the facts are very simple. The money will rescue the Labor Party from the mess it is in in New South Wales and it will be subsidised by the taxpayer. That is something which even you, Senator Evans, must accept as unreasonable. Would you give an undertaking, which I am sure that not only you but every reasonable minded person would support in principle—namely, that there will be no subsidy by ordinary taxpayers to pay off the New South Wales Labor Party's colossal debt?
—I have explained how the law works in this respect. I explained how it worked under your government in the past and will continue to work into the indefinite future, as far as we are concerned.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I refer him to recent reports that import penetration in the domestic car market, which has risen from only 20 per cent a few years ago to over 50 per cent now, is likely to climb to 65 per cent. Minister, in the face of this very real challenge to tens of thousands of Australian jobs, what measures is the government going to take to enable a viable future for the car industry? Given the 90 per cent deterioration to nearly $7.5 billion in Australia of the annual automotive trade deficit over the last three years, will the minister heed the call of the Federation of Automotive Products Manufacturers for an immediate freeze on further tariff reductions or, for that matter, will the government take any other measure to deal with this emergency?

—I would like to pay a compliment to Senator Spindler. He is the only spokesperson for industry on the non-government side of this parliament who takes an interest in this issue. I do not think Mr John Moore, the shadow minister for industry and commerce, has ever asked a question on this subject. Senator Spindler, you are entitled to that respect.

PARA.TAB: I should also say that, as we have had this debate for a long time, I do not agree with Senator Spindler. Let me turn to some reasons. The 20 per cent that Senator Spindler referred to in terms of import penetration occurred in 1984. Do you remember what the car industry was like in 1984? We had high levels of tariff protection, high prices for domestic consumers, too many models on the road, very poor quality, and no exports.

What do we have now? We have a lean, mean and a very competitive car industry. The level of imports is in the luxury car area and in the small car area; areas in which we do not make cars any more in Australia. But the family sedan that we do make in Australia beats the best that the world can throw at us. We hold our market share in terms of Australian production. It is a high quality car, cheaper in price, more efficiently produced, and claiming massive export dollars for Australia.

Riding along with it is the component parts industry. This industry is also going gang busters, to use a phrase that has gained some notoriety regarding manufacturing exporters. It picks up the statistics in a colourful way. But component car part manufacturing exports are going gang busters.

That would not have occurred had not the Button car plan been introduced and had we not phased down tariff protection in this country at a speed at which the industry is gradually exposed to international competition and becomes more internationally competitive itself. This has produced massive changes in the industry. In the old days the industry resisted some of these changes but it now sees how useful and important they were in making this a world competitive industry.

The figure of 50 per cent that Senator Spindler mentioned is the April 1995 figure. I understand that the actual figure was 50.22 per cent. That was a time at which a number of component parts manufacturers in Australia had industrial relations problems and there was an interruption of supply of componentry to the major big four. As a consequence, we produced less that month than we would otherwise have done.
The date Senator Spindler has used is a date that does not reflect the true competitiveness of the industry. I do not accept the proposition that it will go to 65 per cent.

What are we doing about all this? We have been working very closely with the big four car manufacturers who are, I might add, the major importers of small cars in this country and who have benefited under the import credit scheme, thus becoming more effective exporters. We are working with the manufacturers to improve the industrial relations environment, to reduce costs at each stage of micro-economic reform, and to ensure that they become increasingly competitive.

We have signalled that we will examine the tariff regime beyond the year 2000. We will commence an examination of that next year so that the report can be undertaken and completed to give the car manufacturers of Australia a vision into the next century in terms of tariff levels. Importantly, under APEC, we are setting about opening up markets in this region which will allow the comparative advantage that Australian car manufacturers enjoy to penetrate more widely throughout this region.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the minister, I appreciate the export efforts of the car industry but, with a deficit of $7.5 billion, we are not doing too well. The truth is that exports are not rising as fast as imports. If the minister wished to look at the immediate future, he would see that Korea is likely to double its production by another three million vehicles of the kind that are now penetrating our market. I think a tariff review 12 months hence is really not the answer. Minister, what are you doing specifically right now?

—I have said we are working very closely with the car industry in order to help it improve its competitiveness. Next month I am leading a delegation of automotive component-part manufacturers to Indonesia, Korea and Japan in order to encourage them to achieve a greater share of the automotive componentry in those markets, which are important markets.

PARA.TAB: We have internationalised the economy, so flows are both ways. If we had left the tariff wall intact, the old poor quality, high-priced, inefficient Australian vehicle would have been overwhelmed and we would have no car industry now. What we have now, as I have said, is a lean, mean and competitive industry. The export levels that we have seen attained by this industry at this stage are—I think it is a fair comment—at the early stage of achievement. There is a lot more yet to be won on the export side of this market by our more competitive manufacturing base.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to a speech you gave on human rights policy in July last year. In conclusion, you said, `Double standards are not part of Australia's foreign policy repertoire and never will be under this government.' How can you travel the world, Minister, and trumpet the values of a free press, when at home you are proposing to gaol journalists who might publicly report unethical or illegal conduct of the government? Is this a case of a double standard?

—Every country is entitled to take appropriate measures to protect its own security and intelligence service and operations. I would have thought that Senator MacGibbon, among all those in this place, would have a better understanding and more interest in that particular issue than most people. The truth of the matter is that the only likely, really effective, way of protecting those services and those operations is through preventive strategies, through having the kinds of management structures and processes in place that you do not create the kind of disgruntlement which leads to people breaching their obligations of confidentiality in the first place.

PARA.TAB: It is also the case that so far as the media is concerned, where the most damaging publications and releases of information occur, it is wholly desirable to overwhelmingly place the emphasis on preventive strategies of one kind or another. The D-Notices were designed to do that. There has also been a tradition of reliance on the good faith and commitment of the media to this country's national interests and their willingness to understand the issues involved and to respond accordingly when approached by the government, as they were—although this has not been clearly acknowledged by them—in the context of the recent purported disclosures about recent events.

In the event that those preventive strategies fail, it is necessary for governments to have some additional weapons available to make clear the extent of the problems that are caused, the damage that is caused, to the national interest if disclosures of that kind take place. It is in that context and with the active agreement, cooperation and support of the opposition—through its foreign shadow spokesman, Alexander Downer, who agreed to every line of the proposals that I read out in the chamber in this respect—that we floated the possibility of some remedial legislation of that kind, going in some respects into a little different territory from that which had been occupied before, but in other respects not really advancing the process at all.

In the past, of course—although this has again been lost in this great flurry of media debate—under the Crimes Act, sections 70 and 79, the disclosure of secret information was penalisable so far as the first instance disclosures are concerned. Under section 5—provisions relating to accomplices, those who aid, abet or somehow pursue that disclosure in other forums—that was punishable equally as with the primary offence. So there is nothing new in the law in this respect.

What is lacking in the law as it stands at the moment, in sections 70 and 79 of the Crimes Act, is specificity in relation to those offences which are too broadly defined and in many ways overreaching in their impact. What we were floating, what Mr Downer was supporting me explicitly in floating—and if he has been left high and dry by his leader in this respect that is his and the opposition's problem; it was a matter of me acting in good faith—was a situation where there would in fact be a number of restrictions built in; namely, a requirement to prove damage in all cases which the Samuels inquiry had not recommended, plus the specific defences which had not previously been available in the criminal law of a public interest kind, namely, that proof of illegality was established in relation to the acts in question that would constitute a legitimate ground for defence against any such prosecution.

So there was a careful balancing of all the issues that evolved in this. That was only a matter of proposed general principle. Obviously a lot does depend on the detail with which these matters are spelled out in the legislative drafting, and that will be a matter for further and full debate no doubt in this parliament. On that basis, Mr President, I ask—

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the minister's entry to the parliament as a great civil libertarian and bearing in mind that T.J. Ryan memorial lecture of 1982—which I read this week with great interest—in which he promulgated the case for civil liberties, I would have thought there would have been more effort put into modifying or amending the Crimes Act and taking alternative strategies before resorting to the draconian penalties which he has promulgated.

—For Senator MacGibbon to flaunt civil liberties standards is one of the grossest feats of hypocrisy I have heard of in this place. You have a conspicuous record as one of the most extremely insensitive characters in the place so far as these issues are concerned, and I would like you to get up and demonstrate otherwise. So far as—
—Could I take a point of order, Mr President? Sadly, you have to be reminded again and again to open your ears and listen to the sorts of things—
—You called somebody a big dork before.
—You have to be reminded to close your mouth.

—Some people are big dorks. Senator Evans has just accused Senator MacGibbon basically of one of the greatest feats of hypocrisy. If I am not allowed to call these people liars, why should they be able to call Senator MacGibbon in effect a hypocrite and you pretend you did not hear?
—I did not pretend I did not hear. It is not flouting standing orders as standing orders stand or as precedents dictate. But it is not helpful either, Senator Evans, I must say.
—I find it personally offensive.

—Diddums widdums, that is all I can say about that, because I was asked a question in those terms which was premised on exactly the same assumptions that I have thrown back in your hypocritical face—and cop it.
—Withdraw that, Senator.
—Withdraw?
—Yes.
—I withdraw.
—Mr President, just for your edification, there have been six or seven occasions when Labor presidents have ruled `hypocritical' out of order, so I am at a loss—
—There are nine!
—I have just ruled it out of order.

—I realise that, but I am offering you a bit of assistance because originally you said to me that it was not out of order. It is only when you realised, when you were getting a bit of a push, that you did the job.

—Let me simply explain that that is not what you raised in the first place. I have ruled `hypocritical' out of order several times myself, and I have ruled it out of order again. Senator Evans has withdrawn.

—Very statesmanlike of you, if I may say so, Mr President. Might I just say, as I began by saying in opening my answer to you, that of course prevention is infinitely better than after the event. With remedial measures or deterrent measures of this kind, it is infinitely better to go down that particular path. Overwhelmingly our focus will be on that, and I hope it will be possible to inculcate some kind of sense of responsibility among those who flap their gums on these issues but do not act in a way that is helpful and responsible when we are looking at larger questions of national interest of a kind that I thought you of all people would be inclined to be pursuing rather than undercutting.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Senator Woodley asked me a question without notice on 1 June concerning the tendering for welfare services. Senator Woodley drew attention to the speech of the Deputy Prime Minister on Monday 29 May. I undertook to refer the question to the Deputy Prime Minister, and I have since been able to obtain the following information.

PARA.TAB: In talking to the National Anglican Caring Organisation Network, the Deputy Prime Minister observed that there has been an increasing emphasis on tendering out community services by the Commonwealth, state and local governments. The Deputy Prime Minister reflected that it is extremely important that church organisations should seek to maintain the standards that they have set in service delivery when tendering for services.

The minister also indicated that the churches have to ensure that the quality of services is maintained in the contracted process. He also urged the churches to remain strong leaders in identifying new forms of service delivery in response to emerging needs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Baume this day, relating to taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: I specifically asked Senator Cook, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, whether he would at least come clean and admit that his government holds the title as the highest sales taxing government in Australia's history. The facts, which I outlined, clearly indicate that is so.

PARA.TAB: According to the statistics section of the Parliamentary Library, sales tax collections from the latest budget will represent the biggest proportion of gross domestic product in our history. Not only that: those collections from sales tax are about 50 per cent higher as a proportion of gross domestic product than when the coalition was last in government and have increased by about 25 per cent since the pre-1993 election budget.

The Labor government went into that election attacking not just the specifics but the whole concept of a consumption tax. It said, `We are opposed to consumption taxes. Consumption taxes are dreadful. They hit the low income earners.' And it went on with a whole lot of other rhetoric. That rhetoric was uncomplicatedly dishonest—it was crooked. Since that time this government has imposed the biggest ever rises in the consumption tax it calls a sales tax.

It is not just a question of whether this government is credible. We know it is not credible. There is no doubt about it: the government was elected on a basic lie. But what is disturbing is that when you confront someone like Senator Cook, the Minister representing the Treasurer, with the fact of a 52 per cent increase in sales tax since the last election, when you confront him with the fact that that represents $5 billion extra being ripped off consumers by a party which opposed a consumption tax, you get no credible answer. In fact, you get a total whitewash, a pretence that this has not happened.

We heard Senator Cook say, `You wanted to introduce a GST.' We now know what the secret government GST is—sales tax. Sales tax is the government's secret, hidden, sneaky, dishonest GST. It has raised an extra $5 billion since the last election campaign. And what is the government taxing? This government's sneaky, hidden sales tax is on soft drinks, biscuits, snack foods, ice cream, refrigerators, washing machines, toilet paper, wine, motor vehicles, furniture, toothbrushes, soaps, detergents, CDs, radios, record players and computers.

Are they the sorts of things that consumers do not buy? Not on your life: they are the very things that the battlers have to buy. They are things that are basic to an Australian standard of living. But they are the things that this government is taxing, taxing, taxing. And this sales tax—this hidden, sneaky government version of a GST, the one it did not tell us about at the election—is to be increased further on 1 July.

We have a clear situation where the government is blatantly dishonest. But it has been like that for years. The Treasurer, Mr Willis, who introduced these latest sales tax rises, said when he was in opposition that he was `implacably opposed to these measures because they represent a repudiation of a pledge not to broaden the indirect tax base.' It is amazing how you change your views when you go into government and become Treasurer! You then have no principles at all, as has been demonstrated by Mr Willis. When opposing sales tax rises, Mr Willis said:

SPEECH.PARA: This move to more reliance on indirect taxation is therefore a move to a more inequitable tax system and one which we therefore strongly oppose.
The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) said this:
It is a cynical Government which uses taxation by stealth (sales tax) to ensure that people have as little opportunity as possible to protest against its policies.
Former minister Bob Brown said:
Sales taxes are the most inequitable, the most unjust and the most discriminatory against low income earners of any type of taxation which can be devised.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Schacht), to a question without notice asked by Senator Colston this day, relating to resources devoted to activities of the Australian Customs Service in Torres Strait.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the greatest tragedies facing our society is the horrendous drug trade. It is an area of the criminal law over which the Commonwealth has direct responsibility. It is a very serious issue. That is why I am absolutely appalled at the very light note that Senator Schacht made of this very tragic issue in his answer at question time today and in the way that he has dealt with my complaints previously.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht makes light of my concern, says that I talk about people in red hats and that I should be able to identify people who are bringing drugs into our country through the Torres Strait from New Guinea. It seems to Senator Schacht and every one in the Labor government that, if you are out of sight, you are out of mind. If it does not happen in Canberra, Brisbane, Sydney or Melbourne, they do not care about it. The Torres Strait, in case Senator Schacht does not know, is part of Australia. People up there are entitled to the same protection from this horrendous, tragic trade as are other Australians. Yet Senator Schacht says, `We have plenty of people up there looking after it.' They have eight customs officers out of almost 4,000 customs officers in Australia. I do not think—and neither do the people of Torres Strait—that eight officers out of 4,000 is adequate protection.

I would not expect Senator Schacht to take any notice of what anyone on this side says because he is an old Labor Party hack. He is in here for the politics; he is not concerned with running the country properly. But I ask him to take some notice, as I pleaded with him at estimates committees, of local community leaders in the Torres Strait. Island community leaders are appalled and are in fear of their lives over the drug trade. Senator Schacht may say that he has attended a conference in Brisbane and that there is no evidence of it, but I ask him to listen to what the island leaders say in the Torres Strait. As quoted on page 1 of the Cairns Post on 13 May 1995, Mr Wais, the head of the Saibai Island community and the acting chairman of the Island Coordinating Council, said it was crucial that Islanders and the government do something about this horrendous trade. Mr Wais said:
You have to understand. It is life-threatening to councillors and community people trying to put a stop to this because those involved will do anything to stop their identities leaking out . . . .
The Torres Strait is a very small place and, to play it safe, we need to join forces and establish who is doing this dirty stuff. I'm afraid someone is going to get killed . . .

SPEECH.PARA: This island leader and Mr George Mye, a very respected community leader from Darnley Island, have pleaded with the government to set up some checking stations. The article continues:

PARA.TAB: He also said checking stations should be established on each of the islands closest to PNG so dinghies carrying traditional visitors could be cleared of drugs and other health and quarantine goods before proceeding any further.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems that Senator Schacht is not concerned about this. It would almost seem that the Labor Party is soft when it comes to drugs and the importation of drugs. This is a very serious matter and one which needs more than Senator Schacht's dismissive and almost comical comments on the particular problem.

PARA.TAB: There are people in the area who know what is happening. Anyone up there who has been around understands that there is illicit trade coming through. But the people themselves are concerned to do anything about it because they fear for their lives. We do need a greater Commonwealth presence there, whether it be from the Federal Police or more customs officers, but something does need to be done. There was the incident where over 60 kilograms came in by plane and Senator Schacht said it was not a problem. (Time expired).
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to questions without notice asked by Senators Short and Baume this day, relating to taxation measures in the 1994-95 Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the chamber of the question asked by Senator Short. He asked: could the minister inform the people of Australia what higher and new taxes will come into effect on 1 July 1995 and how much extra tax revenue the people of Australia will be paying next year as a direct result? In his answer to Senator Short, in his typical fashion, Senator Cook said, `I am not your researcher; you go and research it for yourself.' He replied in this way instead of addressing the question, coming clean with the Australian people and letting them know precisely what the government has done in relation to taxation this year as a result of the impact of this budget and impacts that it put in place in previous budgets, going back to the Dawkins budget.

PARA.TAB: I have done the research; so I thought I might help out Senator Cook and give some answers relating to the amount of tax that has been increased. It is quite staggering, as Senator Short noted in his supplementary question. There is an additional $14 billion worth of tax being taken this financial year. When we add to that the company tax, that goes up to $17 billion. It is very instructive to look at the budget papers. We find with customs there is another $110 million. There is almost $1 billion—$952,284 million—of extra excise. Most of that is from fuel. Most of the tax is on the tyranny of distance and very little of it—in fact, 2.4 per cent of the 7.7 per cent—goes back into road funding. It is no wonder that the roads in rural and regional Australia and many of our city highways are in serious need of additional money and additional work because of the misuse of the fuel excise.

Sales tax brings in another $2.58 billion. The real killer of this budget and the measures which have been put in place by this government is the PAYE tax. We find that the tax take this financial year increased by $6.1 billion. Almost 40 per cent of the total increase of taxation comes out of the pockets of PAYE taxpayers. Yet this government and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) have the audacity to stand up here and say that they have not increased taxes. The increased tax take is one of the largest increases in one budget in the history of this nation. In round figures it went from $103 billion to $117 billion. In relation to other individuals, the figure is $1.3 billion; the increase in company tax is $2.9 billion; dividend interest and withholding taxes is $90 million; prescribed payments is $160 million; superannuation is $250 million; resource rent tax is $70 million; and fringe benefits tax is $120 million.

Of course, tied up in all of this is the impact of what has occurred by way of sales tax increases. I refer to the additional increases on everyday requirements to do with housing—bathroom, kitchen and laundry items. We heard a little about that yesterday. The impact will be up to $2,000 or thereabouts per house. An average family with two or three children is looking at an increase of well over $1,000 in the cost of a new house.

As we go through these items and note the lack of response by Senator Cook and the government to these points, it is worth pointing out to the Australian public that this is one of the great taxing budgets of all time. On top of that we find that the government has only addressed the fiscal deficit by $3 billion. The rest of it is a con in terms of asset sales. As most people in this place would know, I am a farmer. If you start selling the assets needed to run your farm, you soon go out of business. It does not work. If you lease your family car, you suddenly find out that you do not have a motor car. As we look at everything that has been done in this budget we find that it is very irresponsible in terms of how one runs a business. As far as the fiscal operations of this country are concerned, it is about time this government looked at running Australia as a business. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
