TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), to a question without notice asked by Senator Forshaw this day, relating to small business in Newcastle.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I start I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the letter that was referred to in the question.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Small Business Showed Muscle
From John Tierney

PARA.TAB: I refer to the recent Hunter Region small business rally that expressed the hurt and concern felt by independent shop owners in regard to the extended shopping hours and unfair trade practices by larger chain stores. I believe this was a constructive example of the political process in Australia designed to make governments sit up and take notice.

Small business proprietors of fruit shops, butcheries, bakeries, bottle shops, delicatessens and chemists rallied in force to explain to the Federal Minister for Small Business, Senator Schacht, that the viability of their businesses was being destroyed while governments watched.
Senator Schacht's decision to attend the Newcastle meeting was a welcome change of heart from his initial letter of disinterest in regard to the problems of Hunter small businesses.
The action of the Liberal Party in immediately sending the Small Business spokeswoman, Ms Judi Moylan, to the meeting `flushed out' Senator Schacht.

I believe that but for Opposition pressure Senator Schacht would not have been within 500 km of the Hunter rally, where he was able to listen to reasons for the small business crisis that is unfolding.
The pressure to have Senator Schacht act on trade practices reform will, I believe, stall unless the Small Business Action Committee formed puts pressure on both the NSW and Federal governments.

I welcome the invitation to actively serve on this action committee to organise more delegations to Canberra and NSW Ministers in Sydney, so the position of small business in the Hunter can be addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator John Tierney
King St
Newcastle

This ongoing saga again highlights the plight of small business in Australia. I am quite delighted that Senator Forshaw asked that question of Senator Schacht because it gives me an opportunity yet again to highlight this particular plight.

PARA.TAB: We have in the Hunter Valley at this time one small business going broke every day. The sorts of businesses that are affected are small family businesses, often employing only two or three people. These jobs are really the backbone of our economy—48 per cent of employment in our country comes from the small business sector. I refer to this federal government's lack of action and the fact that Senator Schacht got up yet again today, washing his hands like Pontius Pilate and saying, `Well, it's not really my affair. I can't really fix it at the federal level. It's really a state and local government matter.' He is right; it is a state and local government matter. But where he is wrong is that it is very much a federal government matter. The federal government has the capacity to use powers that it has and it has a capacity through legislation to increase the powers that it has but it chooses not to do that. That is what is at the centre of this debate that is going on in the Senate.

This minister was so lacking in concern at a federal level, claiming it was not his responsibility, that he initially sent a letter back to these small business people when they wanted to talk to him which was extremely offhand, totally dismissive, saying, `Well folks, that's the marketplace. You've just got to live with it.' Or to quote his master, `Well, this is as good as it gets. If you can't hack it in the marketplace you should go back and get a PAYE job.' What an attitude.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like David Jones.

—Of course, he had a job, as has been pointed out by Senator Abetz. He had a job at David Jones but got the sack. He could not hack it in small business. He must have been remembering that, having regard to his vengeance on small business at the moment, and not wanting to do anything about assisting these people.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht was not going to come to the rally either after writing that dismissive letter. Today he gets up and claims that he went there. Let me tell you that, two days before the rally, he was not going. I was talking to the organisers and he was not coming. Suddenly, when our small business spokesperson flew from the other side of Australia to go, he was there. The reason was that the Prime Minister told him to get himself up there.

What a reception he got! It was a very cool reception. Judi Moylan made an excellent speech. When we spoke, we got quite a lot of cheers and claps. When Senator Schacht got up, he was greeted with a stony silence. The reason for that is that small business people know what the problem is; they know where the problem lies. It lies at the federal level. It is very easy to get assistance at the local government level. If you put the right pressure on, you can get the zonings changed. As the lord mayor pointed out, the small business people did not put on enough pressure in the suburb of Mayfield where a new supermarket has started. They have learnt that lesson. That will happen in future.

Sure, action can be taken at the state government level, and you do not need a change of legislation to fix it—it is already in the legislation. Any local government area can apply to the state government for a variation of trading laws for their area if they are harming small business. This certainly was the case in Tamworth, and it could be the case in Newcastle.

The real problem is at the federal level where this minister is not acting sufficiently. He keeps getting up here and telling us that he has got his committee looking at it; they are looking at some cases; and maybe they will be able to do something after they report. There is one small business a day going broke in the Hunter, Senator Schacht. How long can they afford to wait for you to come up with some answer? It needs action at the federal level urgently—now. You have the power. You just refuse to act upon it because, basically, you do not care about small business in the Hunter or anywhere else.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Woods this day, relating to a charge levied against trade union fees.

SPEECH.PARA: The question asked by Senator Woods was a very proper and reasonable question. It is to be noted that it was the second occasion on which Senator Woods asked this question. On the first occasion Senator Gareth Evans undoubtedly embarrassed himself and his government because he did not understand the import of the question, the basis of the question, what it actually meant. I think that today he did understand the question, and that is why he tried to obfuscate and not provide a real answer.

PARA.TAB: The situation—indeed, it follows on from what Senator Tierney has been saying—is caused by the Labor Party's incapacity to do anything right in the area of business. The Australian Labor Party in the state of New South Wales tried to go into business by running a building enterprise in Sussex Street under the great, luminary leadership of the now departed Senator Loosley. That business venture, in the same way the government has run Australia, has run into millions of dollars of debt; in Australia's case, it is billions of dollars of debt. So how does the Australian Labor Party overcome the debt problem?

TALK.START.PARA: —Get the taxpayers to pay.

—Absolutely! Get the taxpayers to pay for it. What better way to do it than to rely on compulsory trade union memberships, levy the members and then give them a tax deduction? Trade union membership is tax deductible. In effect, you can then launder money out of the trade union movement for the benefit of the Australian Labor Party at the expense of the taxpayer. If we on this side of the Senate ran a business deal like that and then sought to levy our members, we would not get tax deductibility for a building fund. We would get tax deductibility of up to $100 of a membership fee. But the vast majority of trade union membership fees are in excess of $100. So the tax advantages available to the Australian Labor Party are not available to the Liberal Party.

PARA.TAB: It is noteworthy that this system exists unfairly with the support of the minister at the table, who basically said, `Them's the rules and that's the way we're going to play the game.' The real point being made by Senator Woods is that the system is unfair. It does not treat everybody equally. Therefore, it ought to be changed. It never engages the mind of the Labor government if the rules are unfair but happen to work to its political benefit.

This sort of rort follows on the heels of the discussion we had yesterday, where Senator McMullan would not provide an answer to questions concerning the National Media Liaison Service that have been on notice for five weeks. Once again, the Australian Labor Party gets a $1.5 million free kick for its propaganda unit against all the other parties in this chamber.

It also follows on the heels of the excessive funding given by this government to organisations such as the Trade Union Training Authority and the union movement in a whole lot of other guises. There has been funding for in-house artists and poets in trade unions. All sorts of funding goes to the trade union movement by this government, which knows full well that the money then gets channelled out of the union movement into Australian Labor Party coffers.

On the second occasion, he obfuscated. The people of Australia deserve an answer. The simple fact is that the treatment Senator Woods has been given on this matter is typical of this tired and arrogant government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard the answers of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) on both occasions. He answered absolutely correctly and in accordance with the reality. Senator Abetz admits that he did. Senator Abetz and Senator Woods are not complaining that this is not in accordance with a law that has been passed by this parliament, where this government does not enjoy a majority. As was made clear this morning, the government cannot gets its legislative program through. That is the sort of parliament we are dealing with. The law that Senator Abetz is complaining about is a law that has been passed by this parliament. He makes it clear by saying that he wants it changed.

PARA.TAB: If he wants it changed, a proposition should be put up. No proposition has been put forward by the opposition that this law ought to be changed. As I say, the government does not have a majority in this chamber. If people are disturbed in the way that Senator Abetz and Senator Woods say that they are—I accept that that is true—why have they not put forward a proposition to change it? Why do they wait instead to put an interpretation or spin on it that favours their political position? There is no condemnation in that; this is a political chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which Evans are you talking about?

—Senator Gareth Evans. Those opposite would admit that, underneath it all, they all respect him. For example, Senator Herron is a man who, during debate, looks with wonder and almost adoration at Senator Evans. Senator Abetz and Senator Macdonald also do, and so they should.
—Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Is Senator Cooney allowed to insult members on this side by saying that we look with wonder at Senator Evans's speeches?
—It is a matter of judgment as to whether it is an insult.

—Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I feel that that remark defames me. It is obvious defamation.

I want to make it clear on broadcast day that the objections that have been brought forward as to what the unions have done and as to what the government has done are brought forward by people who have made no attempt to change the law and who admit that everything that has been done in this respect has been done in accordance with the law.

—I cannot let those remarks go, of course, because the remarks made by Senator Cooney are completely wrong. The first time the question was asked about taxpayer funding of the ALP debt in New South Wales, the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) had no idea what was being discussed. I seem to remember that he started talking about the state government, which has nothing to do with the issue whatsoever. He was floundering and completely lost.
