INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Troeth proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: Labor's neglect of Australian families, demonstrated by falling living standards, high unemployment, family breakdown and associated social costs.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is the first time I have had the opportunity of greeting you, Madam Deputy President, in your new position and I would like to take the opportunity to formally congratulate you.

PARA.TAB: Today's debate brings into question the living standards of families as they have been affected by the present Labor government. I ask honourable senators to think back to the position of families in 1983. While we should always look forward rather than backwards, I think a consideration of families in that year would provide a very different picture of their position as compared to today. Before I am accused by government senators of taking a rosy backward glance, I want to be the first to admit that there would have been a degree of unemployment in 1983 but, by comparison, youth homelessness would have been a very rare phenomenon and families looked out on a far more secure and settled life than they do today.

What are the features of the social dislocation which has occurred under this Labor government? For a start, more Australians than ever before are dependent on government benefits for their income and survival. Between 1983 and 1993 an additional 666,000 people collected the age pension, unemployment benefits, the disability pension or the sole parent pension. The disparity between rich and poor has widened dramatically and it is getting far more difficult for those at the lower end of the socioeconomic scale to even think of attaining levels of income or wealth that were feasible 20 years ago.

In an egalitarian society everyone should be able to aspire to a job that pays them a decent income and those who want to work should be able to work. Under the Labor government this has been taken away. The present government has had the audacity to print copies of a piece entitled `Agenda for families' which came out with this year's budget. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The greatest help a government can give to families is a strong economy . . . Nothing helps families more than employment and . . . decent wages and the opportunity for . . . advancement.

In Australia in November 1983 real total average weekly earnings in today's prices were $545 compared to $543 in February this year. After 12 years of Labor government, real average wages have fallen under a government that pretends to look after the working man.

PARA.TAB: Again, comparing net incomes in Australia to those in America, the wages of a builder's labourer are 99 per cent higher in Los Angeles than they are in Sydney. The hypocrisy of this government to assert the importance of a strong economy! Household debt was 42 per cent of disposable income in 1983 and it is currently 66 per cent of household disposable income.

On any indicator, indeed, moving from the macro-economic indicator of foreign debt or the current account deficit to the micro-economic indicator of household savings, this government has wasted its opportunities. Households have accumulated as much debt in the last five years as they did in the previous 10 years. Again, there is no incentive for families to save and savings are taxed at every turn.

Even more, actions taken by the government in this year's budget forcing families to fork out yet more in taxes will create greater hardship for the average Australian family. The tax take in this year's budget increased 9.3 per cent in real terms and individual tax will have increased by 136.8 per cent since 1983.

Families are going to pay more for cars. They are going to pay more for sales tax. They are going to pay more for cigarettes. They are going to pay more for the building materials that they use to try to build their new home. And the 12 per cent sales tax that has been imposed on building materials will add something like $2,500 to the cost of a new home. So much for the great Australian dream.

Again, the pharmaceutical benefits scheme general safety net widened from $407 to $600—an incredible anti-family measure. According to the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling, this budget in its entirety will result in 13 per cent of families being worse off by an average of $7.60 per week.

In his usual generous way the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) would probably tell you that $7.60 will make no real difference to a family. Let me tell you that a family which budgets dollar for dollar on its average or usual family weekly income needs every dollar it can get. And any lessening of that actual dollar amount will mean that they have to look at where they can save the money.

Again, child care is another area where the government has made extravagant promises and failed to come through. And, again in this budget, we have seen cuts to family day care and an increase in the minimum eligibility for fee relief. Families in which one parent is at home caring for children will be hurt by having their formal care cut to 12 hours per week.

This budget has done nothing for equity or accessibility to child care. Talking about inequality and inaccessibility leads me to refer to a recent EPAC report, Income distribution in Australia: recent trends in research. This shows that the real earnings of Australian workers at the bottom of the income distribution ladder are now also at a lower level than they were under Malcolm Fraser's prime ministership, and the gap between those workers and those at the top end of income distribution has widened by almost 20 per cent under Labor and by 10 per cent in the past four years.

Inequality, high levels of unemployment and low incomes have associated social costs which are reflected in huge health costs. Again, we have increasing levels of youth suicide as well as the actual wellbeing of people. It is a dramatic indictment of an Australian society where youth has no more hope than to take a decision to end one's own life.

Again, area by area from a geographic point of view, no more equality has been achieved. I would like to refer to some of the employment statistics in my own area of Victoria. For instance, teenage unemployment in Victorian areas runs at something like 51.9 per cent in north-western Melbourne and 70.8 per cent in inner Melbourne. And, to give you an idea of the extent of the problem in rural areas, the Loddon-Campaspe-Mallee areas have a teenage unemployment rate of 44.1 per cent and the Barwon-western areas which run from Geelong to the South Australian border—my own area—have a teenage unemployment rate of 39.3 per cent.

Senator Gareth Evans, in his response to my question on 31 May, talked about absolutely spectacular jobs growth and the down trending of the unemployment rate. I would like him to talk to those 70.8 per cent of unemployed inner Melbourne teenagers about this spectacular jobs growth to see what their response is. What are some of the reasons for this very high unemployment level? One reason would certainly be this government's draconian industrial relations legislation. The ability of employers to take on staff is constrained by unfair dismissal laws which make it extraordinarily difficulty for employers to lay off unsatisfactory staff. This results in a reluctance to take on new staff. There is 30 per cent to 50 per cent more in on-costs associated with employing staff, plus the amount of regulatory paper work required. Why would anyone want to take on new staff? Unfortunately, this impacts on families whose members are put out of work or retrenched. There are other impacts that we are discussing.

Choice has narrowed considerably over the last 12 years for Australian families. They are forced to operate within a much more constrained set of choices for jobs, family arrangements, hours of employment and conditions of employment. There has never been more money spent in Australia on social problems than there is today. I am sure that senators opposite will tell us about program after program invented by the government. But all the problems I have mentioned are growing, not diminishing, which is why the coalition believes that Labor has neglected Australian families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the following matter of public importance:

PARA.TAB: Labor's neglect of Australian families, demonstrated by falling living standards, high unemployment, family breakdown and associated social costs.

SPEECH.PARA: Just about every one of those points is false and misleading. To suggest that this government has ignored Australian families is to completely misrepresent what we did in the International Year of the Family and the Australian families document. The document details huge benefits and increases of payments. Senator Troeth, you want to ask the young unemployed people somewhere in Melbourne—

TALK.START.PARA: —Broadmeadows.
—Yes, and see whether they are happy with the employment rate.
—They're not.

—Of course, they're not; and that is why this government is committed to providing assistance for them. We have not completed that task yet, but not because we lack the commitment to continue to do it. You come with me, Senator, and say to all those women who, after February next year, are about to get the maternity benefit of $816, `This government doesn't care about you.' They will say to you, `Rhubarb. We are very pleased with what the government has done for families. We are very pleased that it has an agenda.' We have a government agenda, coming out of the budget, committing us to the family in a way that is more coherent and brings together all the things that we have been doing for families since we got elected.

PARA.TAB: One of the things we have done for families is establish Medicare. So successful is it that we now have your endorsement of it. Families in Australia really welcome it. Two million people were uninsured before we came into office. Now everyone is covered by Medicare. None of them have to worry about whether they can afford the bills when they go to the doctor. Is that family friendly? Of course, it is. Who did it? It was this Labor government; because we care about families.

We also have provided a massive increase in funding for education for the sons and daughters of Australian families. About 37 per cent continued to year 12 when we came to office but it is around 80 per cent now, higher in some places. That is what we have done in education. When students have completed year 12 at school, most—and a significantly increasing number—of those students now have the opportunity of tertiary places at universities, TAFE colleges and other institutions of post-secondary learning. Thousands of youngsters are taking up those opportunities because they appreciate that the way to best have an opportunity in this new society—dramatically changed by a federal Labor government—is to exercise their opportunity for education so they can best participate in it.

It is time for these educational opportunities to be picked up by youngsters and people of all ages in Australia. We have seen a huge change in education flexibility brought about by this government. Families love it on behalf of their children.
Senator Troeth also suggests that we have falling living standards. Let me refer to an excellent article by Deborah Hope in The Weekend Australian of 3 June 1995. The article reads:

SPEECH.PARA: According to Travers and Richardson, the living standards of the present have never been equalled in Australia. `This is true whether we look at real purchasing power per person . . . at standards of housing and extent of education, at the quality of medicine, the extent of support of people who have few resources of their own and at equality of opportunity'. Our social security benefits are well above the OECD average. Since the thirties, home ownership has grown from 55 to 73 per cent, and Australia has one of the highest life expectancy rates in the world. From the prosperous early seventies, real GDP per head has risen by 50 per cent, and Australia is ranked seventh on the United Nations human development index for industrial countries on literacy, longevity and per capita GDP.

It just depends on which piece of paper Senator Troeth wants to produce to convince Australians of her doom and gloom measure. After all, why on earth would people otherwise think of Mr Howard? He has nothing to offer at all. This government has something to offer and has made things so much better for families.

PARA.TAB: Senator Troeth mentions family breakdown and the terrible social cost of all these things that are going on in our society. The International Year of the Family gave us some hard data instead of Senator Troeth's myths about the family. What do we find? The family is not in crisis; the family is not finished; the family is not at risk of extinction; it is here to stay. Over 91 per cent of people think that the family is the most important thing in their lives. People are very pleased with the support they receive from their families. In return, they want to go on providing support for their families.

About four million family households—86 per cent of the total—are couple families: 92 per cent of these are a registered marriage; and 50 per cent of all marriages last around 30 years, or until one partner dies. Ninety five per cent of couples with children are married. Within five years of the previous marriage ending, 69 per cent of men and 65 per cent of women have remarried. That is another set of myths that needs to be set aside.

We find that 79 per cent of children live with both their natural parents until the children are in their twenties; six per cent live in a blended two parent family; 15 per cent live in a sole parent family. Only three per cent of sole parent families have teenagers, and six per cent of sole parent families are headed by men. I hope Senator Troeth will ring her colleague in South Australia, Mr Rossi, and remind him of these facts about families.

For all that it has been challenged and is undergoing change, the family is doing very well. The family has been assisted very dramatically by this government through its commitment to families. We have the specific family agenda that brings together a number of items that were previously separated. People might not have put health and education together as one package for families. I certainly do.

The family agenda certainly increases that commitment when we consider the great maternity benefit and increased child-care arrangements, about which Senator Troeth was very disparaging. Senator Troeth could list only a few negatives that she saw in the child-care area. We have had a dramatic increase in child-care places and a dramatic increase in family day care opportunities. A huge number of people, particularly women, are either participating in the work force, studying or training.

This government gave us educational opportunities and child care which allowed people to take advantage of these things. We have gone from 46,000 places to over 260,000 places in child care, and all of those are very affordable because of the child-care allowance and the child-care cash rebate. I understand that those opposite, in a moment of weakness, said that they will make accreditation voluntary and do away with the requirement of quality in child care. All the assurance we have been able to give parents will be undone by Mr Howard.

I would like to finish by picking up on a point that you made, Senator Troeth, that the working man in this country could take no comfort from life under Labor. You are wrong on those facts anyhow, but this government does not concern itself or restrict itself to the working man; we are concerned about the working woman too. We are concerned about women and we do not put policies for women only under the heading of families.

Mr Howard put out a headland statement yesterday. It may be a headland statement, but it has nothing to say about non-English speaking background families, nothing at all, and nothing to say about women, except that they might be part of a family. This is from Mr Howard, who says that he has been liberated about families—and he was quoted as saying that, I believe, in the Telegraph early this year. He might be liberated about families, but he still has a policy document that says nothing about women.

You, Senator, talk about the working man. What a pity! Perhaps it is because you have not come up to 1983. In the last 12 years there has been a dramatic increase in the number of women participating in the work force. We talk about working people in this country and the opportunities they have under Labor. Under this Labor government there are opportunities for those families that have made such a difference to the quality of their lives and the things that they now entertain for themselves and for their children.

Why would you want to have a headland document that misses out on women altogether? We know that the changes for women make such a difference to the families in this country. To have a woman who is confident and assured as part of a family is to improve on what life was like in the past for families in which women did not have educational or employment opportunities.

They do have opportunities under this Labor government. It has enormously assisted families. Those documents, those figures, anything I can cite, can certainly prove that and give the lie to your MPI today, Senator. So do all of the things that we have done for women. Ask the women of Australia. They are pleased to have opportunities to study and to work. They are pleased to be assisted with child care. They are pleased to be assisted to choose to stay at home if that is what they prefer to do. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The topic we are debating today expresses concern about the impact of falling living standards, high unemployment and associated family breakdown and other social costs. It is implicit in this topic that it is essential there be an adequate system of welfare to assist and empower families that are under economic or social pressure. It is also true, as this topic states, that the economic rationalist policies, pursued with such vigour for over a decade by Labor and also by the coalition, have had a negative impact on the average Australian.

PARA.TAB: Our social safety net has been under great stress in recent years and there are continual calls from many sources for it to be further weakened. It needs to be acknowledged that you cannot rip up the social safety net without providing an alternative. It is no use saying that welfare makes people dependent if you have nothing to put in its place. The alternative to dependency, which is death, is certainly not an alternative.

When cold economic reasoning becomes the main justification for policy making, compassion and caring are very much discounted. This is highlighted by the dismantling and tightening of the welfare system. If we acknowledge the difficulties faced by Australian families, it must be recognised that these difficulties apply all the more to those people who live in rural Australia.

Recently I visited Mount Isa, Longreach, Winton and Cloncurry in north-west Queensland—an area that I lived in for five years in the late 1960s. While I was there I met with people from the Remote Area Families Service in Mount Isa, who work regularly with families throughout the north-west area of Queensland. The stories which these people tell highlight the extra difficulties faced by people in remote areas. It is in these regions that government neglect is obvious. Economic problems are more pronounced in many rural areas, adding to the problems of isolation and distance, and there are substantially fewer health services and other services.

I could give you statistics but it might be useful if I illustrated this point with the human face described to me by the Aged Care Service and Remote Area Family Service in Mount Isa. Those services spoke about the problem in many country hospitals of the government limiting such things as long-term beds. At Julia Creek, for instance, there is one long-term bed allowed, which is always full, while 14 other beds in that hospital remain empty. Recently, a woman in her 80s was sent to the Julia Creek hospital. The long-term bed was full so she had to go over 1,000 kilometres to Brisbane, where she died six weeks later.

There are gaps in our system and I urge both the government and the coalition to take account of them. In remote areas there is a great need for the education of children—a greater need for those on properties than for those in towns. We need to differentiate between rural and remote rural areas. For example, one of the problems faced by many people on remote properties is teaching their children. They need incentives. But there is no child-care funding or tax concessions for people who employ governesses. There is no credit given to graduate teachers who, being unable to get a job anywhere else, offer to do governessing for a period.

The difference between quantitative and qualitative care, which is often blurred by statistical support for submissions, is a problem that needs to be drawn to the attention of all. For example, a ridiculous situation exists whereby, to identify categories in statistical returns, postcodes are often used. There are properties in the Northern Territory which receive mail through Mount Isa. In statistical returns, the Mount Isa postcode is used while the properties themselves are hundreds of kilometres from Mount Isa. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —From the dawn of history, the family, in its various forms, has been the constant, primary, vital unit and support group of all human societies. Human beings have invariably chosen to organise themselves into tribal and subtribal groupings with the family as the basic building block of higher and more complex structures.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, the absolute pursuit of individual self-interest would lead to unsustainable anarchy. Collective security at all levels of social organisation—family, community and nation—has proved essential, whether for physical survival against external aggression, the need for social order, the nurture and protection of the young, economic betterment, social intercourse or companionship. All experience has demonstrated the interdependence between individuals and groups if individuals are to develop their spiritual, intellectual, physical and moral potentials. It is the duty of governments to create that environment which best enables the achievement of individual potential.

Government must never be seen as an end in itself. It is one of the many means—an important one—towards human fulfilment. Clearly, one of the first needs of every individual and family is the opportunity to obtain constant and adequately rewarded employment in a vocation best suited to individual talent. Where unemployment is high and chronically sustained, as at present in Australia, the families concerned are gravely penalised. Quite apart from loss of income, the demoralising effect on the individual is significant.

Unemployment benefits must never be viewed as a substitute for the creation of genuine employment opportunities. During this last decade, a high percentage of Australian families have been seriously damaged by the lack of jobs through levels of unemployment in the recession—which, according to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), we had to have—higher than at any time since the Great Depression of the 1930s.

The statistics disguise greater hardships. Many persons displaced in their middle years are never likely to be re-employed in worthwhile occupations. Youth unemployment has been greater than 20 per cent. School students and university graduates have been unable to plan courses of study with any certainty of employment. High housing interest rates have forced many married women with young families, reluctantly, to re-enter the work force.

In the early 1970s, the Henderson report on poverty in Australia concluded that Australia in the 1960s had been one of the world's most egalitarian societies with an equitable sharing of created national wealth and only a narrow gap between rich and poor. Indeed, it reported that, in terms of the world's understanding of the meaning of the word, there was no real poverty in Australia. At that time we had one of the highest living standards, with unemployment rarely above two per cent and with record home ownership.

Today, there is a vast and growing gap between rich and poor. It has risen by some 20 per cent under this Labor government. Poverty is a very real problem and there is an increasing sense of despair about the issue.

Australian living standards—in spite of what Senator Crowley said—have steadily slipped below other less fortunate countries. The destruction of human dignity and self-esteem is a massive threat to the integrity of the family and is a result of the failure of government. Support systems hurriedly put in by governments can never take the place of family—in fact, they can be dehumanising in their effects. True, the individuals and families affected may not starve or suffer from lack of health facilities but they too frequently feel that nobody is concerned about them. Loneliness, isolation, and loss of self-esteem can be corrosive of the family.

If human potential is to be realised, we need to develop self-motivating people, strongly bonded in their family groups, with eagerness and initiative to strive, and with the opportunities to put their talents to successful enterprises. It is, of course, the duty of government to offer adequate assistance to the underprivileged and the aged poor; the nature of that government support should be such as to preserve dignity in the recipient.

The earlier wage fixing decisions of the arbitration system envisaged a minimum living wage capable of supporting a man, his wife and two children. Effective margins for skill were also envisaged. Later it changed, however, to the capacity of industry to pay. The family principle, sadly, has gone.

The post-war era saw several decades in which Liberal governments sought to strengthen families with full employment, low inflation, and home ownership. As the government said in its agenda for families, the greatest help a government can give to families is a strong economy—that is from the government's own budget papers. Sadly, of course, by those criteria, the government has failed.

These were the decades, in the post-war era, when families did flourish and where the forgotten people were recognised. Today, many single parent families are suffering great hardships with great strain on both parents and children. Many of the newly developed suburbs, particularly in the south and south-west of Sydney, lack community facilities capable of bringing diverse backgrounds and languages together. The result is that loneliness and isolation are manifest. The many chronically unemployed transients, seeking employment or sometimes warmer climates and cheaper living conditions on the central and north coasts of New South Wales, are witness to this trend. Some schools in those areas face the challenge of almost 30 per cent transience in enrolments.

The tragedy is that this government sees its economic theories and policies as goals in themselves and has forgotten that economics, at its best, is an imperfect mechanism. The government needs to be reminded that the living standards and potential talents and aspirations of humans should be the central goal of a government. A genuine concern for people should be the focus of our debate.

If the Australian family is to be strengthened, if the problems of the low income and single parent families are to be minimised, if the elements of family dysfunction are to be identified and mitigated, the first duty of government is to restore the family as a viable economic and social unit, confident and secure in its future. By these criteria, it is very clear that this government has failed.

We all remember the infamous empty promise of Bob Hawke that no children would live in poverty. Yet one in five children is still living below the poverty line. We have record and rising youth suicide rates—again, undoubtedly associated with the stresses and pressures placed upon the family structure. We heard earlier that in 1983 household debt as a proportion of household disposable income was 42 per cent. Now it has risen to 66 per cent. The pressures on families are enormous and are rising.

I mentioned before that the gap between rich and poor has risen almost 20 per cent under Labor—10 per cent in the last few years alone. This last budget, apart from increasing the tax take by almost 10 per cent, has meant that something like 12 or 13 per cent of families would be worse off, simply as a result of the budget, by around $8 a week. Now, $8 might be dismissed by the government as being of no significance but, as my colleague Senator Troeth mentioned, $8 to a family which is counting every dollar is a lot of money.

Senator Crowley, the Minister for Family Services—the minister responsible for the family—said how delighted she was. What was she delighted with? She was delighted with the fact that families are not now at risk of extinction. Just consider that. What sort of aims are we trying to achieve here? The family is no longer at risk of extinction—no words about nurturing, no words about support, no words about encouraging and strengthening—it is not at risk of extinction. I guess that indicates the government's view.

If you ask people what happened in the International Year of the Family, almost all people will say absolutely nothing. The job figures have been fiddled, but there are still massive unemployment figures. The minister mentioned the problems of education. She boasted about how good it was. I point out that 60 per cent of 13- to 16-year-old students from low income families do not have literacy levels beyond the fourth grade. That is primary school literacy levels. This is something the government should be ashamed of. The government should be supporting families, not mouthing empty promises and rhetoric. It should get out there and make sure that the cornerstone of our society is truly strengthened.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to participate in this debate on the allegation of the neglect of Australian families demonstrated by falling living standards, high unemployment, family breakdown and associated social costs. I think today could be described as lies, damn lies and statistics. We have heard a lot of statistics, so to balance up the inaccuracies we have heard from the opposite side I will quote some as well. The National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling has carried out some research on this matter. Its indications are that the gap between the rich and the poor has narrowed by social wage spending in this country.
—Social wage spending?

—Obviously those in the opposition do not understand how people are being helped by this government. The latest income distribution report of the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling states that the average increases of the top 20 per cent of Australian families fall from 13 times to four times that of those at the bottom 20 per cent once the benefits of government expenditure on social welfare services are included.

PARA.TAB: When people talk about social welfare programs, they obviously do not understand the whole gamut of programs that this government has in place to assist people. In terms of public health, Medicare is part of the social wage and social contract to the people. The provision of education is part of the social contract to the people in the provision of social wage spending. There is also housing services and payments of cash support, but those opposite can only see the cash support. They fail to look at the assistance given through Medicare. The majority of people in Australia like Medicare and bulkbilling. However, the opposition failed to appreciate that. It wants more people back like they were in 1982, where over 2 million to 3 million people were without any private health insurance or any health insurance cover at all.

Let us look at some of the facts behind these allegations of decline, which are in fact increases. After tax family incomes—which have to include wages, salary, welfare payments and investment income—have increased by 37 per cent in real terms under Labor. People should be taking cognisance of those sorts of figures—a 37 per cent increase since 1983. We have also seen an increase in employment levels. We have seen a further 1.89 million Australians in work since 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —What sort of work, Sue? Part-time work?
—Both part-time and full-time employment. It is their choice to make.
—What happened to the population, Sue?
—It is the population growth.

—It has not grown by that much. The comments of opposition members show that they do not understand this whole issue. We have to look at the institutions that assist people. Those institutions include Medicare, child care, targeted assistance, family allowance payments and more university places. These are the sorts of issues where government is assisting the people. It is important that the people out there recognise that the opposition only want to talk about people who are on assistance in the form of aged pensions or unemployment benefits. They fail to look at the other services provided by this government. In the opposition's statement last night, it called for the government to get out of a lot of issues. That means there will be cuts to Medicare, education, health, family payments and that type of thing. That is what those opposite are promising.

PARA.TAB: We know from this research that a couple with two children now receive, on average, $193 per week in non-cash benefits. This is from a government that does not care? Rubbish! The opposition does not understand what it is all about. Let us have a look at what its policies would be. The opposition is a policy free zone. I looked at the statement last night to compare its proposals with what we are actually delivering. I cannot find any policies in that statement for women. I find no mention of domestic violence. Domestic violence in this community affects women and families more than a lot of other programs and problems, yet this opposition in its headland statement—cape desolation statement—has no concern for women and children living in violent relationships. It does not even want to address the issue. That is how much the opposition cares for families.
Let us look at some other things that those opposite have talked about. They mention a charter of budget honesty. That is straight out of the USA. They are straight Newt Gingrich words.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is not; it is straight from New Zealand.

—Let us look at the social desolation being wrought upon New Zealand by its economic policies—absolute social desolation and desecration. This charter of budget honesty is straight Newt Gingrich. Those opposite also talk about getting the government off people's backs. Again, it is straight Newt Gingrich. What does this mean? It is a euphemism for a $10 billion cut to services.
—Is it within standing orders to attack the Speaker of another parliament?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—I am advised that our standing orders do not provide protection for foreign legislatures.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that they want to protect their friend Newt Gingrich; the fellow who has cut out school lunches for children. He belongs to the party that does not have any problems with assault rifles and assault weapons.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: clearly it is not in the standing orders, although I hope it might be referred to the procedures committee. Is it appropriate that a senator would grossly misrepresent the republican legislation on school lunches? Is there any protection for a politician of Mr Gingrich's standing?
—I suggest that the only protection is for someone to provide some correct information at a later stage of this debate. The issue that you raise is really a debating point.
—Obviously that issue is too close to the bone. They do not want to know about it.
—You don't know about it because that is not what they did with school lunches.

—It is wonderful; they are so sensitive about the whole issue. They ought to look at what is happening in the states, see the people living in cardboard boxes and begging on the streets. That is the sort of thing they would put up with because they do not want government to be involved in lots of things. They think individuals have the strength to do lots of things for themselves. As Senator Woods said, `You only worry about the poor and the aged; you do not look at what people might need to ensure they do not slip through some of the safety nets.' In the opposition's statement launched—(Time expired)

—Senator Troeth did not need a crystal ball when she started to speak to this issue. She said that the speaker on the other side would get up and go on and on about programs. That is exactly what those opposite did. She was right to a T. I remind Senator West that program after program will do nothing to get young people in Australia, older people in Australia and people on mature age allowances in Australia real jobs. It will do nothing to create wealth in Australia—more wealth that we can divide amongst all Australians to create real jobs, not fake jobs or fake programs.

PARA.TAB: I found it interesting that Senator West had seven minutes in which to speak—

TALK.START.PARA: —Eight actually, but you mob took about a minute and a half.

—Well, eight minutes then. But she spent most of that time talking about what was going on in America and New Zealand. I do not know whether she has been to New Zealand, but a lot has happened in New Zealand and they are laughing at Australia because they are so much more competitive than we are on the world markets now. If you go into any shop you will find more and more products from New Zealand. I bet that New Zealand families are benefiting from that. Senator West spent more than half her time debating what was going on in New Zealand and America because she had nothing to talk about what is going on here in Australia. The reality is that in Australia we have falling living standards, high unemployment and family breakdowns, with the associated social costs.
—And I'll bet there's a lot more under the poverty line.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I interjected once or twice; I did not go on and on throughout the whole speech. Obviously, Senator West could not get through what she had to say in the time allotted so she has to now spend time interjecting in my speech because she does not like what she hears. She does not like to hear that there are breakdowns in Australian families and all the associated costs that go with that. In fact, the situation is desperate for Australian families.
—There are more people in work now than ever before.
—Order! Senator West!

—A recent Australian Bureau of Statistics survey of Australian social trends backs this up, showing greater income in equality, rising welfare dependency, greater family breakdown, the emergence of a working poor and an alarming surge in the suicide rate, particularly amongst young men. We talk about high unemployment; unemployment is currently running at 8.3 per cent, seasonally adjusted in April. This figure is alarming in itself. But we have to look at what is happening with government programs. The government is shifting people off unemployment benefits. Older people who are unable to get unemployment are being shifted to a mature age allowance. This government is fudging those unemployment figures and fudging the impact on Australian families.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the impact of unemployment on young people who are unemployed. Senator Troeth gave some examples of unemployment in rural areas in Victoria. She mentioned two in particular and I mentioned two others: the central highlands and the Wimmera area where unemployment is running at 31.8 per cent for young people; and the Gulbert-Ovens-Murray zone area where the unemployment rate is 36.2 per cent.

Unemployment affects young Australian families across the board. A while ago I had a phone call to my office from a grandparent desperate because her grandchild could not get a job. It does not just worry their parents; their grandparents also worry when they see that number of young people—40 or 45 per cent of young people in rural areas—unable to find a job. Senator Crowley was saying that the situation is good. That is the sort of statement that Mr Keating made to small business. Senator Crowley was telling us, `It doesn't get much better than this; you've never had it so good.' She has not even stayed for the debate. Australian families know that that is not the case. They have been hit by the previous policies of this government and they have also been hit by the current budget.

We spend more on family breakdown than we spend on keeping families together. If we look at the budget we spent on the Family Court and the Child Support Agency we see that we have spent millions and millions of dollars shutting the door after the horse has bolted. In 12 years this government has done almost nothing about families before they reach crisis point. One of the reasons which causes crisis in families is financial stress. In the recession that we had to have we saw families facing enormous financial stress with those rising interest rates. Those families are now the ones who are appearing in the family courts. That is the legacy of this government's policy—family breakdown. What else is a legacy of family breakdown? There has been an increase in the number of young people on the streets. In six years the number of homeless young people has doubled. That is the legacy of this government's policies. That is the legacy of the breakdown in families in Australia today. Those opposite stand in here supposedly proud of their record. I would be appalled and ashamed of the record if I were in their shoes.

What has this budget done for families? Senator Crowley got up and talked about the maternity allowance. The maternity allowance is a broken promise of Mr Keating's. He promised payment for 12 weeks at jobsearch allowance rates and a payment of at least $1,800, double what he is actually giving out. The basic family payment for 16- to 17-year-olds is to be paid through Austudy instead of the family payments scheme. That does not tell people that families will lose a total of $64.20 a year as a result.

Measure after measure in this budget hits families. Mr Howard told us we would not need an increase in the Medicare levy. Do honourable senators know why we have an increase in the Medicare levy? It is because Mr Keating wanted Senator Crowley's vote and she was not happy with the co-payment. Mr Howard said that without a co-payment the Medicare levy would not have to go up. So in order to get Senator Crowley's vote, Mr Keating bought that. This is the price Australians are paying in this budget for Mr Keating being in government—an increase in the Medicare levy. How does that affect families? It means they have fewer dollars in their pocket.

Senator Troeth talked about the cost on new homes and improvements on homes—another cost to the family. There has been an increase in the cost of a family car. This government has an appalling record of looking after Australian families. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to acknowledge that the government has taken some positive measures to assist low income families. Unfortunately, this has been at the expense of middle income families. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) should really look at that. The taxation of families is of concern to most Australians. After the budget I issued a press statement pointing out that a one income family with two children on average weekly earnings is at least $26.77 worse off than they were in December 1982. The government has circulated a note, prepared by the Department of Social Security, which disputes that figure and says that my example was selected for maximum effect. The example I gave was not extreme. In fact, using the same methodology, between December 1982 and December 1984 a one income family with a spouse and four children has actually lost $37 a week.

PARA.TAB: Social Security also wrongly asserts that my figures were misleading because the level of rebates claimed for 1982 was too high. It wrongly used the `without child' level of spouse rebate, which was extraordinary. The extraordinary thing is that Social Security admits that there have been tax increases from 1982 to 1994, even on its own figures. It admits that family disposable income will fall in the year to December 1995. It is no consolation for any family to be told that although the government is taking a larger slice of the tax packet, it is still leaving enough not to make families worse off than they were in December 1982. The percentage increase in tax is still outstripping the percentage increase in income.

On Social Security's approach, the government could argue that as long as disposable income of a family was at the same level as it was in 1901, there has been no real increase in taxation since 1901. It is not even true that the government is still leaving people better off. There is no genuine increase in disposable family income. Social Security has ignored employee taxes not reflected in the CPI. Fringe benefits tax and tax on superannuation amounted to $15.26 per week per worker in 1994-95. This alone cancels out the suggested gain in disposable income.

The most extravagant claim was the Prime Minister's assertion that the best—this was made earlier this week—measure of living standards in Australia is real household disposable income and that between 1983 and 1995 real household disposable income grew by 40 per cent. However, the Prime Minister admitted this figure to be irrelevant as soon as he said it and said that because the population has grown since then, it is more relevant to look at the numbers per head. He then argued that the disposable income per head compared with the March quarter of 1983 had increased 19.8 per cent. This figure is equally nonsense as it failed to adjust for increased working hours by primary breadwinners, increased reliance by families on a second breadwinner and a smaller number of children per household.

Most people would be amazed to be told that if they work a 48-hour week instead of a 40-hour week and get 20 per cent more income, they are 20 per cent better off. That would only be true if you attach no value at all to sport, rest, worship or to be with your spouse and family. Most people find that working longer hours puts considerably more stress on families, personal relationships and their quality of life.

Even if family disposable income did increase by $12.55 per week, that gain would have been purchased by full-time employees working longer hours. They are working harder than ever to defend their families' living standards. ABS statistics show that full-time workers are now working an average of 43 hours per week rather than 38.2 in 1982. A bogus 2.8 per cent increase in disposable income will have been gained since 1982 at the expense of a 12.6 per cent increase in working hours.

Everybody knows that families are working harder and harder to pay more and more direct and indirect taxation to the government for less and less. The government, on its own figures, is seizing 78 per cent of the extra work being put in by wage earners. For the information of the parliament and the public, I seek leave to incorporate the statistics and spreadsheets, as well as an expanded response to the Department of Social Security. I also seek leave to table the Social Security documents that were distributed.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The documents read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: RESPONSE BY SENATOR BRIAN HARRADINE TO GOVERNMENT CRITICISM OF HARRADINE MEDIA RELEASE 16 MAY 1995

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has circulated a note, prepared by the Department of Social Security, which questions the accuracy of my statement that a one income family with two children on average weekly earnings is "at least $26.77 worse off than they were in December 1982".
I wish to respond to the Social Security analysis.

It is suggested that "the example has been selected for maximum effect" and uses male full time total average weekly earnings. It is then suggested "this is not a true indicator of average earnings" and that "less than 37% of full time workers receive earnings of at least this amount."
Male full time total earnings have traditionally been used for comparisons of one income families over time for several reasons.

Most single income families are supported by male wages as it is generally the wife who has the care and custody of children. This is recognised by Government decisions to pay family payments plus Home Child Care Allowance to the primary carer on the grounds that it is usually the wife, not the husband, who has no independent income and has the care of the children.

Male full time earnings are the only consistent statistical series over the long term. Because of changes in the employment patterns of women in the workforce in terms of numbers, skills and opportunities the use of "all adults" earnings masks trends in wage earnings. I note that the Minster for Social Security has used male adult AWE as a benchmark for his answer to a question in the House on 5 June at Hansard p 1039.

It is not very profound for Social Security to point out that not every family is average. That is why people are interested in looking at representative groups, of which one income families on male earnings are an important and socially significant example. Most families, after all, have to survive on one income at some stage of the life cycle.
The example has not been selected for maximum effect.
Single income families on average earnings with more than 2 children have suffered more.
For example, on the same basis, ie December 1982 to December 1994:-

PARA.EMPHASIS: a family on average earnings with a dependent spouse and 4 children has lost $37.17 per week.

SPEECH.PARA: Two-income families have also lost more of their earnings.
A family with a husband and wife, with the husband on average male and the wife on 3/4 male full time earnings (ie about female full time average earnings), with 2 children has lost $44.64 per week.

It is stated that "as Medicare did not operate in 1982 and average workers needed to rely on private health insurance, inclusion of an estimate for private health insurance payments for that year would provide a fairer comparison".

Any comparison for the 37.2% (June 1994) of the population that has retained hospital insurance would show a far worse result. This is especially so because hospital insurance premiums have gone up in real cost because of:-
the abolition of the Commonwealth subsidy to the hospital benefits re-insurance trust account:
the abolition of the Commonwealth subsidy to private hospital beds; and
the abolition of the tax rebate for health insurance premiums (in 1982-83 a rebate of 30.67% was available for payments to a registered health insurance organisation).

In addition, the Government abolished the general concessional rebate for family-type expenses over $1,590, under which many, if not most, families would have been able to claim a 30.67% tax rebate on "out of pocket" medical, dental, chemist or hospital expenses. Because the general concessional rebate included superannuation, life assurance premiums and rates, many family taxpayers would have been able to claim the 30.67% rebate on almost their first dollar of health, dental, chemist or hospital "out of pocket" expenses

The more limited medical expenses rebate now excludes the first $1,000 of medical and hospital expenses and applies a reduced tax rebate of 20%. Contributions paid to medical or hospital benefits funds or to other health insurance funds do not qualify for this tax rebate.

In this respect the comparison has been excessively kind to the Government's record. In 1983 in Victoria family HBA basic hospital contributions were $8.80 per week ($6.10 after the 30.67% tax rebate). In June 1995, they are $16.40 per week and there is no tax rebate. In Victoria HBA top hospital family cover in September 1983 was $13.50 per week ($9.36 after the 30.67% tax rebate) and in April 1995 was $35 per week with no tax rebate.
In regard to medical cover for doctors' visits, in June 1983 HBA cover for doctors' visits was $5 per week in Victoria ($3.47 after the tax rebate).

Thus the total after tax cost for basic medical and hospital cover was $9.57 per week in 1983, or $497.64 per annum ($892.43 in December 1994 dollars). The Medicare levy is now $529.88 per annum and due to rise to $589.74 per annum by December. The 37.2% of people who have retained private hospital insurance are much worse off; people who dropped private hospital insurance are better off (assuming waiting lists are not a problem) but are becoming less so. People who preferred to self-insure are worse off as they, like those with private hospital insurance, are being forced to pay twice, if they wish to have their doctor of choice. People who preferred to purchase cheaper risk-rated health insurance products are also worse off, as these insurance options have now been prohibited by law. Low income earners are unaffected as they are exempt from the Medicare levy and in 1982 they were eligible for free bulk billing for doctors' visits and free public hospital accommodation if they were classed as disadvantaged and thus had a pensioner health benefits card or a Health Care Card. Some 2.3 million people were covered by these cards at 30 June 1982 (Budget Statements 1982-83 p 89).

It might also be noted that the Social Security analysis disputes the inclusion of the Medicare levy while arguing that disposable income figures in real terms (ie adjusted by the CPI) should be used. Since, however, the Statistician discounted the CPI on the introduction of Medicare, no objection can be taken by Social Security to the inclusion of the Medicare levy, if the CPI is to be used to compare disposable incomes over time.

It is asserted that "the table is misleading in other ways." It is asserted that "the amount included for income tax paid in 1982 indicates that a high level of deductions has been assumed for that year but not for 1994 and 1995". It is also asserted that "the level of rebates claimed for 1982 is too high as only Spouse, HCCA and low income rebates are mentioned."

As the footnotes to my table indicated, the tax scales and rebate levels applied are those which were in force in the month of December. The new rate scale and spouse rebate levels ($1,030 for a spouse where there are dependent children) came into effect on 1 November 1982 and were "fully reflected in PAYE instalments from 1 November 1982" (see Budget Statements 1982-83 p 240). The December figures show the tax on a PAYE earner at that time. There is nothing misleading about looking at where a worker is at a point of time.

The Social Security table is also in error by using the lower $830 "without child" level of the spouse rebate. This $200 error plus its use of the full year rate scale instead of the December rate scale accounts for its Table 1 showing a lower level of tax increase (ie Social Security claimed the tax rate rose by 1.59 percentage points instead of 3.69 percentage points).
Social Security's Table 2 to their Attachment B attempts to minimise the significance of tax increases by asserting that "the disposable income of the sample family has increased slightly
in real terms over the period". It is suggested in a handwritten note that such a family will be $12.55 a week better off by December 1995.
The extraordinary thing is that Social Security admits that there have been tax increases from 1982 to 1994 and 1995, even on their own figures.

Social Security also admits that, on their methodology (which looks at changes in disposable income in absolute dollar terms rather than the dollars lost by increased effective tax rates), the disposable income of the family will fall from $31,122.15 to $30,924.66 per annum in the year to December 1995. In other words, even Social Security admits that a one income family on male earnings with a dependent spouse and two children will be $3.80 per week worse off by the end of this year.

But Social Security's methodology also needs to be questioned. It is no consolation for any family to be told that although the Government is taking a larger slice of the pay packet, the Government is still leaving enough not to make the family worse off—the percentage increase in tax is still outstripping the percentage increase in income.

On Social Security's approach, the Government could argue that as long as disposable income of a family was at the same level as it was in 1901, then there has been no real increase in taxation since 1901. That is a nonsense and taxpayers are concerned about how much of their families' incomes are being taken in taxation—they don't see why all their productivity gains or extra work effort should be appropriated by Government. But, in fact, it is not even true that government is still leaving people better off. There is no genuine increase in disposable family income.

As the Social Security paper concedes, the effective tax rate has risen. However, the Social Security analysis does not really address the additional impact of other Federal taxes and increased State and Federal indirect taxation. While some of these taxes are reflected in the CPI, many (such as broadened sales tax) would have a differentially more severe impact on families. Families would also suffer relatively more from the disguised increased taxation involved in water and electricity dividends paid to State Governments.

For example, if tax collected from fringe benefits and superannuation funds are distributed evenly per capita over the PAYE workforce the average increase in the tax burden is $793 per annum or $15.26 per week in 1994-95. (Fringe benefits tax was $2,720 million and super funds tax was $1,900 million; $4,620 million in 1994-95. The number of employed wage and salary earners was 5,823,500). These taxes are taxes on employees and were intended to be so, just as much as PAYE income tax. These taxes alone cancel out Social Security's suggested gain in disposable income.

Another hidden tax is the 6% compulsory employer superannuation contribution. It can be described as a tax because it is a compulsory contribution made out of foregone wages and imposed under sanction of the superannuation guarantee levy. The employer and employee superannuation contributions are to be compulsory payments made in lieu of wages. They will be akin to a 12% flat rate income tax surcharge. A major purpose of the compulsory superannuation scheme is to force people to save themselves out of the age pension, as evidenced by the figures in Table I of Saving for Our Future. If the current 6% employer contribution is included as an income tax surcharge the figures are far worse for the Government's record. It is as though 6% of a worker's income is subject to a 100% tax rate and is gone before he even sees it. This quasi-tax is not reflected either in taxation statistics or the CPI. While it may be argued that it is better for people to save now rather than rely on taxing other people's children to pay them age pensions, one should not lose sight of the fact that today's workers are being forced to take a cut in disposable income compared to their predecessors.

In regard to indirect taxation, total indirect taxes in the December 1994 quarter were $15,203 million or 19.2% of household disposable income versus $5,650 million which was 17% of household disposable income. The increases in the petrol excise and in the basic sale tax rate since 1993 have not been insignificant in their effect. A surcharge of 2.2% taxation on household disposable income is equivalent to an income tax surcharge of another 2.2*(1-.1777) or 1.81%. This is equivalent to a loss $684.70 per annum or $13.17 per week. While various indirect taxes are reflected in the CPI, the CPI does not reflect the differentially more severe impact on families of many indirect taxes. The CPI is based on all consumers, young, single, old as well as families with children. This was why the average price effect claimed for the 15% GST prior to the 1993 election was subject to such scrutiny. The same scrutiny may usefully be applied to Social Security computing family disposable incomes using the CPI where there are changes of indirect taxes over a period.

Even in Canberra which is better off than most of Australia, indirect charges can look large compared to Social Security's alleged gain. For example, a worker in Canberra city now has to pay $25 per week for car parking where it was free in 1982. That non-tax deductible cost of working is alone double Social Security's alleged gain in household disposable income. There are, of course, miscellaneous other charges which would bear more heavily on families eg "voluntary" public school contributions or pre-school fees.

The impact of reduced Commonwealth funding for the States has also had an effect. States and Territories have been forced to put up their charges and squeeze dividends out of public utilities through rigorous adherence to user pays principles. As noted by the Australian Automobile Association (January 1995) "The commercialisation and privatisation of Government Business Enterprises (GBEs) such as communications, electricity, water and sewerage has been accompanied by State and Federal Treasuries transferring existing funded public assets to GBEs at replacement value and imposing spurious `dividend' requirements on GBEs which must in turn be recovered by `user charges.' The result has been a recent meteoric rise in indirect taxation in Australia disguised as `user charges' This form of tax has increased by 650% since 1987/88 from $400 million to $3 billion" (in 1993/94). None of this hidden taxation shows up in official taxation statistics. While such charges are reflected in the CPI they bear more heavily on families than other consumers on average. The failure of governments to pass on to consumers the savings from labour shedding in public utilities means that family taxpayers are having to pay taxes to support these displaced workers while getting little reduction in utility charges.

The Prime Minister has asserted (Hansard 1 June 1995 p 902) that "the best measure of living standards in Australia is real household disposable income" and that between 1983 and 1995 real household disposable income grew by 40 per cent. The Prime Minister himself admitted this figure to be irrelevant as soon as he said it and that "because the population has grown since then, it is more relevant to look at the numbers per head". He then argued that disposable income per head in the last March quarter was $3,568 compared with the March quarter of 1983, an increase of 19.8 per cent. This figure is equally a nonsense as it fails to adjust for:
increased working hours by primary breadwinners;
increased reliance by families on a second breadwinner; and
a smaller number of children per household.

As national income economists, such as the late Professor R I Downing of Melbourne University have long recognized, it is absurd for anyone, including the Prime Minister, to talk about increased national or household income when labour market patterns are changing. As Professor Downing pointed out, in World War II many wives went to work in factories and "if in peacetime a large number of housewives decided to take paid jobs and to employ housekeepers, national product would include not only the paid work done by housewives, but also the paid work done by housekeepers. Yet to the extent that housekeepers were doing exactly the same work previously done by housewives, there would have been, on that account, no true increase in national product." (Downing, National Income and Social Accounts 12th Edition, 1969, pp 47-48).

Most people would be amazed to be told that if you work a 48 hour week instead of a 40 hour week and get 20 per cent more income, you are 20 per cent better off. That would only be true if you attach no value at all to time to rest, sport, worship or to be with your spouse and family. Most people find that working longer hours puts considerably more stress on family and personal relationships and their quality of life.
The apparent gain in disposable income per head is thus doubly bogus. Even if family disposable income had increased by $12.55 per week, that "gain" would have been purchased by full time

employees working longer hours. They are working harder than ever to defend their families' standards of living. ABS statistics show that full time workers are now working an average of 43 hours per week rather than 38.2 in 1982.

Their disposable incomes should be 4.8/38.2 or 12.6% higher than in 1982 if taxation burdens had remained unchanged. A bogus 2.8% increase in disposable income has been gained at the expense of a 12.6% increase in hours worked. Everybody knows families are working harder and harder simply to pay more and more direct and indirect taxation to Government for less and less—the Government, on its own figures, is seizing 78% of the extra work being put in by wage earners.
The figures given on the social wage for low income earners really prove the point since the Social Security note admits most "assistance to families" is targeted. This means that, almost
by definition, the average earner is being cut out of what he pays for. In other words ordinary Australian families are getting a raw deal.

I do not deny that low income large families have gained from social transfers. But it is entirely misleading to describe such social transfers as a "social wage" when so many families are being systematically means tested out of any social recognition of the horizontal equity issues raised by their support of dependants. The situation is not like it was in the 1940s when workers sacrificed wage claims in order to fund a universal child endowment scheme which benefited every worker's family. You might call that a "social wage" but you cannot legitimately pretend that means tested welfare is some sort of social supplement to the earnings of most workers whose families get little or nothing out it.

If one takes the Government's 1994-95 Budget figures, most of the social transfers in the family payments area are going to low income and sole parent families (see Budget Statements 1994-95 p 3.99 Table 4.4). As far as most ordinary one or two income families go, basic family payments are going to fewer of them and shrinking in relative size. They have got very little or nothing from the so-called "social wage" since December 1982 and many have lost.

It is wrong to assert there are improvements to the social wage while with the next breath admitting that the Government has been doing its best to give less to middle income families. For most families the social wage in 1982 included schools and hospitals just as it does in 1995. They are paying more for what they used to have anyway and being left with less of their incomes.
