SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen C.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in opposition to Senator Troeth's matter of public importance today which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Labor's neglect of Australian families, demonstrated by falling living standards, high unemployment, family breakdown and associated social costs.

What we see here today is the result of Liberal Party strategy, based on their Republican advisers advice. The advisers who gave them push polling are now bringing this American strategy of appeal to the family and battlers to the Australian debate. The difficulty which they are going to have with this particular line is, firstly, that they are not particularly well-connected to those people in Australian society and do not have very good links into their concerns and issues. Secondly, the premise on which this approach and today's discussion are based is a false one. It is based, firstly, on an assumption that living standards are falling, and that is clearly not the case. While there is debate about the various statistical analyses, there is no evidence to suggest that living standards are falling. In fact, quite the opposite: they are on the rise.

PARA.TAB: The second assumption made by the matter of public importance is that unemployment is high and it implies that it is worsening. In fact, unemployment is falling and the general employment situation is improving quite considerably. I think the third assumption has been adequately dealt with by the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, and Senator West. It goes to the range of government programs which are trying to deal in a positive way with family breakdown and associated social costs. Those two speakers spent a great deal of time expounding the range of social, wage and other initiatives of this government that have sought to help families.

Before looking at a couple of those economic issues I want to attack what I think is the other assumption which underlines this matter of public importance; the assumption that somehow families are some distinct subgroup of Australian society and that they are not exposed to the general economic and social conditions that impact on their lives, that they experience, say, as workers, as recipients of social security or as members of community organisations. Families are not some subset removed from the rest of our society and community. People who are members of families are impacted on by all government policies. I think it is rather trite to say, `Let's look at family policy,' without looking at everything which impacts on Australian citizens, because they are members of families.

The essential point that I wish to make is that the 1995-96 budget was about families in the sense that it was about continuing a high growth, low inflation and improving employment economy. That is good for all Australians. If it is providing jobs, protecting people's investments, savings and wages through low inflation and providing growth in the economy, that is good for all Australian families. As the Liberal Party and others continually lecture us, growth in the economy is the key to employment and a range of the other social objectives that we all share. So rather than trying to isolate some of the statistics we have heard today to try to prove some sort of case that the Labor government is anti-family, we must look at the big picture and at what we are doing. The starting point for that must be employment.

Unemployment is the greatest blight on families and individuals in our society. We have taken a very serious attitude to trying to tackle what are unacceptably high levels of unemployment. The April figures showed that nationally unemployment had fallen to 8.3 per cent. That is the lowest figure since December 1990 and should be welcomed by all Australians. Employment grew by 90,000, and 80,000 of those were full-time jobs. It is equally the case that the participation rate was up to 63.7 per cent in April, so we had falling unemployment, employment growth and a high participation rate. Those are all very good indicators of employment growth and the fact that we are tackling the major problem that affects Australian families—that is, unemployment.

I think it is a tribute to the Working Nation strategy adopted by this government, a strategy is delivering jobs and it is also delivering jobs for the long-term unemployed, the persons who otherwise would be left behind in any economic recovery. That strategy has now been endorsed by a range of countries as an example of what should be done as one comes out of recession to make sure that the long-term unemployed benefit from growth in the economy and growth in jobs. When you are talking about families you have to start with that employment context.

One of the other things one ought to talk about is mortgage rates. We have heard the opposition talk a lot about mortgage rates in the past but now that the budget has delivered downward pressure on mortgage rates in the Australian community, it is less keen to talk about it. We heard no mention today of what the downward pressure on mortgage rates means for families. What it means is that they are not suffering from increased mortgage payments and the high cost that that places on household budgets. Families look like benefiting in the short term in terms of reduced mortgage interest rates. There have already been some encouraging signs of reductions in rates by a couple of lenders in the last few days.

That has a major impact on families because, along with wages and taxation, mortgages are obviously a big factor for a large percentage of the Australian population in terms of their disposable income. The downward pressure brought to bear on mortgage interest rates by the budget is a great credit to the government and reflects the family-orientated strategy.

As I mentioned before, another aspect is low inflation, which is very important in sustaining the economy, and the growth in the economy. We have been experiencing growth in the order of four per cent and the prospects for continued strong growth in the economy are good. Another issue that impacts on families is tax rates. Our marginal tax rates compared with those of the last Howard administration are much lower and they obviously benefit—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have the highest tax on families in the free world.

—Senator Campbell, for someone who advocated the GST at the last election I do not think you would want to talk about tax rates. This government's record is helping families by attacking the fundamentals in the economy that impact on their lives.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Order! The debate has concluded.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Report No.30 of 1994-95—Efficiency audit—Commonwealth government information and advertising.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This report is very interesting because it highlights the fact that the government has spent $200 million of taxpayers' money over the last five years promoting itself to the Australian community; $200 million of taxpayers' money is the subject of this audit.

PARA.TAB: The findings of the audit are startling as well. For example, in the appendices, there is a series of sample advertising campaigns commissioned on behalf of the government. One of the findings was that in the sample advertising campaigns chosen by the Australian National Audit Office not one of the departments set a performance target for the advertising campaign before commissioning it.

Here we have an advertising campaign on which we are going to spend millions of dollars, but the department which commissions the campaign does nothing to measure the effectiveness of the campaign against its supposed objectives. I believe that there is a very good reason for this. The very good reason is that many of the advertising campaigns which have been commissioned by this government have simply been launched for political purposes rather than for anything else.

In appendix 6 on page 48 of the report we see the heading `Medicare Hospital Entitlements Campaign', a campaign on which the Department of Human Services and Health has spent $3.3 million. It is interesting to see that the minister is in the chamber. One of the stated reasons for the campaign is:

SPEECH.PARA: To increase the proportion of Australians who are aware of their entitlements under the Medicare health system, including free treatment in public hospitals
Another reason was:
To increase awareness of initiatives to improve public hospital service and the benefits these improvements will provide

In other words, this report is going out there to promote how wonderful the government is because we have got Medicare. That is really what it is all about. It is nothing but a very blatant, very unsubtle media campaign to bolster the government's electoral fortunes—funded with $3.3 million of taxpayers' money.

PARA.TAB: I note the minister sitting on the other side of the chamber making all sorts of faces, as well she might. The fact is that, at the same time that the government was saying that we ought to increase private health cover—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I am not quite sure what point of order goes to referring to the intention of my face, Senator. As far as I know, nothing more than a grave frown crossed my brow. I think it is rather silly for you to start abusing me. I think that the standing orders in this place suggest that you stick to the debate and stop being so personal in your attack. You are wanting to argue—incorrectly—about the Medicare documentation, yet you are not arguing the Medicare issue, you are arguing about me. So leave off me and get on with the point.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Order! There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, the minister never has a point of order—she never has a point, actually. This $3.3 million of taxpayers' money is being used to bolster the electoral fortunes of the government, and the government has been caught out. It has been caught with its fingers in the till. At the same time that the government was spending $3.3 million to say what wonderful people its members were because they were providing the Medicare system, they were running around saying that we need to keep 40 per cent of the community with private health cover. In other words, this advertising campaign—I almost made the Freudian mistake of calling it an electoral campaign—was working directly against the government's stated interest of ensuring that 40 per cent of families in the community had private health cover. So it starts to look increasingly like a biased, blatant political exercise to spend $3.3 million to bolster the electoral fortunes of the Labor government.

PARA.TAB: I could go through each one of the appendices—I do not intend to do so—and point out that none of them had performance targets set; and, in fact, I cannot see many that have attempted to monitor the long-term key campaign results. Only one, relating to illicits and amphetamines—an entirely commendable area of concern—seems to be `monitoring target audiences' behaviour towards illicit drugs and other Drug Offensive campaign issues.' That is great, but that is the only one where there is any long-term measuring of the advertising campaign.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you well know that, if you are a business in the private sector which spends money on advertising, you monitor the results of the advertising. If you do not monitor the results of the advertising, you do not know whether you are throwing your money away or whether you are getting some benefit for it.

I believe that there is a very clear reason why the government has no interest in monitoring the results of the advertising campaign. It is because the real reason for the advertising campaign is different from the reason which is stated in the report. The reason for government advertising as stated in the report is to inform people of their obligations and their rights. The real reason for this government spending so much money on advertising is to bolster its electoral support.

If proof is needed, I refer honourable senators opposite to the fact that the Auditor-General in this report again refers to the National Media Liaison Service as being part of the government media mechanism—the means by which the government chooses to advertise. We know that in Audit report No. 19 of 1994-95, the Auditor-General was highly critical of the National Media Liaison Service. In fact, he said that it was a loophole through public accountability, and reference is made to it again in this report.

The National Media Liaison Service issue will not go away. The government can stick its head in the sand as much as it likes, but the truth is that everybody out there knows that the government has a group of flunkies whose job is to monitor members of the opposition and feed the information back to the ministers' offices so that the government can make direct attacks on members of the opposition. Honourable senators on this side of the chamber know that everywhere they go, they are being watched. They know that every word they say on radio is being monitored, and anything the government does not like attracts immediate criticism.

We also know that members of the National Media Liaison Service, led by Mr Epstein—even though he pretends he is not the Director of the National Media Liaison Service—are also spending a large chunk of their time circulating throughout the press gallery upstairs on the second floor and spreading documents on members of the opposition which are highly defamatory. The Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) has seen that sort of conduct; he has been on the receiving end of that sort of conduct. We know it goes on, we know who is responsible for it, we know that it is paid for by taxpayers' money, and you are not going to have a point of order this time, either.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I think that it is quite unparliamentary for Senator O'Chee to claim that members of the National Media Liaison Service are upstairs circulating documents that are defamatory.
—Rubbish! Of course they are; all the time.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Senator Crowley, that is not a point of order; it is a debating point.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recognise the interjection of my colleague Senator Baume. That intervention by the minister was pure rubbish; most interventions by this minister are pure rubbish; most of the things that are said in this chamber by the minister are pure rubbish. Most of the things that are peddled by the National Media Liaison Service are pure rubbish as well, when it comes to some of the innuendo and gossip that it spreads amongst the press gallery about members of the opposition.

PARA.TAB: It is a matter of grave concern for all Australians that $200 million could be spent in the space of five years on promoting the government. When senators on the other side of the chamber say, `How would you people in the opposition cut government spending?', I would say that we would cut back on some of the government's taxpayer-funded self-promotion, because this money—and this is typical of Labor bureaucracies—which is detailed here, does not go to delivering a service; it goes to making the government look good. Heaven help us if we think about what the result of the last election would have been had it not been for the massive expenditure of money by the federal government in dubious advertising campaign after dubious advertising campaign.

I conclude by reminding honourable senators about a campaign which ran recently about people in this country being job-ready. Yes, heaven help us, there are a lot of people in this country who are job-ready. The problem is that this government is so busy spending money telling us about it that there is no money out there for people to employ them. In other words, there are all these people who are job-ready who are just ready for jobs that are never going to come along.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator O'Chee's expressions of concern about government advertising and the way taxpayers' money is being used for it. In this case, $12 per Australian has been spent by the government to tell Australians what they, quite frankly, do not need to know. I am certain that most Australians would rather have the $12.

PARA.TAB: I will now go to the detail of this report. It is reasonable to point out that some of the advertising is of very high quality. As the Auditor-General points out, Commonwealth campaigns have won numerous advertising awards in recent years. One reason for this is that price is no object. The Auditor-General expresses concern about this:

SPEECH.PARA: .price does not enter into the consideration of the competitiveness of creative agencies' strategies.
OGIA regards empathetic and strategic considerations as being far more important.

I also wonder whether it goes to a few mates. However, that issue is not entered into in this audit. It is noteworthy that the Auditor-General has expressed concern that considerations other than price are apparently regarded as very important. I am intrigued to know what all those other considerations are.

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor Party affiliation.
—I acknowledge the interjection from Senator O'Chee. It could well be Labor Party affiliation. I understand that the ANAO has not gone down that track.

PARA.TAB: On that point, the Auditor-General has concluded that a register, such as OGIA's register of consultants, is an efficient and effective method of identifying the most appropriate creative agency for a given campaign. But he considers that alternative management arrangements should be examined with a view to making it more cost effective. I say amen to all that.
I underline Senator O'Chee's point that there is very little effective measurement of whether these very expensive advertising campaigns are meeting any of the objectives. The Auditor-General says:

SPEECH.PARA: Departments have not evaluated the success of campaigns against stated campaign objectives. In some instances, Departments did not fully understand the consequences of using certain evaluation techniques. Inadequacies in evaluation cast doubts on the claims for the success of some campaigns.
We are not talking about peanuts; we are talking about $200 million of Australian taxpayers' money. He goes on:

.with the exception of Defence, none of the campaigns' objectives derived by departments was expressed in quantitative terms. Campaigns typically do not include reference to performance measures. By not setting performance targets departments are not able to determine whether the campaign is likely to give value-for-money or at what stage it becomes uneconomic to undertake or continue the campaign.
This is absolutely damning from the Auditor-General. The report says that the government is spending many millions of dollars and does not know whether it is worthwhile to do so.

PARA.TAB: We then come to the question of whether the advertising is always correct. It is very disturbing to note in the Auditor-General's report a matter relating to advertising by the Australian Taxation Office. The Auditor-General considers that material to be disseminated should be accurate, comply with any applicable legislation and abide by advertising industry standards. He points out that two superannuation guarantee print advertisements, as put out by the Australian Taxation Office, were found by the Advertising Standards Council to be in breach of the advertising code of ethics. He says that, in the first instance, which was essentially a procedural problem, the Australian Taxation Office commenced its advertising for the superannuation guarantee campaign before the enabling legislation had been passed.

It is about time that it got caught by this. Quite frankly, I am sick and tired, as I am certain the Senate and the people of Australia are, of legislation by decree. The government says what it will do. Months and months later, the legislation eventually comes up before the chambers. In this case, the Australian Taxation Office subsequently had to withdraw the advertisements. The problem arose because of a clerical error associated with the passage of the legislation.
The Auditor-General says:

SPEECH.PARA: Departments may sometimes find themselves in a position where the introduction of Government initiatives is affected by delays or changes resulting from the legislative process or other circumstances beyond their control. It is recognised that these events may have an effect on the advertising content and campaign timetables.

Legislation is only legislation in effective terms after it has passed this chamber and received—I will continue to use these words—`royal assent'. It is not legislation just because some jumped-up lackey of this government says that it is. It is disgraceful that we have advertising campaigns undertaken before the legislation passes the chambers, which have a duty to turn it into effective law. It is about time that the government stopped pre-empting the parliament and wasting taxpayers' money on advertising laws that have not and will not come into effect because of clerical mistakes.

PARA.TAB: The second element is worse. In the second breach of the advertising code of ethics, the Advertising Standards Council ruled that another superannuation guarantee print advertisement was misleading and deceptive. That is a good description of the government. It is very disappointing to see that as a description of an advertisement put out by the Australian Taxation Office in relation to a superannuation guarantee campaign.

I am very concerned to read this Auditor-General report. It is phrased in very restrained language. I am also concerned about some other elements of it. For example, the Auditor-General says that some of the target audiences are a bit strange. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: DEET justified its use of television by stating that it wanted to reach the campaign's secondary target audience, `the general community'. However, without specific market research—
the Auditor says—
to establish the extent to which secondary target audiences influence primary target audiences, DEET ran the risk of wasting a significant amount of resources on this campaign.

A significant amount of resources in this case adds up to a fair few dollars. The DEET campaign was either $2.4 million or $0.5 million. The superannuation guarantee campaign cost something like $9 million. That is the one that did not meet the Advertising Standards Council requirements.

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General also notes that errors in central advertising system data indicate a weakness in OGIA's management of creative agency expenditure and its recording system. The Auditor also found this:

SPEECH.PARA: .departmental Annual Information Plans . . . do not perform their intended function;
.OGIA's creative agency shortlisting process may not always result in the Commonwealth achieving the best value-for-money. Nor, at the time of the audit, did OGIA document the shortlisting process.
I raised the next matter earlier:
.price does not enter into the consideration of the competitiveness of creative agencies' strategies . . .
.contracts are not used to appoint creative agencies to government advertising campaigns.

The Ministerial Committee on Government Information and Advertising requires departments to prepare and submit portfolio annual information plans for consideration. Annual information plans contain summaries of each major information activity that a portfolio intends to undertake in the coming financial year and each major activity undertaken in the past financial year.

PARA.TAB: The Australian National Audit Office questions the value added by AIPs at present because they were not considered by the MCGIA between September 1991 and 1994. A significant number of departments submit their AIPs well past the due date. Nearly 60 per cent of planned activities are not undertaken, and nearly half of the major activities actually undertaken are not recorded as planned activities on AIPs. The whole system is a farce. I am grateful to the Auditor-General for pointing it out. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment on Audit report No. 30 1994-95, which deals with Commonwealth government information and advertising. It is only normal for opposition parties to be disturbed when governments spend large whacks of taxpayers' money on so-called information campaigns. I am sure in Victoria and Western Australia, where we have Liberal state governments, that the opposition criticises those state governments about information campaigns on a regular basis.

PARA.TAB: In a society where the parliament must scrutinise government expenditure, it is very important to ensure that we are not moving into an Orwellian era where the government controls matters of information and tells the people what is good for them for political purposes. There is a very genuine need for governments at all levels to spend money, and sometimes considerable amounts of money, on education campaigns, particularly in relation to new government programs.

There are two reasons why I have always been amused by advertisements telling me how good Medicare is and how important it is that I am enthused about Medicare. The first reason is that I am not sure what my choice is if I do not like the product. In some respects I do like the product. It is very handy to have Medicare there when you have a couple of young children who continue to get earaches, runny noses and everything else. You can go to the doctor without worrying too much about the expense. The second reason is that people such as the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley)—who is at the table and who has a smile on her face at the moment—the Minister for Health (Dr Lawrence) and a number of other government ministers over the year reassure us about how popular Medicare is, how well received it is and how important it is to so many Australian families.

To be non-partisan and objective about it, a reflection of that is that Medicare and bulk-billing have become out of bounds as far as political tampering is concerned now. Of course, my leader, John Howard, made that quite clear in his speech last night when he committed the coalition to Medicare and to retaining bulk-billing. That is a very fair assessment of how well people understand Medicare and how attached they are to it. I do not know whether or not people are well aware of their entitlements under Medicare, because neither I nor the government have market tested it.

I think the assumption we could fairly make, even based on the fairly broad measure that all political parties in this country will not tamper with Medicare or bulk-billing, is that people understand Medicare pretty well and those who seek to tamper with bulk-billing or Medicare are very concerned about suffering the political ramifications of that. I think it is fair to say that in the last election the coalition did suffer. There were many people out there who were concerned about having their access to bulk-billing and some of the benefits of Medicare taken away. So that is a broad market test.

The parliament and all parliamentarians should be concerned when Commonwealth taxpayers' money is used for blatant political purposes ostensibly disguised as an information campaign. I was concerned when I turned to page 48, appendix 6, of the report—and I commend all journalists on the second floor of this building and our friend in the gallery today—and saw the amount of money spent in a month on that Medicare campaign.

If your objective were to `inform Australians as to their existing entitlements under the Medicare arrangements', you would expect that it would be an ongoing campaign. You would find out who did not understand what their entitlements were. There may well be some target groups, such as people from non-English speaking backgrounds. The target group may indeed be young people who have not had much access to the need for Medicare or medical service, because young people are generally fitter, and who may need to be informed of this. There may be all of those sorts of target groups and you would think that that campaign would go on for months, if not years, as a regular information period.

But clearly the Department of Health, which decided to run this campaign, made a decision that in about January and February of 1993 there was to be this massive need to ensure that we all knew how good Medicare was for us. It may only be a coincidence that the election was in March 1993. Out of the $3.3 million, I think, that was spent on the entire campaign—and 39 per cent of that was spent on the creative side of it, which is not unusual; it is important to have good advertisements before you spend the money putting them on television—and it is a bit hard to read between the lines, something in the order of $2 million was spent in the weeks before the 1993 federal election. And if we look at the graph we will see that it was only a matter of weeks. It is fair to say that the coalition and all other parliamentarians who are concerned to see the government spending taxpayers' money wisely could be a little cynical about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a look at page 45.

—Senator O'Chee has referred me to page 45. I presume we have another little blimp in the graph. I did look at that, Senator O'Chee. I would give the government almost the benefit of the doubt. Senator O'Chee refers to expenditure under a Commonwealth employment service marketing campaign operated by DEET. I toyed with the idea of criticising the government for that. But to be generous to the federal government, which is not my nature, that money was spent towards the end of 1992, again just before the federal election, and you would have to say that that is a period of the year when a lot of young people do come onto the job market and would need information.

PARA.TAB: However, to be slightly less generous, unemployment was extremely high in late 1992 and early 1993, but it was almost equally as high at the end of 1993 and at the end of 1994. If you look at the graphs you will see that nothing like the $1.4 million spent just before the last federal election was spent during those other times. Clearly the government decided that the young people did not need to know so much about the great services of the Commonwealth. I have been generous, but one could be cynical.

The Medicare campaign is an absolute ripper. Looking at the graph, and it is not very descriptive, it seems that the need to spend nearly $2 million fell almost entirely in the six weeks before the federal election. Kerry Packer, Rupert Murdoch and the other television station proprietors around Australia must have thought, `This is great. Let's have more elections. This is fantastic.' We must watch the share prices of the listed television companies. Since we are on broadcast day, these might be considered as Senator Campbell's share market tips—early election speculation: `Buy media stocks, because the government will spend up big with your money. If you want to get a bit of that money back, buy media stocks just before speculation of an election.'

More seriously, I did my own survey. I surveyed only 100 people. I will put the facts on the record. It was in the Perth metropolitan area and it was in relation to small businesses employing young people. I am happy to provide any honourable senator with the details of that survey I did. It was conducted about three weeks ago. It was to judge the effectiveness of the Working Nation statement initiatives. There has been a very high profile and, I suspect, an expensive campaign featuring Bill Hunter asking employers to employ young people under the Working Nation initiatives. My office surveyed 100 small businesses in that area of Perth. Only 37 per cent of them had heard of Working Nation. I remind honourable senators that this was two or three weeks ago. Only two small businesses had taken any action as a result of those advertisements.

There are loud and clear messages in the Auditor-General's report, which is an important one for both parties in state and federal government. The first one is to avoid using taxpayers' money for blatant political expenses, particularly just before an election. Quite frankly, that is corrupt. The second one is to ensure that you do your market research, look at the audience you are trying to reach, seek to reach that market and then evaluate after you have done the campaign. SPEECH.PARA: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1995-96

The purpose of this bill is to appropriate the Consolidated Revenue Fund for the running costs and capital expenditures of the parliamentary departments for the year ending 30 June 1996. The total amount sought is $144.5 million.
Details of the proposed expenditure are set out in the schedule to the bill. I commend the bill to the Senate.
APPROPRIATION BILL (NO. 1) 1995-96
This bill seeks appropriations of the Consolidated Revenue Fund in 1995-96 totalling $31,689.4 million.

Appropriation Bill (No. 1) provides for proposed expenditure on the ordinary annual services of Government. The expenditure program of the Government, to which the provisions in this bill relate, was outlined in the Treasuer's Budget speech, on 9 May.

Clause 4 of the bill provides for the appropriation of the Consolidated Revenue Fund to enable the Minister for Finance to issue an amount for the payment of increases in salary and payments in the nature of salary arising out of awards, orders or determinations made under, or in accordance with a law. Allowance has been included in the overall budget figuring for such prospective increases: that allowance is not, however, appropriated in advance of any increases being awarded.

Provision has also been made for the possible commencement, during the course of the financial year, of the Financial Management and Accountability Bill which is one of a package of bills the Government introduced in the last Sittings to replace the Audit Act 1901.
Details of the proposed expenditure are set out in the Schedule to the bill, the main features of which were outlined in the Treasurer's Budget Speech.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
APPROPRIATION BILL (NO. 2) 1995-96
This bill seeks appropriations of the Consolidated Revenue Fund in 1995-96 totalling $4,365.5 million.

Appropriation Bill (No. 2) provides for proposed expenditure on the construction of public works and buildings, the acquisition of sites and buildings, certain advances and loans, items of plant and equipment which are clearly definable as capital in nature, and expenditure on new policy initiatives for which legislation has not been previously approved. Provision is also made for grants to the States under section 96 of the Constitution and for payments to the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory.

As for the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) which was introduced earlier this evening, provision has been made in Appropriation Bill (No. 2) for the possible commencement, during the course of the financial year, of the Financial Management and Accountability Bill which is one of the package of bills the Government introduced in the last sittings to replace the Audit Act 1901.
Details of the proposed expenditure are set out in Schedule 2 to the bill, the main features of which were outlined in the Budget speech. I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill is a machinery financing measure to enable certain defence expenditures to be met from the Loan Fund rather than the Consolidated Revenue Fund and to supplement the moneys available to the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

Legally, expenditure from the Consolidated Revenue Fund cannot exceed the moneys available to that Fund. Successive Governments have adopted the practice of introducing a Loan Bill to authorise the issue of moneys from the Loan Fund to meet expenditures that have been appropriated by the Parliament, but for which insufficient funds are available in the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

The purpose of this bill is to make provision for the financing of the prospective deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund. While the Budget as a whole is anticipated to be in surplus in 1995-96, there is a prospective deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund of about $2.1 billion. The difference between the two estimated outcomes arises because appropriations from the CRF include various items which are functionally classified as financing transactions rather than outlays, and thus do not affect the Budget outcome. These items include superannuation payments made by the Commonwealth on behalf of public trading enterprises.

The bill provides authority for the Loan Fund to meet defence expenditures incurred in 1995-96 after the passage of the bill that would otherwise have been met from the Consolidated Revenue Fund and, if necessary, to supplement the Consolidated Revenue Fund so that it can meet its other commitments. The bill also provides the authority to raise loans to cover these payments from the Loan Fund.

Except for loan raising expenses, which are currently estimated at $9.7 million for 1995-96, the bill does not authorise expenditures additional to those already approved by, or currently before, the Parliament. I emphasise that the bill does not in any way impinge on the prerogative of the Parliament to appropriate moneys, but simply provides the means to finance expenditures previously approved and appropriated by the Parliament.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, it is nice to be able to get on to some sort of program. The time we have taken to get to this reflects the absolutely appalling mismanagement by this government—it has been going on for weeks and weeks and weeks.

PARA.TAB: The Qantas Sale Amendment Bill amends the principal Qantas Sale Act 1992 to increase the foreign ownership limit for Qantas from 35 per cent of issued capital to 49 per cent and restrict foreign airlines to holding no more than a combined 35 per cent of the issued share capital. This increase in the access of foreign investment is a manifestation of the bill's intention to increase the foreign ownership limit to facilitate an appropriate return to the Commonwealth.

It should be pointed out that, currently, Qantas is already 25 per cent owned by British Airways. And the bill, I might say, is very regrettably necessary because this Labor government has plundered the savings of all Australians to the extent that we are not capable of buying Qantas at a price which would not be achievable without increased levels of foreign equity. It enables Qantas to widen the market so that an achievable price can be obtained. It would not be necessary if we did not have among the lowest savings ratio in the world. Certainly, compared with South East Asia, our savings ratio is very low indeed. Anyway, this is the sorry state of affairs in which we find ourselves. One must be realistic and, for this reason, the opposition will not be opposing the bill.

The privatisation of Qantas is a move that the coalition supports for different reasons to the government. The government simply supports it because they want the money. The shifting of Qantas into the private sector, however, from a coalition point of view will enhance the competitive edge that Qantas has been successfully developing. The Qantas float will provide Australians with an opportunity to invest their savings into a genuine Australian business proposition as opposed to just the ALP's narrow and doubtful futuristic compulsory superannuation scheme.

This government will no doubt argue that it is promoting savings through the superannuation scheme. But I would make the differentiation that the government is pushing them into survival savings; it is not talking about net investment savings.

Whilst the coalition is in agreement with the purpose of the legislation, the sale of Qantas has been a very sorry exposition of Labor Party incompetence, mismanagement and the subject of budgetary deception.

The sale of Qantas has now been on the last five budgets. And in every single one of these budgets the prospective sale of Qantas has played a cosmetic role—it has simply been there to fool the Australian people.

The government, through its now legendary mismanagement of the economy, has exploited the prospectus of various Commonwealth assets to cover its misdeeds and consequent predicament with the deficit. After years of grand expenditure from this tax and spend government, the ALP has created a budget deficit that has posed a threat to their re-election. The prospective Qantas float has been utilised to create a spurious budget surplus among other asset sales.

The opinion that the decision to increase foreign ownership in Qantas will increase the value of the float by some $300 million—the estimates given in some quarters—constitutes the motive of the government in perpetrating its budgetary fraud, the fraud that the government has been responsible with its fiscal policy and has delivered a budget that has ensured the health of the Australian economy. Everyone knows how transparent that is. There is no budget surplus this year in real terms; it is a budget deficit.

The government's track record on privatisation is by no means impressive. When you look at the facts, the proceeds from privatisation since the ALP have been in government have been below budget estimates by $5.1 billion—$5,100 million!

The government should stop exploiting asset sales to suggest that it has been in charge of an economically judicious administration—privatisation does not whitewash years of electorally expedient fiscal irresponsibility which has become the hallmark of the Keating Labour government.
The sale of Qantas, whilst an intrinsically virtuous policy, has been cynically recruited by the government into a meretricious budget which has a bottom line deficit.

The Qantas privatisation has endured a tortured and sclerotic evolution. This becomes apparent when you have a brief look at its history. The timetable for the float has been progressively delayed by the government from beginning to end.

In 1988 Qantas and the former Australian Airlines were faced with uncommercial debt to equity ratios and therefore reasoned with the government about the possibility of greater access to equity capital. One of the few rational people who addressed this was ex-Senator Walsh who took the view—I think this is expressed in his recent book, for those who have taken the trouble to read it and, if they have not, they should—that it seemed fairly silly to him that year in, year out taxpayers were putting money into a commercial operation which could well have been done in the private sector.

The government finally responded to this call in September 1990 by deciding to sell 100 per cent of Australian Airlines and 49 per cent of Qantas. In April 1991 the government announced that the float of both airlines would be done as a trade sale. In June 1992 the announcement came that Qantas would be able to purchase Australian Airlines for $400 million and with 100 per cent rather than 49 per cent. In fact, interestingly, we have more icons of the old Labor Party thundering down, not because of any change in philosophy but simply because of the fact that, due to their own economic mismanagement, they want the money.

The Qantas articles of association were designed to safeguard the national interest. The most salient of these national interest protecting articles of association was the 35 per cent foreign holdings restriction on which the then Minister for Finance, Ralph Willis, made the following comments:

These safeguards are important to maintain the basic character of Qantas, as well as to ensure that Qantas's operating rights under Australia's various bilateral air service agreements and arrangements with other countries are not put under threat. Once in legislation, these safeguards will not be subject to the whim of the government of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: He said they `will not be subject to the whim of the government of the day' when those opposite fixed the lid at 35 per cent. But they have been creeping up on the old lefties like Senator Burns, year in year out.

PARA.TAB: In the moveable feast of the Labor Qantas sale, the ALP threw away the cookbook a long time ago. It has been making it up as it goes along. After making this supposedly iron clad announcement, it is now allowing foreign ownership to go up to 49 per cent. The government did that because it needed the money. Probably more importantly, as I mentioned at the beginning of my remarks, this government over a period of 12 or 13 years has plundered the savings of Australians through our taxation system, not only in the direct taxation system by way of income tax, not only by way of indirect taxes which have risen so enormously in the past 12 years, but by there being a penalty on people who save and invest. Until that is addressed, we will not fix the incredible problem we have with low household savings in Australia.

One does question the commitment of the Labor Party to the intrinsic reason for privatisation as a sound economic restructuring policy, as opposed to an instrument of its budget. It is clear from remarks made by various members of the Labor Party—members of parliament on the other side and, I think, some senators here—that the Labor Party is far from any ideological consensus on the subject of the privatisation of Qantas. In fact, there is no Labor commitment to the intrinsic value of the Qantas float; the commitment is simply to cook the books in the budgets we are given by this government year in, year out. This has been going on for some years.

The Labor Party's whole program of privatisation has been as disingenuous as it has been a manifest example of maladministration. There is no doubt that markets in Australia have been freed up and, as has been said over and over, that is a good thing. It has made us competitive in some areas. But what has not happened is that the Labor market has been freed up. We cannot have one section of the market freed up and the other not, because one will counter the other. That is what is happening in this country. We know why. The people who write the laws for this government are part of the unelected ACTU.

The problem with the government's program of privatisation is that it has been disorganised and disorderly, careering around in a ramshackle fashion, making up a new direction on every one of its whims. Qantas is a serious international business that requires the vision and discipline of a forward looking government.

I have a long association with Qantas. I suppose there might not be anyone else in this place who first flew with Qantas when I did. If my recollection is right, it was around October or November 1941. That is a long time to be flying with Qantas. I have seen that airline grow. My state has a close affinity with Qantas, shown by the very name: Queensland and Northern Territory Aerial Services. We have been very proud that its origins were in Queensland. It must be remembered that when Qantas started it was a privately owned company. It was only when Labor governments started thinking they should own airlines that this position changed.

The opposition does not oppose the bill. The reason for the bill, as I pointed out, is that there are not sufficient domestic savings in Australia to maximise revenue from the sale. The savings of people from other countries have to be included in the equation, in order to maximise the return. I do not dispute that there should be a fair market price for Qantas shares. That is very important, bearing in mind all the moneys put into Qantas over the years. It is only right that when the sale is made it should be done in a way that maximises that return. I am also aware of the fact that the reason for the increase in foreign ownership was to enable Qantas to broaden its market, because the market in Australia, in respect of funds available for investment, was too narrow. Again, that re-emphasises the point I made earlier, that this Labor government has plundered the savings of ordinary Australians.

The government, through its policy, has really stripped Australians of their savings. Under Labor, there is an in-built disincentive to save. I read comments by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) the other day. He was complaining, `The trouble with Japan is they save too much.' I think he then referred to `Australia' but he may well have said `the United States' when he said, `Australians spend too much.' The question of why that occurs has never been addressed. We do not have to do a survey and employ a consultant to find that out. The reason is that if people are frugal, put money aside and wish to invest it, they will be paying income tax at the highest marginal rate.

Even though one would have expected—with the decrease in the inflation rate from the high figures of the mid-1980s and so on—there to have been more of an incentive to save, that has not happened because of the attitude of this government, `If you save you must be rich; and we will tax you.' But most people are not rich and this attitude is now coming home to haunt us. The only way we can be sure of maximising a return on the sale of the balance of Qantas is to look overseas to get more money in the pot, thus creating a bigger market.

The legislation recognises the state of our affairs. The majority of Australians—I am one, for sure—would prefer to see a great company such as this totally in the hands of Australian shareholders. There is no doubt about that. However, we cannot get away from the real world. As I have explained a number of times in the second reading debate, we do not have sufficient investment capital in this country to ensure a maximum price. Therefore, we have no option but to support this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Qantas Sale Amendment Bill seeks to do two things. First, it seeks to increase the total level of foreign ownership in Qantas from 35 per cent to 49 per cent. Second, it seeks to prevent the sale of more than 35 per cent of the airline to foreign-owned airlines. The government tells us that this will bring the ownership in Qantas in line with the general rules governing the ownership of Ansett. Those rules are already inserted into the Air Navigation Act.

PARA.TAB: It is instructive to look at the reasons why the government has chosen to increase the foreign ownership level of Qantas. That increases the number of potential bidders, thereby increasing the total potential price. At one level, this is a very grubby revenue raising exercise. The principle that the national carrier should be nationally owned has to be abandoned. We would say as Australian Democrats that in some respects that has been sacrificed at the altar of the finance department, which runs revenue maximisation.

Why do we need to go off-shore to maximise the return on selling Qantas? Senator Parer has talked about that; and I agree. We do not have the capital in this country—and those who do, do not always choose to invest in Australia. We should not overlook the fact that the federal government and the state governments are at the moment selling so many publicly owned assets that they are probably in danger of swamping the local financial market.

Over the next three years the federal government alone is proposing nearly $9 billion of asset sales. At the same time, the states are gearing up to sell off banks, TABs, water authorities, power stations, the right to build roads, and so forth. This new living, breathing entity called the Australian financial market is not an unlimited drip of money. With our low rate of national savings there is only so much money that can be found in this country to buy privatised bodies. Inevitably, money will be needed and it will come either by Australians borrowing overseas to fund their purchases or foreigners investing directly from overseas.

In an attempt to stabilise our huge foreign debt the government, in our view, has rubber stamped a massive swap of debt for equity. As a nation we are still living beyond our means but, instead of borrowing the money, we are selling off the silver to pay the bills. What a choice we have! In the past 10 years the total level of foreign ownership of Australian assets has increased from $36 billion to $156.8 billion. In 1987, profits paid overseas accounted for just two per cent of our income from exports. Now it is over eight per cent and growing rapidly. The item, repayments on foreign investment, is one of the fastest growing items on our huge and deteriorating current account deficit.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been for seven or eight years.

—Yes, and growing. The Australian Democrats are not opposed to foreign investment but, as pointed out by Mr Vince FitzGerald, servicing of equity is usually more expensive—and more long term—than the servicing of debt. Swapping debt for equity can, in the short term, make the current account look better but it is worse over the long term, leading to interest rate rises, unemployment, and business confidence being worse than it would otherwise have been.

PARA.TAB: As FitzGerald points out, the key consideration must be whether the investment is likely to increase Australia's overall economy: for example, by opening up new export markets or introducing new technologies and increasing productivity. At the moment it still seems to be assumed as a matter of faith that all foreign investment and ownership achieves this. I do not think we have asked enough questions. I do not think we have tested the faith on this sufficiently.

We have to ask: have any of these sales achieved any of the export or productivity goals that Vince FitzGerald talks about? Could these goals have been achieved by other means? This has not been tested, particularly since 1986 and the then Treasurer Paul Keating's decision to change the test for approving foreign buyouts from one of having to prove net economic benefit to Australia, to the test of `not contrary to the national interest'. Around the same time, the `opportunities test'—that is, checking whether there was an equal Australian bid on offer—was also abandoned. This is particularly relevant in the recent public debate in this country on the sale of Fairfax.

Economists will tell us that also included in any test of the benefit of a foreign sale should be where the Australian funds and resources released by the sale are next employed. This is difficult, if not impossible, to measure. But it does appear that resources, instead of being reinvested in other productive enterprises, are going into three areas: private consumption, non-productive investment and overseas.

In our view, foreign investment must be a partnership of measurable benefit to the nation. I would want to argue most strongly that national interest goals can still exist within a rapidly globalising world economy. The balance can be achieved, but I am afraid that it is something in which this government has, over the last decade, demonstrated a complete lack of interest.

The Australian Democrats believe that, rather than continuing to live beyond our means by borrowing to cover up inadequate national savings, Australia should be concentrating on improving our trade performance, our national savings, and the quality and productiveness of investments funded by our scarce savings. Foreign investment policy should fit into this overall strategy and not consist of simply opening the door and putting a `for sale' sign on it.

The Foreign Investment Review Board has totally failed in its vitally important role of ensuring that foreign investment decisions are not contrary to the national interest. This was clearly demonstrated in the majority report of the Senate Select Committee looking at the Fairfax takeover. I note that the final report of that committee was presented in late March, triggering the 90-day deadline for a government response.

For some time I considered asking the opposition to consider delaying the passage of this bill subject to the government's response because it seems to me to be quite irresponsible of us to say, `Don't worry about what happened with Fairfax. It will not happen again with the sale of Qantas because the Foreign Investment Review Board is a reformed body now. It really listens to what is said'. We have had no government response. I have no confidence that anything has changed and that the national interest in the sale of Qantas will be treated any differently from the national interest in the sale of Fairfax. That is why I prepared the second reading amendment which I have circulated in the chamber.

This particular act requires any new owner to keep the name Qantas. What will it be attached to? The buyers of Fairfax told the Foreign Investment Review Board, `We will have an Australian chief executive officer'. It did not, and it does not, and nothing has been said or done. Nothing has changed to give the Australian Democrats any greater confidence that the national interest goal will be pursued as a result of increasing foreign investment as part of the Qantas sale.

The Australian Democrats would have been prepared to support this bill without qualification if we could have been assured that the Foreign Investment Review Board would conduct a rigorous, transparent—that is very important—and national interest focused assessment of any investment proposals for Qantas. In the absence of the reform of the Foreign Investment Review Board I do not have confidence that that will happen.

I move our second reading amendment to register our disquiet at the government's lack of response to the important issues raised in the Senate Select Committee's report. As a sign of goodwill I say, reluctantly, that we have decided not to continue with our proposal to delay passage of this bill. But I hope we can revisit the reform of the Foreign Investment Review Board debate when the government presents its response. I move:
At the end of the motion, add:
"but the Senate deplores the failure of the Government:
(a)to respond to the recommendations of the first report of the Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of Foreign Ownership Decisions in Relation to the Print Media; and

(b)to have put in place new procedures for the Foreign Investment Review Board with a stronger assessment of whether a proposed investment is contrary to the national interest and whether an equal Australian bid is available, prior to consideration of any application for foreign investors to purchase part of Qantas".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleague Senator parer on the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill 1995. At the risk of repeating what has already been said, the coalition will not oppose the bill. This bill amends the Qantas Sale Act 1992 and is going to increase the foreign ownership limit of Qantas privatisation from 35 per cent of issued capital to 49 per cent and will restrict foreign airlines to holding no more than a combined 35 per cent of issued share capital.

PARA.TAB: I think we should look back at the Qantas Sale Act 1992. In 1992 this government announced, after a lot of toing-and-froing, that 100 per cent of Qantas would be sold. The community's interest was said to be protected by a number of national interest safeguards. Senator Kernot has shown a lot of concern about that aspect here tonight.

Other provisions included: the total foreign ownership was not to exceed 35 per cent and no single foreign interest could exceed 25 per cent; Qantas's operational base and headquarters was to remain in Australia; the name Qantas would be preserved for the company's scheduled international passenger services; the company would be incorporated in Australia; and at least two-thirds of the Qantas board would be Australian citizens.

Also, in the Qantas Sale Act 1992, the chairman of the board was to be Australian and the directors were to be provided with broad powers, including the power to deny registration or to force the disposal of shares held by foreigners to ensure that foreign ownership limits were not breached. The 1992 act also imposed a restriction to prevent votes of substantial foreign shareholdings, defined as being more than 15 per cent of voting shares in Qantas, being counted in any vote to appoint or remove more than one-third of the directors of Qantas at any given time.

We are going to be changing the 1992 act. Mr Willis, in his second reading speech on 4 November—and I think Senator Parer must have been looking over my shoulder when I put my speech together because he quoted the same thing, but I will just say it again—said:

SPEECH.PARA: These safeguards are important to maintain the basic character of Qantas, as well as to ensure that Qantas's operating rights under Australia's various bilateral air service agreements and arrangements with other countries are not put under threat. Once in legislation, these safeguards will not be subject to the whim of the government of the day.
The whim of the government has changed, as we would expect. It is whimming here; it is whimming there; and it is whimming all over the place.

PARA.TAB: While we are talking about the whim of the government, I will just remind the Senate that the 1992 One Nation statement announced an open skies agreement with New Zealand, which by November 1994 would allow Air New Zealand to compete in the domestic Australian market and open up the New Zealand market for Australian players. The government found out last year that this agreement would not benefit Qantas and, in fact, would have a substantial negative impact on its profitability. Then we found the Keating government re-enacting the underarm bowling incident and reneging on the agreement at the eleventh hour. I can tell you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that the New Zealand people that I speak to, whether they be parliamentarians or ordinary people, have not forgotten the underarm bowling incident and keep reminding me about what happened with this supposedly open skies agreement. So Australia, once again, through the efforts of this government, has had to hang its collective head in shame at these embarrassing antics and whims and philanderings.

We all know why the whim of the government has changed. It wants to prop up its shonky budget and con the Australian people once again. The only reason the government wants to increase foreign ownership is to get its grubby little hands on more cash, and the quicker the better. This government needs more cash to fund its budget, to finance its supposed surplus. It wants an extra $200 million to shore up this fudge-it budget.

We heard about this here yesterday in question time. The Keating government's surplus is nothing like the real surpluses of real economies like New Zealand's. The New Zealand government surplus is a real surplus which is going to pass on real tax cuts—not superannuation contributions that some people might be lucky enough to get from 1997 onwards. In this particular case, as has been said by two previous speakers, it is like selling the family home to buy the groceries.

I, too, like my colleague Senator Parer, am very proud of our national carrier and believe it must remain a part of the Australian identity. The flying kangaroo signifies a lot of things to a lot of people—getting home or the big trip away. I remember very well that in the film Rain Man it meant a lot to Dustin Hoffman, who was playing the part of rain man. When he was asked which was the safest airline in the world, he said, `Qantas.'

It has a great tradition, but a lot of people are going to be disappointed. The reason they are going to be disappointed is that, for the wrong reasons, the government is selling off this airline at a time when we have the highest interest rates in the OECD; at a time when we have the highest sales taxing government in our history; and at a time when the value of the Australian dollar is dropping. I will tell you what—anybody from overseas buying into Qantas will be buying in at a bargain rate because of the price of our dollar at the moment.

Regrettably, we have heard all this before, of course—this new-found privatisation ethos of the government. We have seen what has happened with the Commonwealth Bank. The government was not going to sell half of that, but ended up doing so because it wanted some more money for this so-called surplus that it is creating. It sold off the other half of the Commonwealth Bank, which it was never going to do, to the point where Mr Willis put out a false prospectus. Because he is the Treasurer and it is the government doing it, nothing will happen, but if you or I did that, we would end up in gaol or be heavily fined.

We can look at some of the other problems being faced by the privatisation program of this government. The government does not seem to know how privatisation works, and we only have to look at the proposed sale of the ANL to see that. So it is no wonder the government, when it considered selling Qantas, had to get in the Rowland Company to implement a communications strategy to encourage widespread public participation. It is no wonder it had to get Ernst and Young Registry Services as a share registrar. It is no wonder it had to get Reark Research to conduct a qualitative and quantitative research to gauge investor interest.

On top of that, we find that it is going to spend $20 million through the John Singleton Advertising company's ALP campaign. I noticed an article this week which said that high fliers were helping to get the Qantas float off the ground. The article mentions people like Kate Ceberano, Mandawuy Yunupingu and Paul Mercurio. I just hope they have enough money to be able to invest in Qantas. If they have spent their money investing in the Commonwealth Bank and a few of these other areas that the government is going to privatise, as Senator Kernot pointed out, there might not be too much money left around to invest in anything.

Why would the government then turn around and spend $20 million on this campaign? There have been some serious doubts raised about this advertising campaign. Questions could be asked on another day about why the favoured tenderer for this particular campaign was John Singleton, but I will not go into that today.

We ask ourselves what is privatisation really all about? What is real privatisation—not the phoney sort of privatisation for all the wrong reasons that this government is going on with. The coalition, on the other hand, has had a long history of support for privatisation. Our support is a philosophical one and so far different from the attitude of government. Our belief in privatisation starts with the ability of the private sector to provide the same goods and services more effectively and efficiently. That is one of the reasons why we privatise—to allow the private sector to provide those services in a more efficient manner. The community service obligations of government must be part of the private sector management.

The second main aim of privatisation is that any proceeds of these sales must, and I repeat `must', be used to reduce our public indebtedness. Australians, as we all know, must increase their private savings, and Senator Kernot raised that matter quite strongly. The coalition sees privatisation as a way of increasing the number of Australians who are investing in Australia. But, if there is not a national savings policy, there will not be enough people with enough money to invest in all these enterprises that are being privatised. The only view that we get from the government is this very narrow view that, as far as national savings is concerned, its idea is compulsory superannuation. It thinks that is the only way to increase the private savings of Australians. It is a rather blinkered approach.

There are other ways. Senator Parer mentioned the Japanese and their savings. They have had a compulsory savings scheme since the war, since the rehabilitation of Japan. It is through that scheme that they have had so much capital with which to expand into investment, manufacturing and the like. The same goes for Singapore. But in this country we have never had a decent national savings scheme.

I want to make a few general comments about privatisation. For a long time, privatisation was a dirty word as far as particular sections of the Labor Party were concerned. There were a lot of doubts about there being any advantages to privatisation. But there is international evidence that privatisation works, particularly in higher or middle income countries.

The World Bank estimates that, around the world, 15,000 separate state owned enterprises have been privatised since 1990. The same research demonstrates increases in domestic welfare and productivity as a result. In most cases identified by the World Bank, consumers have benefited or, at worst, were no worse off.

I know that privatisation does not come easily to a Labor government. It certainly transgresses the political ideology of the Left wing. This has led to some division and resentment within the party. It has also meant that we have inherited an ad hoc approach to privatisation rather than a detailed strategic plan for privatisation over a period of time.

As Senator Kernot said, we have something like $9 billion worth of possible projects that will come onto the market in one big hit. I have already mentioned the problems with the Australian National Line. That is a fair indication of this government's failure to understand how privatisation works. The Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton, has already indicated publicly that ANL is in such a bad condition that the government could not give it away. That is a bit of an indictment on the government's attitude to privatisation and the way in which it runs those enterprises. The debate over the sale of the Federal Airports Corporation has also left the community wondering where the government is heading.

If the government wants to look at some decent examples of privatisation, it need go no further than the Port of Auckland in New Zealand where privatisation has reduced running costs by 43 per cent in real terms. In England, when the Tilbury docks were privatised as part of a management-staff buy-out, shareholders saw the value of their shares increase from #1 to #11 in only 2 1/2 years. That is the way you do it.

There have been some successes in Australia—I am not going to be all negative—such as the privatisation of the coal loaders at Port Kembla, which has already proven its worth. Costs have fallen by 22 per cent in the first year after privatisation in 1990. I just wonder when we are going to see action on some of the other waterfronts. We have seen a bit of action in Western Australia but it has been the wrong sort of action.

As I said, we are privatising for the wrong reasons. The government is desperate for cash. It looked at Qantas and said, `Gosh, it has been on the shelf for five years. We had better dust it off, change the act and get some more foreign ownership in.' It is a bit like a used car that you have had sitting in the yard for three or four years trying to flog it. You spend a bit of money on it, you tart it up—put some mag wheels on it and a stripe down the side—and hope you will get rid of it. That is what the government is doing with Qantas. It is making it more attractive by allowing more foreign ownership so it can get a better price for it. But in the scheme of things, that is not the way it should have been done. It has been done for all the wrong motives.

Although the coalition will not be opposing the bill, our ideas and beliefs on privatisation are in total contradiction to those of the government. The government's motives are sneaky and shoddy. It is trying to prop up the fudge-it budget. It is only interested in the money, not in gaining real benefits for the country, which is what we should be looking for. We need to reduce our foreign debt. We need to apply the benefit of privatisation for the good of all Australians. Unfortunately, this measure is being rushed through to allow the government to portray this budget as a budget in surplus when, as we all know, it has been a smoke and mirrors trick.

We know that by bringing money from overseas it will not help our foreign debt situation. As Senator Kernot so ably said, the servicing of equity is far more expensive than the servicing of debt. All in all, while we do not oppose this sale of Qantas we believe that the government has shown once again that it is not capable of privatising correctly let alone running the country in the way it should be run. It certainly cannot present the sorts of budgets we need.

TALK.START.PARA: —My comments in regard to the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill will be brief. I am probably a bit sadder than most people in this place about the passage of this bill because, as I have mentioned before in this place, I was an employee of Qantas for six years in the 1970s. That was a time when the employees of that organisation were very proud of our standards of service, not just the on-board standards—the flashy giveaways, the frequent flyer points, and so on—but the standards of training and the standard of service provided to the industry.

PARA.TAB: The fight to retain a national airline is already lost. Qantas will be privatised. In spite of many community objections to privatisation, it has already gone. In some sense, as with other government business enterprises, it was lost as an effectively publicly owned enterprise operating in the public interest when it was corporatised. To a certain extent, Qantas has always operated in a mode quite different from the Public Service. It was always working within a competitive environment which, with various levels of industry deregulation, has become more and more cut-throat.

What you do not see are the bits behind the front of an airline. They include such things as pre-flighting, which I do not think exists so much any more. Pre-flighting means preparing for the flight, actually making sure that those booked were going. We did not have the situation of regularly overbooking and hoping those people did not turn up. It also meant preparing for people with medical problems, for children travelling alone, making sure they were looked after. I cannot tell you with any certainty how Qantas operates now in relation to pre-flight but I can say it was one of those areas on which there was a lot of emphasis in the 1970s.

At the point of corporatisation the government effectively said that public interest was no longer its prime consideration in operating the national carrier. It would be just as if the Commonwealth had shares in a normal company: the company would not pursue non-commercial community objectives.

I indicate at this stage that the Greens will be supporting the second reading amendments of the Australian Democrats. We believe that any measures that try to make sure that public interest is incorporated into the sale and privatisation of Qantas should be supported.

But what about this bill? We still have concerns that cost cutting by privatisation will mean that Qantas will lose its status as the safest airline in the world. We are still concerned that Qantas, on its domestic routes, will make commercial decisions not to fly the less heavily loaded routes and, in the process, eliminate air transport to smaller and more isolated parts of the country. Will this bill make that more likely or make things worse? I cannot say that positively. I am fairly certain that giving greater control to foreign shareholders will not make things any better in this regard.

This bill will not improve anything. There is no reason that we can see to support it, and we will not. There is no reason to pass more control of any interests overseas. The government keeps some impression of Australian control by setting foreign equity at a limit of 49 per cent. What a joke! Anyone who knows much about corporate control knows that effective control does not require absolute control through 50 per cent of share ownership. The effect of dispersing shareholding in Australia through selling to many shareholders is to increase the relative power of larger shareholders. A more effective mechanism of maintaining a measure of national control could be to demand that at least 50 per cent of foreign ownership be through small share sales on foreign exchanges, rather than allowing British Airways to get 25 per cent and another foreign airline to get 10 per cent, with the remaining 14 per cent potentially held in the hands of one or two `foreign persons', which I assume include foreign companies other than airlines.

Basically, what we see here is the passage of another icon, along with Vegemite and most of our other processed food companies, to overseas hands. We move one step closer to turning Australia into a company town in which we are all tenants. This is not a plug for nationalism; it is a plug for community interests. Australia was one of the first countries in the world which had an airline because of the distances in Australia. We need to look at our transport routes and what we will do with them.

I suggest that today is a very sad day. I am pleased to see the opposition recognise the cynicism associated with this bill, but it is sad to see that, whichever way it goes, however badly it is organised, it will still support the bill. I would like to think that there will be some mechanism by which all government business enterprises can answer to public interest, even though there is a greater level of privatisation. I have yet to see any evidence that the government has the mechanisms or the political will to enforce this. I have yet to be convinced. I hope very sincerely that it will be doing that in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to support my colleagues Senator Calvert and Senator Parer in their remarks on the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill 1995. This is an important bill. It is certainly an important bill for the government. It is rendered necessary through the government's desperate lack of cash and the need to find some money to bridge the huge gap between its expenditure and its revenue before taking assets sales into account. A final figure for the float of 75 per cent of Qantas is not specifically known as yet and will not be known until the proceeds are in. According to the Department of Finance in the Senate estimates process, it is envisaged that the float will take place in the next couple of months. We could see the proceeds in August if, for once in the government's history, it gets the handling of this bill right.

PARA.TAB: Last year when the Qantas amendment bill was debated, it was said that the 75 per cent could be worth somewhere between $2 billion and $2.3 billion. The fact that this bill is extending the permissible amount of foreign ownership presumably will mean that the government expects to get some more money as a result.
