If we stick another couple of hundred million dollars onto that, we could well be looking at proceeds of $2 1/2 billion. That will be a major contribution towards the $5 1/2 billion of assets sales that the government has planned in this budget to meet the gap between its expenditure and its revenue.

The tragedy is that the government is using the proceeds of assets sales to meet recurrent expenditure. But the only legitimate financial consequence of assets sales is to reduce the public debt. The fact that the government will be using the proceeds of the Qantas float only to meet its recurrent expenditure is a tragedy. In essence, it means that the government is selling off its prized assets so that it can pay for its groceries. That is what the government is doing.

We have debated the sale of Qantas for a long time. In preparing some of the background notes for my contribution, I went back to an urgency debate that took place six years ago yesterday, on 6 June 1989. The opposition moved a matter of urgency; namely, the need for the government to ensure the future of Qantas and Australian Airlines by their sale to the public as suggested by the Minister for Transport and Communications and supported by the Prime Minister. The reason we moved that urgency debate in June 1989 was that we believed the only way to get real efficiency and competition and to maximise the resources and asset of the airlines was to privatise them.

The tragedy at that time was that the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis, and the present Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, along with Senator Button and Senator Peter Walsh, agreed with the coalition about the need to privatise Qantas. They were rolled by the left wing of the Labor Party at that time. They were rolled on several other significant occasions after that before they managed to break the deadlock that existed within the Labor Party at that time.

It was a progressive breaking of the deadlock, and it is only in the last couple of years that we have seen the government agree to the sale of 100 per cent of Qantas. It is only in the last month that we have seen the government prepared to make such provisions in relation to foreign ownership so that the sale might proceed expeditiously with proceeds being appropriately received. The purpose of the bill before us today is to increase the foreign ownership limit that presently exists from 35 of issued capital to 49 per cent, to restrict the individual foreign airlines' holdings to no more than 25 per cent of the issued share capital—that is what the present act does—and to restrict foreign airlines in their holdings of the percentage of issued capital of Qantas.

This bill will increase the total foreign ownership limit for issued capital from the existing 35 per cent up to 49 per cent. It will restrict foreign airlines to holding no more than 35 per cent within that 49 per cent and it will restrict any individual foreign airline from holding no more than 25 per cent of the issued capital of Qantas. The government has put that proposal forward. The opposition is not opposing the bill. Indeed, we support the bill because it accords with the principle that we have always had in relation to privatisation—namely, that if you really want to have an efficient airline and get the greatest benefit from the very expensive and extensive assets that are tied up in airlines, privatisation is the way to go. There is no reason whatsoever for governments to be in the business of owning and running airlines.

There is a very significant difference in our approach to the rationale of this matter compared to that of the government. There is only one reason why the government is proceeding down this privatisation path. That is because it want to get its hands on the cash that it can raise from the sale of Qantas more quickly than might otherwise be the case so that it can try to fill the gap in its budget. In any case, in my view it will have a hole because the prospect of the government meeting the forecast that it has set itself in the budget for expenditure and revenue is very unlikely.

The government's track record on privatisation over the years is quite appalling. In the year concluding at the end of this month it budgeted for asset sale proceeds of about $2.7 billion. Indeed, it may have been a little higher. The actual expectation of proceeds from asset sales in this financial year is now $55 million. In other words, it has raised virtually nothing compared to the several billion dollars that it planned when it formulated its budget last year.

In November last year the government came to us with yet another Qantas amendment bill. The purpose of that bill was to extend the date for possible completion of the sale into the 1995-96 budget year. In the course of that debate we said two things that have proven to be totally correct. Firstly, we said that the government could have difficulty finding sufficient local take-up of the float and therefore it may have to return to the parliament to seek further change to the Qantas Sale Act in relation to foreign shareholdings—in other words, to increase the foreign shareholding permissible. That is precisely what this bill is doing. I do not want to say, `I told you so' but that is the case if we look at the debates of 30 November 1994 on this matter.

I notice that Senator Cook is handling this bill at the moment for the government. That is good because I wanted to point out to him the second thing that we said that has proven to be correct. During the debate on 30 November last year I raised the question—Senator Cook attempted to belittle me on it—of what would happen to the government's budget for 1994-95 if the sale of Qantas was not completed within the 1994-95 financial year. I also asked what contingency plans the government may have to fill the hole in the budget that would therefore have arisen. The response I got from Senator Cook was that the concern that I had raised about a hole being created in the 1994-95 budget `would not arise.' The fact is that a hole did arise. The sale will not be completed by the end of 1994-95.

It now looks as if at long last the sale of Qantas, which has been in the government's budget for the fourth successive year, will actually proceed to finality. We certainly hope it will because the government's handling of this issue, going back many years, has been quite appalling. As a result, I believe the government has missed many opportunities that should have been taken for the sale. Ministers were originally talking about the need for the sale of assets such as Qantas as far back as 1989. If we checked the record we would be able to go back further than that.

In the last six years we have seen a tortuous situation and for the last four to five years we have seen the tortured situation whereby the government has been trying to do things to sell the airline but has handled it so appallingly in a variety of policy areas that the sale has not been possible. We have seen the government chopping and changing its transport policies. The government was involved in tremendous difficulties and backflipping within its own ranks on the whole question of foreign ownership.

Last year we had the appalling situation where with less than a week's notice the Transport Minister, Laurie Brereton, pulled the pin on air navigation rights and agreements with New Zealand—a most distressing debacle in terms of relations between our two countries. It has gone on and on and the government has been unable to get its act together in any shape or form. Fortunately it now appears that the circumstances have arisen whereby we may at last see finality in this matter. Certainly from the coalition's point of view, we hope that that is the case.

The reasons and the rationale behind the government's sale of Qantas is very different from the coalition's. The government wants to get its sticky fingers on some cash. That is really the only thing driving the government's sale of Qantas, which compares very starkly with the reasons why we on this side of the chamber have always supported and argued for the sale. It has been our policy for many years to sell Qantas for very good and proper reasons. There are three main reasons. Firstly, we want to privatise Qantas because we believe that the path of privatisation is the path that leads to the most effective and efficient use of the nation's assets and the maximisation of the benefit to consumers that efficient utilisation of assets brings.

Secondly, as I said before, we believe that the proceeds of privatisation should be used almost exclusively for the retirement of public debt. That is not the case with this government. Indeed, we have seen over the last five years the government's outstanding public debt absolutely skyrocket from a figure of $25 billion to $30 billion to a figure now of about $95 billion. None of the proceeds of the Qantas sale in 1995-96 are going towards the reduction of that very dangerously high level of debt. It is such a high level of debt that the interest bill on it alone exceeds what the government spends on defence and is of the same order as it spends on education. As a result of that squandering by the government, the taxpayers are having to meet interest bills that exceed the total defence budget in this country.

The third reason why we go down the privatisation route—we regard it as a very important element in any privatisation—is that we want to increase private savings through the introduction of employee share ownership schemes. I do not know whether the government has any plans which are able to be announced in relation to share ownership schemes. When I asked that question of the minister last year during the debate, he said that no decisions had been taken on share ownership schemes and that decisions were still pending. I hope that in his reply to the contributions by coalition senators to the second reading debate that will be one of the important matters that he takes on board. Indeed, I hope it is a very positive response because if there are no adequate employee share ownership schemes involved in this float, that will be a very significant factor missing from what is otherwise required.

I wanted to make those points in the debate. As has been said by my colleagues, the coalition supports the bill. We hope that at long last we are nearing the end of this tortuous route towards the final sale of Qantas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak on this matter because it is an area of public policy in which I have taken a long interest, probably spanning back to about 1983 or 1984 when I invited to Australia Dr Madsen Pirie from the Adam Smith Institute, who did a lecture tour of Australia. I am not sure whether Senator Cook was actually in the parliament by then but the Labor Party at that time spent a lot of its campaign funds hiring people like Graham Kennedy to lampoon the coalition's nasty idea of selling off the silver to pay the butler and selling off the national jewels.

PARA.TAB: I am genuinely pleased that the government has seen, as Senator Short said, both the fiscal imperative of privatisation and the bigger benefits to the economy. Importantly—and it does not come out in debates about privatisation very often but it should—if you ensure that you get a higher return on the Commonwealth's own assets, if you have an efficient economy and an efficient public sector economy, of course, the government, as a part of the economy as a whole, is better able to direct its resources and its policy towards helping those who need greater assistance from the Commonwealth government than others. Certainly, that is a very important part of the debate.

I think the government would argue—and I am sure it has been argued at national Labor Party conferences on the last couple of occasions—that there is no great community benefit derived from the Commonwealth owning an organisation like Qantas and that the money is better spent in other areas. The massive capital injections that are required for a business of the nature of Qantas create a drain on the Commonwealth demand for funds which could be better spent in other areas; the government might even get a better return in other areas. I welcome the shift in the Labor Party's policy in this area. Certainly, we support the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill.

There are a couple of specific points I want to make about this bill. I want to put on the record something that should be there in relation to the benefits of privatisation and the motivations behind the government's privatisation in this current year's budget, of which Qantas forms a part, as it has in many previous budgets. The Qantas privatisation looks like an aeroplane waiting in one of the long queues at Sydney airport; it is finally going to make it on to the main runway from the taxi runways and it might actually lift off this time. We will give a big cheer when she takes off.

Honourable senators on all sides of the chamber—or just about all sides—will say to Qantas, James Strong, the employees, the passengers and certainly the shareholders of Qantas, that we hope it will be a very successful float and that Qantas will continue to be one of the great airlines of the world; that it will indeed be a profitable privatised entity; and, importantly for all Australians, that it will be a company and a service which will bring many people from all around the world to our shores so they can spend lots of money in our shops on Australian produced goods, thus improving our current account and allowing our small businesses to flourish as a result of Qantas providing its passengers with a good service.

In relation to the impact of the proceeds of the privatisation, the government is making much play of the fact that the budget has been put into a $700 million-odd surplus this year; that it will actually reduce demands on Australia's capital markets and therefore reduce pressure on interest rates. It is certainly something that Senator Cook has said in public statements. It is certainly something that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has sold during his selling spree of the budget on radio stations around the country. When people say it will not have any impact on interest rates he says, `No, we're reducing the Commonwealth's call on capital markets by these billions of dollars and therefore the pressure on interest rates will go down.'

Those who look closely at these things know that privatisations do not necessarily do that. I am actually about halfway through reading former Senator Peter Walsh's book Confessions of a Failed Finance Minister. On Sunday night on the plane I read page 109 where he refers to the effects of privatisation. He puts it in the very crisp, clear and simple language that he is renowned for putting complex economic arguments into, so that even mugs like me can understand. I want to quote it at this stage because he makes the point that just by privatising something you do not necessarily reduce the burden on the capital markets.

Clearly, the capital markets need to provide the capital for whoever buys it. I presume, even though I did not do much economics in my tertiary education, that the higher the foreign investment, the lower the call on Australian capital markets. To that extent, this bill might minimise that effect. I quote from former Senator Peter Walsh's book in relation to this matter as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: This does not necessarily mean the asset sales are wrong per se, but the argument that they lessen pressure on capital markets and interest rates by reducing the Budget deficit is fraudulent.

I guess Peter is calling the Prime Minister, and anyone else who is running that line, fraudulent. I am sure the Prime Minister would not take great offence; I am sure Mr Walsh has called the Prime Minister and previous Labor prime ministers worse than `fraudulent' in his time. He goes on to say:
The net effect on capital markets of government borrowing to fund a deficit, or private borrowings of the same amount to buy government assets is zero—or close to it.

I think that point needs to be made. I am sure that that will not feature highly on any discussion of this, but it needs to be understood that the vast bulk of the asset sales in this government's current budget will have very little effect on the demand on Australian capital markets.

PARA.TAB: In the days since the budget was announced, we have heard in the Senate and in the other place that pressure has come off interest rates as a result of the budget. I would welcome, as I am sure all members of this parliament would welcome, any reduction in the pressure on interest rates, because those people who are most affected on a day-to-day basis—those people who are repaying their home mortgages, and small businesses which are paying for their working capital—are indisputably paying some of the highest real interest rates in the world. The latest figures I saw were in the Economist magazine of about a month ago where an analysis of real interest rates in OECD nations showed that only Canada was pipping us.

I remind Senator Cook, since he is in this chamber and is obviously going to respond, that he was wrong when he said in the Senate—I think it was last week—that interest rates were higher under the previous Liberal government than they were and are under the Hawke and Keating governments. I ask him quite earnestly to go back and look at the figures for himself. I have had a good look at them both in nominal and real terms. Unfortunately, the ABS figures go back to only 1978, so if the years of 1976 and 1977 distort the figures, then I will stand corrected, as I hope the minister will.

Minister, you will find when you analyse real interest rates, as determined by the deflated business lending indicators—which the parliamentary library will provide you with—that under the previous Liberal government, real interest rates averaged 4.08 per cent. Under your time in government, real interest rates—the effective interest rate that affects the competitiveness of our businesses in Australia—were about 8.8 per cent. That is roughly twice the interest rate burden on business in Australia. I would be very happy if you came back to the Senate and corrected me if I am wrong. I would be even more happy if you came back to the Senate one day and apologised for misleading the Senate about this.

That is very important to Australian business. An important consequence of privatisation should be to reduce the Commonwealth's longer term debt burden. As Senator Short said, we believe that the best way to do that is to reduce its recurrent need to fund that debt burden, and use the proceeds of privatisations, such as Qantas, to reduce that public sector debt.

Privatisation—this is where I started and this is where I will end—should always be considered a policy that is not driven by ideology. It was painted as that by the Labor Party in the early 1980s for its political motives. I am glad that it has found other reasons and motives for privatising Qantas—it needs the money; in this case, to make it look like it has achieved a surplus.

Back in September 1990 I addressed this issue of privatisation, particularly the issue of the quantum, or the percentage, of an asset that the government might sell and the effect it would have on the sale price. At that stage, I think that 30 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank was going to be sold, and 49 per cent of the airline was going to be sold. It struck me at that time—and I had been around the place for only a few months in September 1990—that the Commonwealth was probably going to significantly affect the income it would receive from the sales by its decision to sell those small amounts.

I can understand the political imperatives on the government: it is easier to go to the national conference and say, `We are just going to sell a little bit of the bank and we will never sell the rest.' I am sure that those people in the Labor Party and at the national conference would cop 30 per cent, but not the whole lot—as they have obviously copped this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will not cop anything.

—They are this year; it is a good year for the Right. I addressed a question to Senator Button on 17 September in which I specifically asked him whether or not it would make a difference to the net proceeds if only a small bit was sold instead of selling a controlling interest. I also asked:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . does the Minister agree that the loss of once-off windfall proceeds of partial privatisation, due to offering less than an optimum level of equity, can never be recouped?

I thought the answer was fairly obvious, but Senator Button spent most of a page of Hansard explaining why that was not the case. Rather than go through the whole answer, because it is too lengthy, I seek leave to have page 2407 of the Senate Hansard of 17 September incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The Hansard read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
Privatisation

PARA.TAB: Senator CAMPBELL—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the Minister agree that a sustainable improvement in Australia's trade in services can be achieved only by the development of comparative advantage in our service sector? Does he agree that one of the central features of those economies that have developed this advantage is a high level of private provision of public services and privatisation? Would he also agree that many of the nations in the South East Asian region have been making rapid progress with privatisation, leaving Australia years behind? Finally, will the doctrinaire, anti-privatisation mindset of the left wing of the Australian Labor Party ensure that Australia misses the opportunity to develop comparative advantage in services, or will the Government pursue a privatisation program to expand opportunities for Australians to develop world competitive service industries?
Senator BUTTON—I would not get too excited about what Senator Campbell called the mindless mindset of left wing members of the Labor Party. I think he ought to be concerned about—
Senator Campbell—I didn't call it mindless; you did.

Senator BUTTON—That was the word I was just about to apply to the honourable senator's question. I think he ought to be a bit more concerned about some of the rhetoric inherent in his own question. I will tell the honourable senator what I will do for him: I will provide him as soon as possible with a comparative table of the public sector share of GDP in a number of OECD countries—all OECD countries, if he likes. He will find that the Australian public sector share of GDP is relatively low—in fact, very low—-compared with most of those countries.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Campbell asked a question in relation to a number of unspecified countries in the Asia-Pacific region. I will try to provide him with some figures on those countries, too. All of those countries are essentially mixed economies. Most of them are what we used to call command economics still in terms of their economic management. I do not think one can draw a great deal of comfort from that in seeking to establish a sort of ideological point in this debate. The facts do not support the honourable senator.

There is a different question as to what ought to be done about privatisation issues in Australia. That is the subject of a different debate. The point is that the public sector as a share of GDP here is not, as the question implies, very significant compared with other countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The point is that the government made it quite clear at that stage that these matters would not affect Commonwealth revenue. The government's decision since that time has proved Senator Button wrong. I think the decision to increase foreign equity also fits into the same principle.

PARA.TAB: At the Commonwealth level, there is still a lot of privatisation, a lot of contracting out and a lot of efficiency gains that can be made. I was most alarmed by what was said at a hearing of the Senate Finance and Public Administration References Committee, which met in the suburb of Liverpool some weeks ago to discuss service delivery in the Commonwealth. Witnesses from the Community and Public Sector Union were there. When I asked them whether they thought there was anything the Commonwealth did that could be contracted out or privatised, they said, `No, not a thing; it is absolutely necessary for all of these things to be done by Commonwealth government employees and the Commonwealth government.'

I have to say to the public sector union that we do not agree with its logic, and I am sure that the government does not either. There are many entities that the Commonwealth owns and things that the Commonwealth does which will serve the public and the taxpayer better if they are contracted out or privatised.

I am very glad to be able to stand in this parliament in 1995 and say that privatisation is clearly not a dirty word around this chamber any more. I hope and pray that enlightened trade unionists—and I am sure there are many of them—see that privatisation can be a good public policy and that it can assist the so-called battlers, those who are on lower incomes and suffer disadvantages in the Australian community, because we can ensure that taxpayers' dollars are expended far more effectively to assist them. The more efficiently the public sector is run, the more opportunities this economy will provide for those who do suffer disadvantage. It will allow the economy to grow at a faster rate and grow at a rate without increasing this nation's debt. I am very happy to lend my support to the passage of this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill. I think it is an important bill; indeed, in many ways it is quite an historic bill. I would like to record a few remarks and observations. There are a couple of aspects that I would like to draw attention to. It is intriguing to note that Chifley's heirs—to use the phrase that Mr Hawke used in about 1988—were not going to privatise the great government authorities, such as Qantas, Australian Airlines and the Commonwealth Bank. This bill shows just one of the many rapid changes in philosophy that the Keating Labor Party has had to make.

PARA.TAB: At the start of the 1980s, things like privatisation, smaller government and lower taxes were totally anathema to the Labor Party. It was interesting that today the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) felt he had to pick up the argument and say how much in favour of smaller government and deregulation the Labor Party is. He beat his chest on that front. Enterprise bargaining was a very dirty concept with the Labor Party in the early and latter parts of the 1980s. Look at the ideas which govern how the economy is managed. Hark back and think about where these ideas have all sprung from. Have they sprung from the bowels of the Labor Party? Have they come from the trade union movement and the philosophies expounded at federal conferences of the Labor Party? The answer is that they have not. The Labor Party, including the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), was vehemently opposed to privatisation, smaller government and deregulation.

What philosophic contribution did the Labor Party make during this period to the economic management of the economy? The only thing that Senator Cook could point to is the accord. It is not so much an innovation and help in policy making but something that effectively represents an area where the Labor Party tried in some ways to cloister the labour market from fully-fledged reforms. It is interesting to speak about the fact that the Labor Party has brought before this chamber a bill to privatise Qantas.

The brief remarks I wish to make involve a number of issues related to Qantas. I have brought them forward before this chamber in recent years. I am a Victorian senator. What has intrigued me about these great mergers which Mr Keating has driven—the merger of Qantas and Australian Airlines and the merger of the State Bank and the Commonwealth Bank—is that there has been a steady stream to my door of former employees or prospective former employees of these institutions. I have said to them on a number of occasions, `I am happy to assist you, but don't you have a trade union movement? Don't you have trade union leaders who are concerned about the particular issues that you raise?' I will not use the exact description that these trade union members have given of their union leaders; it would not be appropriate in a distinguished chamber like this. However, it did lead me to think just how different the Labor Party and the union leaders have become.

In the old days, the union leaders used to represent employees to the government. In other words, if employees felt they were being put on by their employers and the government, the trade union movement would very strongly make representations to the government. Something very interesting has happened that I wish to record.

My experience in relation to the employees and former employees of Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank is that trade union leaders represent the government to the employees. In other words, it is the role of the senior trade union officials to attempt to explain to employees why they should support government policy. As a result, the employees who are being displaced—sometimes in a quite callous way—as a result of government policies are really finding that they have no-one to speak for them. The very last thing the government and the trade union leaders want is for these employees to cause any problems.

I come from Victoria. There have been marches in the streets by the trade unions over the voluntary retrenchments that have been made in the Public Service by the Kennett government. There has not been one march or protest by the trade union leaders over the massive retrenchments by the Commonwealth Bank. About 8,000 individuals are involved, and that number is rising. One journalist spoke to me about this. I said, `Do you have any comments on the trade union leaders and the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association?' Apparently they did not wish to comment. It is not that they wanted to march in the streets; they did not even wish to comment. The employees of the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas are being forced to look elsewhere for people who can provide them with assistance.

Something rather important has happened. The Labor Party has dumped all its old philosophy. So it should have; it was from another period. In the old days, the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) and Senator Cook used to get up with their Karl Marx and read the odd extracts. They would feel that this was making a contribution to an understanding of the wider world. That has all changed. We understand that. Good on them; I am all in favour of it. The other big change has been in the trade union movement. The last thing that trade union leaders want to do is lose the government grants, government appointments to jobs and all the perks of office. They do not worry about the trade union members because they are seen as being expendable. Quite a number of trade union leaders do fulfil the traditional role.

It is interesting that in two areas—the Qantas area and the Commonwealth Bank area—the employees who have spoken to me believe that they have received no comfort from the trade union leaders. In the old days, the trade union leaders were concerned with protecting the employees and, in the case of Commonwealth authorities, representing them to government. Today the situation is different. Trade union leaders have a job to represent the government to the employees and to make sure that the employees do not cause any trouble or embarrassment, particularly in the lead-up to an election.

Something rather important has happened, the full effects of which are being washed through the community. Why are so many people refusing to join trade unions? Why are the trade unions losing members when they have had a government in office for 12 years that has given them every aid and comfort? The reality is that the employees no longer feel that many trade unions are prepared to represent their political interests. I put that on the record, because it is a tragedy when, in relation to a number of these government authorities, very real issues with employees could have been better handled had the trade union leadership been more vigorous.

I refer to the further example of Comcar. The TWU was on a promise from the government that it would not make any changes to Comcar. Apparently, that promise was junked within four weeks of the election. We have now had fairly widespread retrenchments of Comcar drivers. Many are pending in the next few weeks.

Comcar drivers have spoken to me. I have asked, `What is your trade union doing? What is the TWU doing? It is on a promise from government to protect your jobs.' Frankly, it is questionable whether such a promise should have been made. I have asked, `Why is it not making a fuss in the press about this?' The reality is that the job of the top people at the TWU is not to represent the interests of Comcar drivers to the government but to tell Comcar drivers to keep quiet and do what they are told. They say that they have made the best possible deal and that, for heavens sake, the drivers should not make a public fuss about it.

So I bring to the attention of the Senate those three particular government bodies in which I have had some contact with the employees. In each case the employees are fed up with the trade union leaders. My final and concluding comment is that I have attempted through Senate estimates, questions on notice and other processes to follow just what is happening with employees in relation to Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Order! It being 6.50 p.m., we will move to consideration of government documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I will speak briefly in relation to this document. This document is in relation to article 19 of the ILO constitution. The Australian government is required to submit the text of new conventions and recommendations to the competent authority—the Australian parliament. So this is one particular area—that is, the International Labour Organisation—where there is an automatic submission to the parliament before adoption. For adoption there must be two-thirds majority of the tripartite International Labour Conference. The purpose of this convention is to provide protection to part-time workers so that their working conditions are the same as or at least equivalent to those of comparable full-time workers.

PARA.TAB: The economic importance of part-time work and the need for employment policies to take into account the role of part-time work in facilitating additional employment opportunities must be recognised. This is from the text, but it is extremely important in relation to Australia's situation. The Australian position in relation to this convention so far is that the ACTU has indicated that the government should support ratification of the convention. Currently, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has presented a preliminary view that there would be no obstacles to the ratification of the convention. However, it is looking at the complexity of some of the matters and it is still considering its options. I would like to think that the Chamber of Commerce and Industry does, out of principle, support the fact that part-time workers do deserve some protection of their standards of employment.

There is an overview presented of the current trends in Australia and it would not take much to see that there is a growth in the part-time work force. The major impetus has been mentioned to come from a combination of the intensification of competitive pressures, special demand and working conditions and the introduction of new technology. We know that there are lots of areas, our service industry in particular, where we go in and find that there are people specifically employed, for instance, for lunchtime only. There is no carryover. They do not necessarily work through the day. They are employed specifically to service customers at lunchtime.

I would have to say that growth in the part-time work force assists the government in helping to fudge unemployment statistics. Often it means that the government can talk about the number of jobs. People might be in part-time jobs to survive or to pay their mortgage. Some people might have to have two or three jobs. The reality is also that, when you have a greater percentage of people on part-time jobs, you are not necessarily talking about an increase in welfare across the community. You might be talking about a part-time job which a person may, under such things as case management, be forced to take which does not actually increase their financial circumstances to any great degree.

Part-time work is of particular importance to women, who make up the majority of part-time workers and workers with family responsibilities. There is a high participation of women in part-time work. This is a major factor in women's lower average earning compared to men. This is one factor which must be taken into consideration later when we are talking about the implications of compulsory superannuation contributions. What will be the impact in the long run of superannuation benefits once a person has retired? If the statistics clearly show, as we know they do, that women are much more likely to be in part-time or casual work, then it is obvious that the benefits of superannuation payments will be less. Of course, this is made worse by the fact that the government's contribution is less, depending on how much you are earning.

There is a regulating framework, but there is a problem sometimes in implementing this. The limited availability of permanent part-time employment under awards is mentioned. It is quite difficult to actually get a recognition of permanent part-time work. There is a failure of some awards and agreements to confine casual employment to employment which is short term, irregular or seasonal. There are relatively high weekly hours, a requirement for permanent part-time employment in some awards and agreements which may have forced some employees into casual employment.

There have been, however, a number of developments during the 1980s and 1990s. It seems that there are some improvements. However, casual employment has important disadvantages which may justify award based or other limitations on its use. It is a very insecure form of employment and it is not generally associated with many of the award benefits which are associated with other forms of employment.

What we see in Australia, according to the report, is large scale and long-term casualisation combined with limited scope for movement into the permanent work force which could threaten the achievement of objectives such as improving the overall level of skill in the work force, encouraging lifelong skill acquisition and promoting equal employment opportunity. It should be worked in for the fact that most people on this type of work are less likely to be members of a union because of the nature of the work and, therefore, are doubly disadvantaged. It is very necessary for Australia to ratify this treaty and I trust that there will at least be some debate about the benefits of doing so. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Order! I propose the question:
That the Senate do now adjorn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to continue a speech which I began last week and which concerns the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories and its lack of care in the preparation of materials that it put on the Australian market and which were used for the treatment of large numbers of human patients. Tonight I wish to speak about the disease CJD, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. This is a disease with a spontaneous incidence of about one per million of the population. In the approximately 2,600 people who have received pituitary hormones prepared by the CSL there have already been four cases of CJD. As this is a disease with a very long incubation period, it is almost certain that other cases will appear.

PARA.TAB: Knowledge of diseases of this general class began to appear in the 1930s with knowledge of the transmissibility of scrapie, a disease of sheep. In 1934-35 a vaccine prepared against another disease of sheep, louping ill, was used in the United Kingdom to vaccinate sheep. The vaccine was prepared from the brains and spleens of sheep and was treated with formalin to sterilise it and to ensure that it did not transmit any disease. This was and still is a standard procedure. While the sheep that received the vaccine were protected from louping ill, some 18 months to 2 years later they began to develop scrapie. In short, a vaccine which had been correctly prepared, in which the active agent had been successfully killed and which conferred proper immunity as intended nonetheless transmitted another fatal neurological disease in an unexpected manner.

In 1936 French research showed that scrapie could be transmitted from sheep to goats. Thus, 30 years before CSL put human pituitary hormones prepared from human pituitary glands collected at autopsies into the marketplace, we began to collect knowledge of a class of infectious neurological diseases which were transmissible, which were caused by a presumed virus and in which the infectious particle was resistant to formalin.

For many years the disease of `kuru' has afflicted some of the tribes in New Guinea. The work of Gadjusec and others in Australia in the late 1950s and early 1960s showed that this was also caused by what came to be known as a slow virus. Kuru was transmitted through the eating of human nervous tissue. There was a long latency between the eating of this material and the appearance of the symptoms, but once these appeared there was a steady and inexorable progression of mental deterioration leading to death.

In 1958 Gadjusec was working on kuru in Australia. He visited England and saw some of the work on scrapie. He published work on kuru in 1959 in the Lancet. By 1963 kuru was shown to be a transmissible disease and the agent responsible for its transmission was shown to be resistant, not only to formalin but ultraviolet light, phenols and autoclaving. Recognising that CJD in humans caused very similar changes in the brain to both scrapie in sheep and kuru in humans he placed CJD in the same general class of diseases. Some of the work on kuru was done in the CSL laboratories. CSL scientists at the time were therefore well aware of the work going on kuru, the infectious nature of the causative agent and the nature of the disease process.

By 1966 CJD had been shown to be a transmissible disease and by 1970 CJD had been transmitted in the laboratory to a range of other primates.This sets the background against which CSL entered the business of preparing human pituitary hormones for the treatment of human diseases.

By the early 1960s it was known that there was a group of transmissible infectious agents, affecting nervous tissue, brain and spinal cord, and in which the active disease appeared many years or decades after first infection. Moreover, the agents responsible for these diseases were very resistant to all the normal sterilising agents and there was no treatment for any of these diseases once they manifested themselves. The diseases were then fairly rapidly progressive with death as the inevitable result.

It was extremely likely that there would be other diseases discovered which would show similar characteristics. One can never be sure that all the diseases of a particular class have been discovered and characterised.

In June 1963 CSL was asked to investigate the manufacture of pituitary hormones. These had been made on a small and experimental scale by individuals working out of university laboratories. Three of the many pituitary hormones were of particular interest: growth hormone, follicle stimulating hormone and luteinising hormone. The latter two are responsible for stimulating the formation and ripening of the Graafian or egg follicle in the ovary and the formation of the corpus luteum which maintains a pregnancy. The use of these two had been shown to be effective in treating some cases of infertility in women. Growth hormone had been shown to be effective in stimulating the growth of stunted children. Once the effectiveness of treatment with these hormones became known there was a push by both doctors and patients to make them generally available.

The work at CSL was undertaken. The bulk production of these hormones involved the collection of pituitary glands from human cadavers, the making up of a batch of such glands, and the extraction of the hormones from these batches. As it turned out some 1,300 glands were combined before the extraction process was applied. Thus it was likely that the inclusion of a single gland which was infected with one of the slow virus agents would have infected the whole batch. Also, it would be essentially impossible to sterilise either the batch or any of the separated hormones. And by the very nature of these agents it was impossible to tell whether any particular pituitary gland was infected.

This is all common sense and does not depend on the wisdom of hindsight. As a consequence of this commonsense conclusion a prominent scientist advised the Department of Health in 1965 not to allow CSL to proceed with the preparation and distribution of hormones from human pituitary glands. Nonetheless, CSL went ahead with the blessing of the Commonwealth department.

One must now turn to the method of preparation of the hormones from the batches of pituitary glands. After maceration and other steps the separation of the three hormones of interest was achieved by chromatography, specifically by gel filtration. This involves applying the mixture to the top of a column of gel and allowing the material to run through the gel. The different fractions run through at different rates and emerge from the bottom of the column at different times. These different fractions can thus be collected. Now it was known that the virus fraction would run through the column the quickest and would be the first fraction collected. It seems that CSL assumed that the separations would be so complete that the later fractions, which contained the hormones of interest, would therefore be virus free. But no separation by column chromatography is so complete and it is quite clear that some virus would remain attached to the gel and the glassware, thus contaminating every fraction which emerged from the column later.

Again in 1965 a prominent scientist advised the Department of Health that because viruses would elute first every later fraction collected from the column would be contaminated and that therefore sterility of any of the hormones used for hormone injection could not be guaranteed.

In summary then we had a situation in which no pituitary gland could be guaranteed free from the carriage of slow viruses, which we now know to be prions; even smaller and more difficult to detect than viruses. We know that at the time of the start of CSL's large scale manufacture of pituitary hormones we had good knowledge of several `viruses'—prions—capable of causing severe rapidly fatal neurological disease but with a long latency and we knew that these infectious agents was remarkably resistant to all the usual sterilants used in the preparation of vaccines and other biological products for injection into humans. And we know that some scientists had put these fact together and advised against the manufacture of human pituitary hormones.

The making and distribution of pituitary hormones began in the mid-1960s and continued to the mid-1980s. The company went ahead despite the warnings and despite the commonsense conclusion that should have been drawn regarding the risks based on the evidence available at the time. It also seems that no microbiologist was employed on the production line of the human pituitary hormones. Is it surprising that we have now seen cases of CJD appearing in the recipients of these products? Of course it is not!

CSL has now been sold. The sale was accompanied by a prospectus and an indemnity regarding past actions. Did the prospectus reveal the possibility of legal action against CSL? And how far does the indemnity protect CSL from actions which many, one might say most, would regard as not just unfortunate or unpredictable outcomes of actions taken in good faith and with proper precautions given the state of knowledge at the time, but actions which were negligent and well below any reasonable standard of scientific and medical care given the knowledge that was clearly available at the time?

CSL was not observing a code of good manufacturing practice. But more than that, it was ignoring the risks to the recipients of its products, risks which any reasonably competent scientist working in this field could reasonably have foreseen. The risks were foreseen, the Commonwealth Department of Health was advised not to proceed with the preparation, yet the department and CSL went ahead.

Legal challenge to CSL and the government is being prepared. It is quite unfair that private litigants should be saddled with the whole expense of sorting out the role of government and government agencies in this mess to say nothing of the possibility that the present privatised CSL still carries some of the blame.

This whole episode goes to the very heart of the proper responsibility of government, of the proper discharge of that responsibility. It must be investigated by a Senate committee. I shall be moving in that direction shortly. I urge each and every senator to examine the information that is available for I am sure that any dispassionate reading of this story will convince any fair-minded senator that this is the fair and appropriate course of action.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise some concerns that the Australian Democrats have and which were placed on the record this morning in our dissent to the report of the Economics Legislation Committee on the Competition Policy Reform Bill. That bill raises a fundamental issue of process as well as a number of substantive concerns. The competition policy agenda incorporates a radical rethinking of the role of government and government services.

PARA.TAB: This rethink has occurred within a narrow ideological framework based on the concept that competition, just like greed, is good at all times. There has been inadequate public debate on what this agenda means, where it is leading and why this narrow framework should be imposed on the provision of community services, the furthering of ecological sustainability, improving consumer protection, health and safety or the promotion of social equity.

These issues were not being adequately debated, in public or in parliament, before the COAG agreement was signed. Most of the detail of the government's agenda is contained in the three agreements signed at COAG in April. The Democrats foreshadow that, in an attempt to broaden the debate over the impact of the implementation of the government's agenda, we will be moving to set up a parliamentary inquiry to look at the agreements and how they will be implemented.

A number of matters in the Competition Policy Reform Bill raise particular concerns and amendments concerning these matters are under consideration. I will address them briefly. The first is the definition of public service. Clause 75 of the bill seeks, in proposed section 2C, to define what government activities do or do not constitute a business activity. This section may need to be amended to further clarify what is or is not business to ensure that core services such as health, education, welfare, employment and environmental protection programs are clearly excluded. Otherwise, we could be legitimising heading down the Victorian local government road, in which everything from library services to swimming pools is regarded as a business to be run on a user pays basis, without regard to the public benefit.

The second concern is about the access regime. Proposed part IIIA establishes the access regime for infrastructure. However, in establishing a right to access for private providers, it fails to guarantee the provision of quality services to all users of the infrastructure. With cherry picking of the most profitable aspects of the facility for contracting out, the public sector provider could be forced to provide unprofitable services at higher costs to the taxpayer and to the disadvantage of consumers who are apparently to be deprived of cross-subsidisation and community service obligations.

This is clearly unsatisfactory and provision needs to be made to avoid such developments or, at the very least, to address the consequences of the action proposed. This applies in particular to people living in regional and remote areas and to measures needed to protect Australia's natural environment, a need which is likely to be ignored or neglected in a situation of free-for-all competition.

The next issue I wish to address is local government. While it is represented at COAG, the local government sector is not party to the agreements. There remains a serious and legitimate concern in local government that competition policy will be implemented by the states to the detriment of the local government sector. Those in Victoria would be familiar with the cavalier treatment meted out to local government in that state. The federal government must require the states to adequately consult with local government, with a view to reaching agreement, before implementing any aspect of competition policy reform. The bill may have to be amended to ensure this. Finally, there is the issue of representation. The proposed composition of the National Competition Council is in need of review. At the very least, provision needs to be made for the inclusion of a consumer representative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning I raised some questions, in a notice of motion, relating to the continuing breaches of the Australian Corporations Law and the Australian Securities Commission requirements by the New South Wales Labor Party's subsidiary, Labor Centenary House Pty Ltd. That is the company involved in the chaotic and disastrous redevelopment plan for part of Sussex Street. It is involved in that plan with the AWU-FIME, which also has financial problems, and the Seamen's Union.

PARA.TAB: This morning I outlined the fact that eventually, after breaching the ASC requirements, the Labor Party's subsidiary had come out with its financial accounts for the 12 months to December 1993—about six to eight weeks ago—and revealed a deficit of shareholders' funds of $2.2 million, with current liabilities of $3.8 million and total assets of only $1.6 million. When these financial accounts were filed about eight weeks ago, the group also filed the 1991 and 1992 accounts—almost three years late. That also is in breach of Securities Commission requirements.

These accounts were filed only when the Securities Commission began undertaking deregistration action against the Labor Party's subsidiary for failing to meet the requirements of the law. The problem seems to start from the very top. The piggery companies of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) could never meet the requirements of the Corporations Law. The New South Wales ALP is incapable of meeting the requirements of the Corporations Law.

I mentioned this morning that Mr John Della Bosca wrote to the Australian Securities Commission saying that the financial data could not be provided earlier as no commitment could be given to sign the accounts because, ultimately, the control of the company rested with the voluntary officials. They were listed as Mr Davies, Mr J.B. McLean and Mr Arthur Gietzelt.

In November 1992 the ASC had written to Labor Centenary House Pty Ltd saying it wanted to know whether the company was still in operation because the ASC had not received any reports, reports that were required by law. Mr John Della Bosca, on 15 September 1992, wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: We are currently experiencing administrative difficulties affecting the company's accounting and secretarial functions. We are addressing these issues but I believe it will take six months to be in a position to lodge annual returns.

Those secretarial difficulties certainly lasted a long time. The financial accounts did not come in in six months time, in the middle of 1993, but in the fourth month of 1995. I am intrigued by this persistent breaching of the Corporations Law. This Labor Party subsidiary did not have an annual general meeting as required by law. We do not know whether the accounts it did file had been audited. There is no indication that they had been, although the company said it had appointed an auditor. Apart from those messes, what is intriguing is the ALP's Sydney building in Sussex Street. It bought the disaster in 1990 for $3.8 million. Property experts, accordingly to the Australian Financial Review a couple of days ago, now value it at around $1.5 million.

PARA.TAB: The AWU-FIME union associate who is involved in this fiasco said a little while ago that this matter has been thrown into doubt by a massive internal dispute between the amalgamated union's two partners—the former Australian Workers Union and the Federation of Industrial, Manufacturing and Engineering Employees. The financial report released by a former FIME official recently revealed that the union had debts of over $17 million.

We know the New South Wales Labor Party is technically bankrupt and is being kept afloat by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia—for one reason or another which I have never been able to work out—and the Commonwealth Bank, as I understand it, has paid off $10,000 a week just to meet its interest bill. But what about the financial situation of the AWU-FIME with this huge debt? I understand that in Queensland, in particular, various employees of the union have been advised that the union intends to divert funds that have been provided for the future benefit of retiring employees, particularly by way of long service leave, into paying some of the current operating debts of the AWU-FIME.

No doubt the federal Labor Party would not like to see that sort of thing happen to its industrial wing. I wonder what sort of control the Department of Industrial Relations has over this kind of diversion of what are supposed to be future benefits for retiring employees by way of long service leave. Is it possible for the department to prevent this money being diverted by this union?

On the face of it the union appears to be plundering the future retirement benefits of employees to pay what I understand is $3 million as part of the union's huge debts. I understand that many of those debts consist of telephone and credit card bills which have been run up by the union's head office in Sydney. The Queensland employees of the union are not too impressed by anything south of the border—particularly rugby league teams—and are certainly not impressed that, because the amalgamated union of the AWU and the FIME is apparently incapable of running itself officially, their retirement incomes are being put at risk.

I do not know if any minister is specifically in charge of these matters. As the AWU-FIME is very much a right wing union, I do not know that any of the ministers here would care very much about it. It seems that there is a problem facing union employees.

We have seen many instances where employees of unions have had to take action in the Industrial Relations Court against their employers. We have a fascinating situation where perhaps some of the worst employers are union officials. We have already seen that the piggery of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was a terrible employer in that it breached award wages on at least three occasions. It seems to me that the Labor movement's industrial or political wing cannot meet the industrial relations law or the Corporations Law. It is consistently in breach of ASC requirements. It would be a very nice idea if the Labor movement could get its act in order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, in part of April and early May I was very privileged to make some study visits as a parliamentarian to a number of countries in Australia's interests and in my own interests in parliamentary activities in the Senate. I was able to visit Turkey as deputy chairman of the Australia-Turkey friendship group to attend the 80th Anzac Day commemoration services at Anzac Cove, at a point near the Dardanelles, and at Lone Pine.

PARA.TAB: As the invitee of the Turkish parliament and government I also attended the 75th anniversary of the Turkish Grand National Assembly—the national parliament of Turkey—a special parliamentary session, a presidential lunch and other activities. I wish to thank the Turkish Ambassador in Australia, Mr Orhan Aka, and his staff. I also wish to thank the Australian Ambassador to Turkey, Mr David Evans, for the assistance that he gave to me, my wife, and a number of parliamentarians who were able to attend the Gallipoli commemorations and the 75th anniversary of the Turkish parliament.

Ataturk, the founder of the modern Turkish nation, is pivotal to both Gallipoli and the formation of the parliament. Time does not allow me to expand on the importance of these two events in Turkey during the month of April. As an Australian senator it was a pleasure to be part of those activities. Following the activities in Ankara, Istanbul and Gallipoli, my wife and I visited Ephesus on the Aegean coast for two days. We were delighted to see the ancient city of Ephesus and the surrounding region.

On my way back to Australia I also visited Zimbabwe. I am a member of the Africa subcommittee of the parliament. The Joint Foreign Affairs Defence and Trade Committee has undertaken to look at reassessing Australia's relations with southern Africa—in particular the 11 SADAC countries. The two pivotal nations in this review will be Zimbabwe and South Africa.

I was able to have a wide range of talks in Harare which were facilitated by our High Commissioner, Kerry Sibraa, the former President of the Senate. High Commissioner Sibraa has been visiting the subcommittee in Canberra this week. I could not think of a better host than High Commissioner Sibraa and his wife Julie and I wish to thank them especially for the discussions that we had over several days while I was carrying out a range of meetings and visits related to the countries to which our High Commissioner is accredited: Zimbabwe, Angola, Botswana, Namibia, Zambia and Mozambique.

It was possible for my wife and I to visit Victoria Falls and Hwange National Park—only for a day and a half; it was rather rushed—and also to go down to Great Zimbabwe where we saw the walls that constitute the greatest civilised monument in the whole of sub-Sahara Africa. I would love to expand on these experiences, and I will do so in contributing to the parliamentary inquiry.

Australia has been very close to modern Zimbabwe from the time of its independence. I recall my own parliamentary leader at the time, former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser, making a magnificent contribution towards the achievement of full democracy and independence for Zimbabwe. His actions are very well remembered by the officials that I met in that country. They are looking for a close relationship with Australia and I hope that will be the outcome of the recommendations of the parliamentary inquiry.

Zimbabwe has very substantial agricultural and mining resources and it has the basis for being one of the most prosperous states in Africa. There is political maturity and leadership in many ways exceeding South Africa's because South Africa is still in transition to putting in place full democracy under President Mandela.

I wish to thank High Commissioner Patel in Canberra for the way in which he facilitated my visit and gave me every kind of personal encouragement to pursue the questions I wished to ask. I was able to visit the parliament, the ministry of foreign affairs, the major university in Harare, and the art gallery to see, in particular, Shona sculpture.

In South Africa I visited Capetown and Stellenbosch. I met parliamentarians in the parliamentary buildings. I was also able to have discussions with representatives of the political science department at the university. I thank High Commissioner Ross Burns in Capetown and Pretoria for the excellent way he facilitated my visit, for making numerous arrangements, and for becoming an enduring personal friend as a result of our working together.

I visited Johannesburg and Pretoria, only too briefly, but in a way that was enormously to my own advantage in trying to understand more about the transition in which South Africa is now involved. South Africa has the potential to be the chief economic powerhouse of the continent. I wish to place on record that, as a part of the Indian Ocean states consultations, Australia and South Africa and the other countries bordering on the Indian Ocean should increasingly be involved in regional discussions and cooperation. I wish also to give my thanks to High Commissioner Stein for his advice prior to my leaving Canberra.

I should finally refer to the brief visits, in transition to these principal objectives, that I was able to make to the Netherlands, Ireland and the United Kingdom. I wish to thank Ambassador Michael Tate, in the Netherlands, for his extraordinarily generous welcome to me and the arrangements he made, especially for me to see the international court. It is very important at the moment with the Timor case involving Australia in Den Haag. I was able to follow-up academic and other interests in Amsterdam, Delft and Leyden. With our ambassador and with Senator Denman, who was a most pleasant companion, we also went to see the launch of Batavia, a reconstructed sailing ship, by Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands.

I also had discussions in Dublin about the Northern Ireland peace process with representatives of the foreign ministry of Ireland, which were hosted by Ambassador Eddy Stevens, whom I thank. I learned a considerable amount about the current programs in the International Fund for Ireland, to which Australia contributed $7 million recently. I was able to make visits to Tipperary, Cork and Kerry. I thank members and former members of the Dail for their welcome to me on this, my return visit to Ireland.

In the United Kingdom I had a brief meeting with High Commissioner Neal Blewett, and I thank him for his hospitality. I was able to visit my old university college in Cambridge, to have a most pleasant 24 hours in London and to spend a small amount of time in northern Cornwall.

I sum up this brief report about my parliamentary visit to these countries by saying that—especially in Turkey, Zimbabwe and South Africa—we have continuing important agendas which parliamentarians, in dialogue with the Australian government, need to pursue to Australia's best advantage.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 1 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the estimated number of albatross killed by tuna fishing activities in the oceans to the south of Australia and what percentage of this toll is due to the use of longline fishing techniques.
(2) Which tier of government and what department is responsible for overseeing fishing operations in the oceans to the south of Australia.
(3) Which species of albatross are: (a) currently considered to be declining in number; and (b) considered to be endangered.
(4) What measures, if any, is the Federal Government taking to address the threat to albatross numbers from tuna fishing.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Albatrosses spend the bulk of their lives at sea, returning to land only to breed. Twelve countries, including Australia, have jurisdiction over the breeding grounds but the migratory range of albatrosses includes the territorial waters of many other countries and the high seas. There are world-wide reports of a sustained decline in many of the albatross populations (eg. Weimerskirch, H. and Jouventin, P. (1987) Journal of Animal Ecology 56:1043-1055; Croxall, J.P. (1991) Reproductive Constraints on Albatrosses 20th International Ornithological Congress. 1:281-302; and Garnett, S. (1992) The Action Plan for Australian Birds. Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service) and capture on the baited hooks used in longline tuna fishing is considered the major cause (eg. Brothers, N.P. (1991) Albatross mortality and associated bait loss in the Japanese longline fishery in the Southern Ocean Biological Conservation 55:255-268; and Croxall 1991).

Direct mortality in association with commercial fishing has been documented for 12 of the 14 species. It is this fisheries-related mortality that has been implicated in the decline of albatross populations.

Understanding the nature and magnitude of albatross bycatch associated with commercial fisheries is in its early stages. In 1989, it was estimated that the Japanese component of the Southern Bluefin tuna fishery worldwide had incidentally taken 44 000 albatrosses per year. Since then fishing effort has virtually halved and mitigation measures have been introduced, although the initial analysis has not been repeated. There are no data regarding high seas or domestic tuna longline fisheries of other nations (eg Indonesia, Korea Taiwan or the USA) although each of these fisheries is reported to "catch birds" in association with tuna longline activity. There are no data available on the incidental catch of albatrosses by the Australian domestic tuna longlining fleet.

Other threats to populations of albatross include ingestion of plastic particles at sea, oil (leading to loss of thermoregulatory ability), threats to breeding habitat (eg by trampling, predation of eggs and chicks—particularly cats and rats), tourism, extreme climatic conditions and the avian pox virus (Gales, R. (1993) Cooperative Mechanisms for the Conservation of Albatross Australian Nature Conservation Agency, Project No. 148). There are no data to indicate what percentage of the decline in albatross numbers can be attributed to these causes although anecdotal evidence suggests that these threats are likely to be insignificant compared to longline fishing.

(2) Generally, the area from 3 nautical miles to 200 nautical miles offshore (known as the Australian fishing zone) is the responsibility of the Commonwealth. The management of Commonwealth fisheries falls within the Portfolio of the Minister for Resources. Commonwealth fisheries are administered by the Australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA) and policy matters and international fisheries access arrangements are negotiated on behalf of Australia by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

In general terms, the States and Territories have fisheries responsibilities for inland waters and for waters between the low water mark and 3 nautical miles offshore. Under the Offshore Constitutional Settlement it is possible for one Government to have responsibility for the management of a total fishery (outside the jurisdictional areas described above) in order to rationalise the management of that fishery.

(3) Over their entire geographic range, population declines have been demonstrated for six of the fourteen species of albatrosses (Gales, 1993). The species for which this has been documented are: Diomeden exulans (Wandering Albatross), D. nigripes (Black-footed Albatross), D. melanophris (Black-browed Albatross), D. cauta (Shy Albatross), D. chrysostoma (Grey-headed Albatross) and Phoebetria fusca (Sooty Albatross). These species are considered to be threatened. Two species are considered to be endangered (D. albatrus and D. amsterdamensis). The population status of three species is unknown (D. bulleri (Bullers Albatross), D.chlororynchus (Yellow-nosed Albatross) and P. palpebrata (Light-mantled Sooty Albatross)). Direct mortality in association with commercial fishing operations has been documented for 12 of the 14 species (nb. D. irrorata (Waved Albatross) and D. albatrus (Short-tailed Albatross) are not recorded as being associated with tuna longline fisheries).

In Australian waters Garnett (1992), in the Action Plan for Australian Birds, recommends listing D. exulans chionoptera (Wandering Albatross—Macquarie Island sub-species), as endangered and D. chrysostoma (Grey-headed Albatross) as vulnerable.

(4) The Federal Government is undertaking a range of cooperative measures to address this problem. I have asked the Australian Nature Conservation Agency (ANCA) to ensure continued funding for research into measures to address the documented decline in albatross numbers due to tuna longline fisheries. ANCA is currently providing the second year of funding for a three year project to the Tasmanian Department of Environment and Heritage. Dr Nigel Brothers and Dr Rosemary Gales are working jointly on this project to investigate the conservation status of albatrosses in Australian waters and the nature and the extent of the albatross-fishery interaction. Their work includes development of mitigation measures and cooperative links to encourage use of these deterrent devices both within Australia's fishing zone and, importantly, on the high seas.

Over the past three years ANCA has allocated some $270 000 to this work. The Australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA) has contributed over $300 000 from the Bilateral Japan Australia) Access fee and industry contribution, and the Tasmanian Department of Environment and Land Management has contributed some $50 000, as well as the full time resources of Dr Brothers.

The Australian Antarctic Division, within my Portfolio will co-host the first International Conference of the Conservation of Albatrosses in August 1995 in collaboration with the Tasmanian Department of Environment and Land Management. Delegates will attend from South America, South Africa, New Zealand, North America, South America, United Kingdom, Japan and Australia. A workshop to examine the interaction between albatrosses and tuna longline fisheries will be held immediately following the Conference to discuss the global issue.

At its last meeting in Hobart the Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources (CCAMLR) adopted a new Conservation Measure which will require mandatory mitigation measures to be used to reduce the incidental mortality of seabirds during fishing operations in CCAMLR waters (south of 60 degrees S). This Conservation Measure became binding on all Parties (with the exception of France and South Africa who entered reservations) on 7 May 1995. Australian scientists contributed significantly to the development of these conservation measures and were active in pushing for its adoption during the Conference of Parties.

The Convention on the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna, a trilateral treaty between Australia, Japan and New Zealand ratified in 1994, establishes an Ecologically Related Species Working Group which will examine, among other things, the issue of incidental take of seabirds by tuna longline fisheries. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy has the lead in these negotiations and seeks input from AFMA, ANCA, other Government Departments and non-government organisations in preparing its position. Australia has been pushing very strongly for this group to consider experimental testing of the effectiveness of various mitigation measures which will reduce the incidental take of seabirds by tuna longline fisheries operations.

From November 1995, the use of bird scaring devices (tori poles) will be made mandatory in the Australian fishing zone for all Japanese tuna longline vessels fishing south of 30 degrees S. AFMA is considering implementing similar measures on larger Australian tuna longline vessels fishing in the same waters.

ANCA convenes a Seabird Fisheries Interactions Group comprising scientists (both fisheries and seabird biologists) representing fisheries interests at the Federal Government level and conservation interests (both Government and non-government). The Group provides a forum for coordinating the development of cooperative mechanisms for the conservation of albatrosses.
